BistroMath profile analyser v4.25


The image above contains clickable hotspots

Introduction to version 4.00 and above
The support for x87 processor on the Windows10/64 bits platform is deprecated by Microsoft. As BistroMath no longer is developed on a genuine Windows 32 bits based compiler there are some small effects that inhibit exact reproduction with previous versions.
BistroMath supports all parameters introduced in (the prepublication of) NCS-33.
Now multiple data sets can be kept in a history list.
See also the introduction to the challenges of profile analysis.

Overview
The BistroMath application originally was designed to analyse measurements from the OmniPro-Accept software. Versions 6.2A, 6.3, 6.6c, 7.3 and 7.4  have been tested. In BistroMath also the OmniPro binary file rfb-type, PTW (.mcc) files, Sun Nuclear text (.snctxt) files, SNC clipboard data, Varian w2CAD, Nucletron wtx and wda files, CMS/XiO profiles, hdf profiles, Pips-profiles and generic two column data files are accepted. The program hooks up to the chain of clipboard viewers and thus analyses all information which is placed on the clipboard. When a measurement is copied from the OmniPro sytem (or any other source), the data will be found as valid profile data by BistroMath in the clipboard. When available and set as preferred behavior, a reference profile is loaded for comparison. For a inline/crossline scan always the field borders are detected, including profiles fully outside the main axis. Also files with multiple curves can be read. For selected 2D-arrays (at this moment only the PTW Starcheck-maxi) a multiprofile dataset can be stored as reference.
As means of analysis an optional gamma analysis can be calculated when a reference profile is loaded.
Any profile may be stored as reference. When available and if configured, the measurement will be divided by the reference profile. In this case the flatness of the division curve will be given as a bracketed value, as shown in the example above.
The program uses a fixed axis convention to store the data internally. This is reflected in the written data files.
All reference profiles are resampled to the measurement grid and, for inline/crossline profiles, aligned with the measurement.
For depth dose curves a model can be applied to parameterise the data. These data are put on the messages tab and are written into several file formats.
For any input type OD to dose conversion and / or background correction may be applied. A file conversion tab is added to convert and rename groups of files.
A more thematic overview can be found in concepts and Comparison with references.
The Quick Start guide attempts to cover the different application areas.
The Results panel can by completely configured by the user. This opens also the opportunity to convert all positions to mm (or microfurlongs). The Dutch NCS-33 publication is fully supported.


For depth dose curves the absolute analysis values and graphic display/relative analysis results have separate, configurable, normalisation points. If this leads to a maximum outside the range 99%-101% the text is altered to "RDD" as shown above. A Nelder-Mead optimisation algorithm is applied to a model to describe depth dose curves.

Operation
All three curves Measurement, Reference and Calculation can be toggled with respectively "M", "R" and "C". The vertical indicator lines which show the In-Field area are toggled with "I".
Zooming may be done by creating a box in the desired area from topleft to bottomright with the left mouse button pressed. When the Zoom-item is checked, auto-zooming is done for profiles.
Panning is done by creating a box from bottomright to topleft with the left mouse button pressed or by pressing "U".
Values will be shown when the Values-item is checked. Note that there may be small differences as the given numbers are the true normalised values but the graphs are normalised over a small area around the normalisation point to give the best graphical alignment.
Internally all profiles are stored in G to T direction, A to B direction and Up to Down direction respectively to avoid any mixup with different data sources. Therefore the data ordering may be inverted when rewriting data.
Please also read the topic on getting started with FFF.


Beta status limitations
The SNC-clipboard format is based on a private patch which might or might not be published by Sun Nuclear. The Varian format is untested independently.

Legal issues
The user and only the user is responsible for his or hers decisions concerning the proper functioning of radiation therapy equipment. This software is merely a tool to support these decisions. With using BistoMath you agree with these conditions.

Privacy, disk access and communication through internet
This program has no features for data transfer other then to and from a disk location. Only disk locations given by the user will be accessed. BistroMath cannot (and therefore will not) contact any server for any purpose through the internet.

Checksum (sha256)
Th checksum is calculated using https://defuse.ca/checksums.htm#checksums. This value can be found during the installation procedure and on the website.

Comparison with references as QA method (overview)

Introduction
All QA-protocols currently (2016) only describe classical flattened fields. Both the dose differences within the In-Field area (usually 80% of the nominal field width) and the width of the penumbra region should not exceed certain limits. New developments are upcoming however. 
A more schematic overview is presented in challenges for profile evaluation.


presentation Eric Klein, chair of TG-142

This concept has several complications.
  • Small field accelerators like the Elekta Beam Modulator usually have a much more "dome-shaped" field. The flatness parameter is typically is 4-5%. This is much more than the normal tolerances.
  • It does not work at all for wedged fields.
  • It does not work for flattening filter free (FFF) beams.
    For all of those fields also the field size definition becomes problematic. As modern treatment planning systems (TPS) can handle non-flat fields effortlessly, linacs should reproduce the configured models in the TPS within tight limits. Both the general accepted tolerances for flatness and the intrinsic (non-)flatness are (much) higher the preferred range of differences with the TPS.



    Therefore a comparison of a (measured) field with a reference is the central element in BistroMath. Now a relative flatness can be derived from the calculated {measurement divided by reference} profile. With a good QA-regime this relative flatness can be held below 1% under standard conditions and 3% for all gantry angles. As alternative also a gamma calculation can be presented.
    To cope with limitations of the 50% definition for field size, BistroMath has two alternative methods, the maximum of the first derivative and sigmoid fitting.


    Concepts of implementation

    Automatic loading
    Working with references becomes cumbersome and error-prone when this has to be done manually. Therefore Bistromath is able to load a reference from a library based on the name of the scan type, linac, beam, field size, depth and wedge state. This library is a number of files in the references directory. When automatic loading of a reference is switched on, the appropriate file will be taken from this library, or when a temporary reference is set, that will be used.

    Filling the reference library
    Of course, when you start using BistroMath, this library is empty. All needed references must be loaded once and then stored as reference. However, you should unlock this feature, since it is locked at start.

    Types of references
    Currently three types of references can be used:
  • Single scans, opened as any supported file type, will be stored as OmniPro v6 ascii file in the library with a well-structured name.
  • Structured scan-sets for supported 2D-arrays will be stored in their original format in the library with a well-structured name that includes the type of 2D-array.
  • Unstructured multi reference files can be loaded as temporary reference when reference indexing is switched on. As unstructured files cannot be assigned with a well-structured name there is no automatic mode for loading these files. They can be opened directly as reference however.
  • A mirrored version of the measurement.

    Cross-referencing by Generic Beam lists
    When a clinic uses generic beam data to describe all beams of the same type (energy, brand, head type) in the clinic measurements of one machine might be compared with another. This can be done by adding an entry in the aliases tab as explained below. This establishes a fixed relation between two treatment units. When for different beams also different treatment units are referenced, a separate list is needed. The list is activated in the Reference menu. When active, this list is applied before the alias list.

    Cross-referencing or correcting data by applying aliases
    When a clinic uses generic beam data to describe all beams of the same type (energy, brand, head type) in the clinic measurements of one machine might be compared with another. This can be done by adding an entry in the aliases tab, putting the name of treatment unit of the measured data as "Key" and the equivalent reference unit as "Value". This alias is applied whenever any curve identification string is generated. This is fully compatible with automatic loading of references. Note that always the true name of the involved linac is displayed.

    Cross-referencing by ignoring the treatment unit name
    In the processing menu the option to ignore the name of the treatment unit can be activated. By definition this only works for temporary references as there is no way the know the alternatives. 


    Reference logics
    The following rules are applied to use references.

    1  Check state of Automatic Load of Reference
    When this first option in the Reference menu is not activated no comparison will be made.
     or
    If this option is switched on, continue with step 2.

    2  Check temporary reference state
    If temporary reference file is loaded then check whether this is a single curve ( » 4) or contains multiple scans ( » 3a).
     or
    No temporary reference is available ( » 3b).

    3a  A multiple scan reference is loaded
    If reference indexing is on, then use the internal index to find (and load when found) an alternative scan ( » 4).
     or
    The measurement and reference are of a known structured multi reference type and the Device specific Reference option in Reference menu is switched on to load the scan with the same scan number. The reference name will be derived from a combination of measured values, given parameters in the measurement file and the measurement device name ( » 3b).

    3b  The library is searched for a suitable reference
    (Note that loading any file is based solely on the name of the file. When active, first the Generic Beam list is applied, then all aliases are applied in this stage.)
    The measurement is not a known structured multi reference type: file identification is based on linac, scan type, beam, field size, depth and wedge state ( » 4).
     or
    The Device specific Reference option in Reference menu is switched on: file identification is based on linac, array identification, beam, field size, depth and wedge state. When this file search fails it is reported in the Messages tab. Otherwise the appropriate scan number is loaded from that file ( » 4).

    4  A reference file is loaded
    The characteristics of the reference are checked against the measurement. Note that all aliases are applied again with the contents of the file.
    Both scans are seen as identical ( » 5)
     or
    Only the linac is different and the treatment unit name is set to be ignored in the Processing menu ( » 5)
     or
    The files are not seen as matching and type checking is switched off in the Processing menu the user is willing to accept any outcome ( » 5)
     else
    No comparison is made.

    5  The reference is processed.
    Apply alignment of the reference if this option is switched on in reference menu. Note that there are different methods for evaluation of the position of the profile. As last resort even profile matching can be applied. ( » 5)

    6 Generate the calculated curve.
    The reference menu offers four choices:
     - a division of measurement and reference,
     - a gamma analysis,
     - the addition of measurement and reference,
     - none of the choices above.

    Tests
    To replicate the tests some preparations must be taken.
  • Copy selftest02_real.txt to Unix.txt. Change the "Radiation device" from "selftest" to "Unix" in this file. Open the file in BistroMath and save it as reference.

    The following situations were tested. The order cannot be changed freely as some tests continue from previous states.
  • Open a single scan file (selftest02_real.txt). A reference is taken.
  • Reload the file (Load curent data in the Fille menu, <Ctrl>+<L>). The in-memory reference is found, accepted and applied again.
  • Apply an alias (selftest=Unix). A reference from Unix is taken.
  • Activate Ignore name of Treatment Unit in the Processing menu and remove the alias selftest=Unix. Open selftest02_real.txt and set it as temporary reference. When opening Unix.txt, it will be compared with selftest.
  • Activate Index multi reference in the Reference menu. Open selftest31_BeamAdjust.mcc and set it as temporary reference. When opening selftest02_real.txt, it will be compared with the appropriate scan from the StarCheck data. Note that water phantom data are compared here with data from a 2D-array.
  • Open any unstructured multi-scan file and set it as temporary reference. When navigating through the file by using <PageUp>/<PageDown>, always the the same file is taken as reference. Note that the first applicable scan is taken ast actual reference. With repeated scans in the file the reference might therefor differ form the measurement.
  • When changing from one 2D-array file to another one with different characteristics (and not set as a temporary reference), the in-memory reference is discarded and a new one loaded. [Not replicable with standard selftest data.]

    See also:
     Challenges for profile evaluation
     Measurement menul
     Results panel
     Edge detection
     Symmetry and Area Ratio
     Field size interpretation





    Editor
    Raw data tab


    The editor is used as vehicle to store the copied text from the clipboard. The measurement data can be inspected in detail, changed and/or stored as text file. When the another tab is selected and changes have been made, these data will be processed as usual.
     


    Configuration
    configuration

    Introduction
    BistroMath offers a lot of possibilities which can become confusing for the user. Therefore the configuration is organised in three layers of ini-files which reside in the common application data directory  (C:\Documents and Settings\All Users\Application Data\BistroMath or C:\ProgramData\BistroMath). Storing configurations with free choice of name is locked and must be unlocked with <Ctrl>+<Alt>+<R>. See the Advanced Settings tab on how to make this menu item visible permanently.
    With wedged fields or likewise asymmetric fields should be verified that both direction and signs conform with the used water phantom software. Especially the GT/Inline/Inplane direction is inconsistent defined amongst different vendors and sometimes even different versions of one vendor.



    Advanced Mode
    To assure a uncomplicated standard mode almost all settings and menu's are locked and can be unlocked by checking Advanced Mode. However, loading presets can and will set all items regardless the state of Advanced Mode. The Advanced Mode state itself is not configurable. When advanced mode is preferred at startup this should be set in the Advanced Settings tab and stored in a configuration file.
    On returning to standard mode the last known configuration and preset will be restored from disk, ignoring the stored Advanced Mode preference.
    Note that storing a configuration file with any other name than bistromath.ini is also blocked in standard mode. Therefore you need Advanced Mode to write institute.ini.

    Simple Mode
    The Simple Mode option hides a lot of features which should be carefully considered during configuration. Verify that this mode is unchecked ("off").



    Configuration files
    Bistromath does not depend on the Windows registry, but saves it own data in configuration files of the .ini type. In version 4 a lot of names were changed. To keep backward compatibility a conversionlist is used to convert any old elements (BM700_renamed_elements.ini). This file can be removed if there are no ini-files written with previous versions.

    Institute.ini
    When found this file will be taken as only file for all settings. This is intended as reliable standard configuation for all users in one institute.


    BistroMath.ini
    When institute.ini is not found, bistromath.ini will be used. Also this file holds the full set of settings for the program. The difference is that this file has no protection and can be saved or loaded by any user.

    Presets

    Preset files contain a limited range of settings, mainly the menu options that can be checked/unchecked. There are a lot of meaningful combinations however that can be related to some "task". As tasks can change, another preset can be loaded. When a preset is loaded as command line parameter, the name is the file name without exclamation and extension (the file name compare!.ini would give "-preset compare"). 

    Configuration file overloading
    For all configuration and presets files only the parameters found in the file are subject to any changes. All other settings remain unchanged. This implies that after starting BistroMath with a standard setup like institute.ini, any stripped down configuration can be loaded on top of the basic setup.


    Ini-files

    The most essential configuration data for daily use such as reference depth and normalisation values ar found in the Configuration tab.
    The reference depth is used to normalise depth dose scans. Thus all displayed analysis values are based on this normalisation  ("AbsDepth/AbsValue"). The graphical display of the depth dose curve has its own normalisation ("RelDepth/RelValue"). When combined with a reference file the calculated division will be normalised at the same depth. Although the shape of the division will not change drastically the found minimum and maximum will be different. When using generic beams or reference dosimetry at a specific depth this might be the optimal setup.
    When the dosimetrical system is based on a depth beyond dose maximum, all depth dose curves should be evaluated relative to this reference point. The text "PDD" is then changed to "RDD".
    The Configuration tab is read-only when not in Advanced Mode.

    These values are joined with Dose Conversion parameters. Because there can be different film types this may lead to multiple dose depth definitions for one energy. Starting with version 2.00 all definitions for one energy are kept uniform.



    Reference directory
    The Reference directory is set at installation but can be changed.

    Configuration data without user interface
    See Configuration files.


    See also:
     Installation and configuration,
     Quik Start guide,
     Configuration files,
     Save as Reference,
     Presets menu,
     Institute defaults configuration,
     Command line options,
     2D-arrays,
     Interpretation of depth doses,
     Aliases.
     Configuration tab
     Axis swapping
     Scan angle definition




    In-Field area, Flatness, Symmetry, Area Ratio, Elevation and Linac symmetry Error
    general description 



    Definitions for In-field area, flatness and symmetry
    The Absolute flatness is defined as maximum-minimum, i.e. the vertical range, denoted by the two red lines below. This value is presented for a filtered measurement and limited to the In-Field area, indicated by the vertical blue lines below. The In-Field area concept is based on conventional profiles as "flattened area". The same range however is still useful for non-flat profiles and then should be seen as analysis area. When a division of two curves is evaluated, the relative flatness as calculated from the blue "calculated" curve.
    Note that the In-Field area is point based: when the size is established, the nearest data points will be set as borders of the In-Field area. The area will be set symmetrically around the chosen center position when possible: the central point must be within 1 cm of the average of the borders.
    For FFF profiles the the flatness is meaningless. When a such a profile is detected the flatness is annotated with (F) and expressed in percent per cm. When both absolute and relative flatness are given for a FFF-curve, the absolute flatness is followed by a "c" and must be read as "%/cm".
    These definitions are based on the Dutch NCS protocol and comply with most international protocols.


    Example

    The flatness is 2.0%, found as maximum and minimum within the In-Field area. The symmetry value is found as ratio of the points at the blue arrows, giving 100.9%.


    Elevation
    When all measurement points within the In-Field area are fed into a linear (first degree) model, the slope is a good measure for the symmetry as shown in the example above. The slope is recalculated to a normalised height difference over the In-Field area: 100·slope·(In-Field area width) / (normalisation value). In the example above this is represented by the red arrow.


    Symmetry
    The symmetry is defined as the largest ratio maximum[centre-x]-minimum[center+x] for a point and its mirrored position within the In-Field area as calculated on a filtered curve found at the red arrows below. The symmetry is prone to noise: although the theoretical minimum is 100% values below 100.4% are not observed.


    Area Ratio

    The area ratio is defined as 2·(right half In-Field area - left half In-Field area) / (total In-Field area). This alternative measure for the symmetry is insensitive to noise, has signed result value and gives a clinically more relevant figure. There is a caveat however with the definition given here when the field is asymmetrical with respect to the field center. A asymmetrical range will then produce large effects with a perfectly flat field. Also a asymmetric distribution of the data points can have significant effects for small fields. Therefore a resampled, symmetrical range (with the length of the In-Field area) is taken around the choosen field center. The center of field might be the origin, the middle of the field borders or the top of a FFF field. In the example above the actual calculation is 2*(B - A) / (A + B). Since the center is significantly different from the origin, the area ratio value is annotated with a 'b'.


    Linac symmetry error

    The internal ionization chamber of a linac compares the signal of two symmetric regions to evaluate the symmetry of the beam. For an Elekta machine segments of a ring shaped area with a inner radius of 7.3 cm (at isoc) and an outer diameter of about 15.3 cm, indicated with the green boxes below. By definition, the signal is averaged within each box ("L" and "R"). The Linac symmetry error is now calculated as 2*(L-R)/(L+R). For the calculation in BistroMath the evaluation is also limited by the field borders (the 50% positions or derivative based). Thus for smaller fields the Linac symmetry error possibly is not calculated at all. The boxes are corrected for actual SSD and measurement depth. It is displayed when the Linac symmetry error is selected in the Measurement menu. The inner and outer radius can be set in the Settings tab.


    Relative flatness

    When there is a reference available, a division of measurement and reference can be calculated. The relative flatness is found as maximum and minimum within the In-Field area for this line.


    Profile Evaluation Points (PEP)
    The upcoming NCS-33 report will introduce Profile Evaluation Points (PEP) as low resolution descriptor for any profile shape. The analysis results for these points, the Profile Evaluation Point Dose (DPEP).
    A Profile Evaluation Point can be defined as either:
  • An absolute position in cm relative to the origin. This is implemented with the 'X' key in the Results Panel Rules.
  • A percentage of the radius of the field, with negative values for the left side. This is implemented as 'r' or 'R'  for rounded relative positions.

    See also:
     Settings tab
     Measurement menul
     Results panel
     Edge detection
     Symmetry and Area Ratio
     Field size interpretation


    Concepts
    general description 

    Reliable results
    BistroMath is highly adaptable and configurable to users needs. This might also be a pitfall when multiple users are using the same software for a common basic task.
    This can be managed with several strategies:
  • saving all preferences in the predefined, "protected", institute.ini or any other user-defined configuration file when used with command-line parameters,
  • using presets to set for specific tasks, optionally loaded at start with command line parameters,
  • using command line parameters to overrule several critical features.
  • a configurable graphical representation to comply with the water phantom software. 
  • blocking most settings at startup in standard mode.


    Configurable output to screen and file
    All visible analysis results can be configured from this list In the special modes additional output can be written to a file and/or the clipboard.
    Also less used features can be hidden for the user.


    Multiple data input routes for multiple files
    A key concept of BistroMath is the observation of the Windows clipboard for plain text data. This clipboard interception can be switched off/on. Data less or equal to the configurable value MinClipBoardBytes or starting with "BistroMath" are ignored. When recognised as valid data they will be used. Also files can be dropped or opened in the classical way. Multiple files can be dropped or opened when the history list is activated.


    Multiple data formats
    A lot of data formats of all major water phantom suppliers, including some binary formats, are supported.


    Data correction
    Probably not much used, but data can be converted to dose with user defined parameters and/or corrected for background. These parameters are related to different file types. 


    Depth dose analysis
    The correct normalisation position is set according to the user settings. Note that fixed depths might be used here. Dependent on these settings "PDD" values might be presented as "RDD"values. Next (p|r)DD10 and (p|r)DD20 positions are calculated. On top of the objective depth dose at certain levels the graphical normalisation point is relevant when the measurement is compared with a reference. Especially for generic beams the depth of standard dosimetry should be taken for normalisation. Now dose differences in the measurement compared to the reference depth curve will be zero at the (grapical) reference depth in stead of dose maximum. The maximum is fitted with a quadratic fit to evaluate the position and height of the maximum. The same code is used for standard filtering with identical settings.


    Relative curves


    A key concept of BistoMath is the comparison of a measurement with its reference curve. Please read the overview. Reference curves are stored by the user and as default loaded automatically, based on machine name, modality, energy, wedge status, field size and depth. The machine name of the reference can be overruled at load time by using a alias. Temporary references can be used also.
    In the image above a measurement is divided with a symmetry corrected reference profile after profile alignment based on matching because of missing penumbras. Both aligment and symmetry correction are noted in the reference information text. For the same reason all results based on the field borders are red. The flatness of the measurement itself is 2.0% but when compared to the reference the range of differences, the relatve flatness, is limited to 1.2%.

    Profile alignment
    When a reference is loaded, the center of the reference is optionally moved towards the center of the measurement. This can be problematic when a field border is missing in measurement and/or reference. Then fallback strategies are used, based on the first derivative or matching as last resort.

    Symmetry correction
    Also, the reference profile might be slightly asymmetrical, which optionally can be corrected. The slope of a straight line, fitted on the data with the In-Field area is applied to the data, starting at the field center.

    Comparison
    The result of the comparison with a reference curve, the calculated curve, is user defined. The primary design target was to calculate the difference as measured/reference, normalised to 100% in the normalisation point. In that case the flatness of the calculated curve also can be evaluated: the relative flatness.
    Alternatively a gamma calculation can be applied.
    The reference may also be used to combine it with the reference to one summed curve. This can simulate the effect of abutted fields.

    Division of measurement and reference
    When the comparison is chosen to be the division of measurement and reference the calculation starts with the raw data of both measurement and reference. After quadratic filtering to temporary buffers the center of both profiles is calculated. Then the divison is calculated on points with the same relative position to the center in their data set. The result curve is passed through a median filter.

    Field types
    Profiles are classified as Standard, FFF, MRlinac, Wedge, Small or Electron. This concept is further explained on the Field types page. All related parameers can be found on the Field Types tab.


    Multiple-data files
    Files with several measurements in one single file come in two variants:
  • A series of profiles with no predefined ordening. These are mostly data sets from water phantom like the IBA RFA300 format (*.asc), OmniPro 6 binary (*.rbf), PTW (*.mcc). Any profile in such a set is treated as individual profile.
  • A fixed, organised data set, mostly from a specific detector like a 2D array. The data can be used as indivdual profiles, but the set as such can be stored as reference in the original format. This makes it possible to automatically extract the appropriate curve as reference. 
    For multiple-data files the <PageUP>/<PageDown> keys are used to browse through the file.


    Temporary references
    Any scan can be used as temporary reference, which can be handy to compare two variants of beam settings/machines/fields. Also a check on the scan type can be switched off. When a temporary reference is active, no other reference will be loaded automatically.


    Automation
    BistroMath provides SpecialModes for transferring results and automated processing.


    See also:
     Comparison with References
     Quik Start guide
     Center of Field and Normalisation of profiles
     normalisation of depth dose curves
     Results panel


    Contact / suggestions for improvement

    This program was designed for a single radiotherapy department. If it does not completely cover your needs you can contact me at bistromath@kegge13.nl.



    Theo van Soest


    Normalisation of depth dose curves
    general description

    The PDD is normalised on a reference depth if this is given. Otherwise the dose maximum is used. Separate normalisation points are used for the graphical representation and the analysis results. See Configuration and Depth dose interpretation for a detailed explanation with examples.

    See also:
     Depth dose interpretation,
     Configuration tab,
     Configuration.




    Graph area
    window elements

    Below the bottom axis the orientation of the curve with respect to linac coordinates is denoted with AB / TG / UD in the order as defined by the axis direction in the data.

    Zooming
    Zooming of the vertical scale can be done with the <Up> and <Down> keys. The keys <Z> and <U> set or unset zoomed state. Graphical zooming can be done with the mouse left button pressed selecting an area from top-left to bottom-right. The other way around for unzoom.

    Graphical elements
    Besides the obvious data curves there are helper lines (Top model, FFF slopes, penumbras, residual error dots), indicators (In-Field Area) and cursors. All of these elements can be toggled on/off in the View menu or simple keyboard shortcuts. See also curve selection below.

    Curve selection
    Data curves can be selected by clicking on corresponding label. Pressing the <spacebar> cycles through all available elements and brings these to the foreground.
    With the curly brackets '{' and ''}', data points on these lines can be made smaller and larger respectively. The round brackets, '(' and ')', do the same but are reserved for uniquely for the measured curve. See keyboard functions for more details.

    The "cursor" can be moved with the <left> and <right> keys, combined with several combinations of <Shift>, <Ctrl> and <Alt> for larger steps. The base step is the same configurable step size for profile shifting ("<", ">").
    Files can also be opened by drag-and-drop into the graph area. Multiple files can be dropped or opened when the history list is activated.

    See also:
     Keyboard functions,
     View menu,
     Measurement menu,
     Advanced settings,
     Results panel,
     Profile shifting.


    Bistromathics and the ship Bistromath
    curisoity



    "Bistromathics itself is simply a revolutionary new way of understanding the behavior of numbers. Just as Albert Einstein's general relativity theory observed that space was not an absolute but depended on the observer's movement in time, and that time was not an absolute, but dependent on the observer's movement in space, so it is now realised that numbers are not absolute, but depend on the observer's movement in restaurants."
     Douglas Adams; Life, the Universe and Everything, 1982 


    Further explanation of the theory behind bistromathics:

    "The first nonabsolute number is the number of people for whom the table is reserved. This will vary during the course of the first three telephone calls to the restaurant, and then bear no apparent relation to the number of people who actually turn up, or the number of people who subsequently join them after the show/match/party/gig, or to the number of people who leave when they see who else has shown up.

    The second nonabsolute number is the given time of arrival, which is now known to be one of those most bizarre mathematical concepts, a recipriversexcluson, a number whose existence can only be defined as being anything other than itself. In other words, the given time of arrival is the one moment of time at which it is impossible that any member of the party will arrive. Recipriversexclusons now play a vital part in many branches of mathematics, including statistics and accountancy, and also form the basic equations used to engineer the Somebody Else's Problem field.

    The third and most mysterious piece of nonabsoluteness of all lies in the relationship between the number of items on the bill, the cost of each item, the number of people at the table and what they are each prepared to pay for. (The number of people who have actually brought any money is only a sub-phenomenon in this field.)"

    The Bistromath was a ship used by Slartibartfast to save the world from the people of Krikkit. It used the Bistromathic Drive to get through the universe. The inside of the ship looks exactly the same as that of the inside of a italian restaurant and the ships trajectory can be modified by ordering different things on the menu.

    source: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technology_in_The_Hitchhiker%27s_Guide_to_the_Galaxy#Bistromathic_drive


    Results panel
    configuration

    Starting with version 3.20 all results in this panel are completely configurable. The explanation below assumes a standard setup.
    The v3.20 rule set has been carefully designed to reflect previous versions. All values are clickable: the result will be copied to the clipboard.

    The results of the analysis are shown below the graph and depend on the type of profile:

    Inline/crossline profiles

    The left and right positions values are presented for a filtered curve according to the chosen definition (50%, user set value, derivative edge detection or sigmoid model). The exception here is the sigmoid model; because of its statistical nature it is based on the unfiltered measurement. For this purpose the main axis is chosen as reference point if the main axis falls within the measuring range and the dose value is at least 95% of the maximum dose. Otherwise first the left and right position are based on the dose maximum and the new normalisation point is chosen as the average of these preliminary positions. This normalisation point can also be set.
    The flatness is calculated as defined by NCS-8 within the central 80% of the 50% width. Also the maximum value within this area is given. When a reference file is used to calculate a relative error and the calculated curve is set to visible, also the relative flatness is given. Alternatively, a Gamma analysis can be calculated. Then the Confidence Limit is given as m+1.5s of the gamma curve (where m and s are the estimated mean and standard deviation).


    When the origin is chosen as Center of Field and for FFF profiles the In-Field field CoF strategy is taken as default strategy, not the center will be reported but the position of the top. There are two different models available: the Top model and the Slopes model. Also, the penumbra values are replaced with the slope values (in %/cm) as found with the sigmoid model. Note that the slope is much more sensitive to the quality of the fit and the chosen fit range.

    The colors are meaningful:

    The color of the curve titles (i.e. equipment and date) corresponds with the curves in the graph.
    Green values and labels: the curve shifted. The measurement may be shifted towards the center by the user. As standard behavior the reference curve is aligned with the measurement. The needed shift for the reference profile is reported in the curve title.
    Blue values: non-standard results on corrected curves (i.e. symmetry correction on measurement curve).
    Red values: non-standard analysis results.

    Depth dose curves

    The PDD is normalised on a reference depth if this is given. Otherwise the dose maximum is used. See Configuration for a detailed explanation with examples.

    Annotations
    There are several annotations for the center position, profile width and field borders:
     (c): Based on the calculated center, the field is moved at the origin.
     (b): Standard 50% border detection is used to calculate the field borders; not displayed for center position.
     (e): Edge detection is used to calculate the field borders.
     (i): Inflection point with the sigmoid model is used to calculate the field borders.
     (s)  The 50% level is derived from the sigmoid model.
     (nn): The user dose level at nn% is used for the field borders.
     (T): The Top model is used to find the top of a FFF field.
     (S): The Slopes are used the top of a FFF field.
    For values dependent on the normalisation:
     (n): The normalisation is different from the standard (Normalisation on center).
     (*) A configured normalisation value and/or depth is applied for a depth dose curve.
    There are annotations for flatness and symmetry:
     (s): The measurement is corrected for symmetry (see also example below).
     (F) A FFF-profile is detected. The flatness is given the slope in percent per cm.
    General annotations:
     (z) The SDD of a profile is changed.
     (f) Fitted data are used for depth dose analysis.
     (r) Data are resampled.
     (~) The result is changed by a manual shift.
     (!) The result is based on a synthetic profile.
    Possibly multiple annotations are combined as is shown in the extreme example below.


    Curve information
    Curves can be labeled as "composite" when it is not a straightforward (filtered) measurement anymore. This is true for merged data, derivative, gamma calculation and the ratio of two curves. 
    For the Measurement and Reference curve a composite curve this shown as "Composite(curve information)".
    Filtering and symmetry correction are not denoted as composite results but have their ow explicit information added.

    Curve selection
    When the coloured name/date label is clicked, this will select the corresponding curve in the graph area will be selected.

    Configuration
    The parameters to show are fully configurable. The input typse are shown in the Evaluation types list.
    Here an example used during the development of BistorMath v4.


    See also:
     Results panel rules
     Why are my data values colored?
     Center of Field and Normalisation of profiles
     normalisation of depth dose curves
     Keyboard functions
     Configuration
     Settings
     Profile analysis strategy
     Adding reference files
     Flatness, symmetry, Area ratio and Linac symmetry error
     Interpretation of depth doses
     Results panel rules
     Sigmoid function


    Data axis conventions
    general information

    Using different file types and/or different tank setups might lead to a mixup of directions when comparing data and would lead to significant larger complexity of the code. Therefore, for all file types the data are stored internally always as G»T / A»B / U»D / L»R. As the interpretation of the data itself is not changed, this review should have no effect for any previously generated data file. However newly written data files represent the internal storage conventions as decribed above.
    This reduced complexity has a small disadvantage. As data are not always presented anymore in the direction as measured, this might lead to an inverted bottom axis when compared side-by-side with the measuring system and can be corrected with Axis swapping.
    Note that data are really inverted, when  Axis swapping is used and rewritten to some file. The original data can always be saved from the editor window. When data are stored as reference, always the editor data are used.


    Axis swapping
    view menu  | measurement menu

    For most users it is prefered that the graph view matches with the profiles as seen in the water phantom software. Notably the GT-axis is handled inconsitent by different vendors or even different versions of one vendor. Therefore here the GT (inline/inplane) axis is taken as example. The axis designations and/or the axis direction (sign) might be wrong. Therefore both can be altered independentty.
    BistroMath is carefully designed to preserve the original data on export. Therefore axis swapping normally will not effect the export at all.

    Preserve original data on export
    This option in the Measurement menu regulates the effects of axis swapping on export. Its default state is on. Switching off this option introduces serious data integrity problems because swapped data will be interpreted as original, unswapped data when opened again from file. This can undermine institution wide conventions for data interpretation. Therefore the state of this menu item is always on at startup and is not taken from any configuration file. Moreover the item is locked at program start.


    The direction of the data representation on the screen may be inverted when comparing side by side with the measuring system. BistroMath by default uses the standard directions from G / A / U / L to T / B / D / R for Inline, crossline, beam and diagonal scans respectively.


    The GT / AB / UD / LR designations can be swapped as viewing options and is reflected in the bottom axis title color. Note that this will not influence the graph itself nor the subsequent analysis.


    The axis sign (direction) can be inverted at read time as a measurement option and is reflected in the bottom axis labels color. This swaps all data from left to right and vice versa and has effect on all relevant analysis results but is not reflected by any color in the results panel. Colors in the results panel have other meanings.



    See also:
     Data axis conventions
     Viewing options
     Measurement options
     Results panel colors
     Installation and configuration issues
     



    Institute defaults configuration
    options menu 

    With multiple users working on possibly installations and/or user id's it can be hard to maintain a uniform standard of analysis behavior. Any user might save the standard configuration file, making it hard to establish the stable result over longer periods. Also, starting with Windows Vista, the users are not allowed to overwrite the files in the program files directory. The users versions of these files are masked by the operating system.

    There is a Save config as... item in the Options menu. This option is locked at program start and should be unlocked with <Ctr>+<Alt>+<R>. Through this route a configuration file can be stored with any name. The name defaults to institute.ini. See the Advanced Settings tab on how to make this menu item visible permanently.
  • On startup Bistromath will look for a file institute.ini in the same directory as the executable. Note that "Save config" and "Load config" use the file bistromath.ini.
  • Alternatively the shortcut to BistroMath can be changed to load any configuration file. For instance: "C:\Program Files (x86)\BistroMath\BistroMath.exe" -config path_to_any_file. Note the spaces between executable and flag "-config" and between the flag and its value. When not a fully qualified path is given it will be interpreted as relative to the path of the executable.
    Once a decent institute.ini is created this can be distributed.

    See also:
     Configuration,
     Command line parameters. 



    Getting started with FFF
    general information 

    As there are not yet generally accepted methods for analysing FFF users of Bistromath should careful explore all possibilities and set the right choices in the configuration file. 
  • FFF detection should be activated (Field Types tab).
  • The FFF detection parameters should be set (Settings tab).
  • Edge detection should be activated and whether or not the Sigmoid model should be used (Advanced settings tab).
  • Starting with version 4.25 explicit assignment from Standard field type to FFF field type and detection of FFF in file data in OmniPro v6/7/8, IBA RFA300 .asc, PTW and Sun Nuclear .snctxt and clipboard formats.
    Further decisions must be made on:
  • How the top should be modelled (Measurement menu).
  • What should be defined as the center of field (origin, top, edge based field center).
  • How the profiles should be normalised (top, origin, center of field)
  • Whether or not a reference should be corrected for symmetry (Reference menu).
    More detailed explanations can be found in the FFF-topic.
    If this topic is shown by BistroMath after a FFF profile is detected, then with closing this help file you acknowledge that you have explored these options and you have set a intitute wide configuration file.

    See also:
     Configuration,
     Measurement menu,
     FFF-profiles,
     FFF sytem.



    Command line parameters
    configuration
  • -SpecialMode{number}. See SpecialModes for details.
  • -config any_file. See Institute defaults configuration for details.
  • -references any_directory will use that directory for reference files.
  • -data any_directory will use that path as initial directory for data.
  • -preset any_preset_name. See Configuration for details.
  • -advanced start BistroMath in advanced mode.


    Histogram tab

    histrogram tab 



    A histogram is a statistical analysis tool in which all data values are sorted into discrete ranges which are called bins. When all data point are sorted the number of data points per bin is the resultant histogram. The horizontal range shows the values related to the bins. Any histogram procedure should find out the value range and set a reasonable number of bins, mainly based on  the number of data points.
    In BistroMath a histrogram is always based on the calculated curve data. This might be the ratio of measurement and reference or the gamma analysis result.

    In both cases a Confidence Limit, a concept of J. Welleweerd, can be calculated as the the absolute deviation + 1.5 * the standard deviation.
    The horizontal range (and bin ranges) can be set with <arrow-Up> / <arrow-Down> keys.

    The histogram might also represent absolute data.


    [Venselaar J, Welleweerd H, Mijnheer B.: Tolerances for the accuracy of photon beam dose calculations of treatment planning systems; Radiother Oncol. 2001 Aug;60(2):191-20]


    See also:
     Reference menu,
     Gamma analysis.


    Results panel rules
      configuration

    All results in the Results panel are completely configurable. This page explains the mechanism and how to set up your own rules.

    Default rule setup
    All panel rules must be introduced through a configuration or preset file. If no rules are given BistroMath will take its own default. 
    In version 3.20 it was designed to reflect the previous version as closely as possible.

    Startup logics
    At startup the Results panel is empty. No analysis results will be displayed in this state.
    However, also loading a configuration file is part of the startup. After this step all standard 'rules' (explained below) will be added if Standard Panel setup is activated or no external rules are loaded. Therefore, after setup the panel rules list might contain a mixture of own rules and standard rules. All rules in the list by design have unique identification numbers (id's). At startup, and also by pressing <End>, a mapping of each rule id per location is displayed.


    Panel rules list
    The Panel rules list drives the display of analysis results in the Results panel. Currently there are two colums of eight rows available.
    After analysis the complete list will be evualated. When a rule is found to be applicable (for instance scantype and modality) the configured result parameter will be displayed at the also configured panel position. Multiple rules can exist for the same position. Effectively the last applicable rule for each position will be visible.

    Ordering of the list
    New rules are always appended to the bottom of the list. When there exists another rule with the same id this rule will be removed.

    Rules list in Simple Mode
    In Simple Mode only a limited range of features is shown. This behavior can also be applied to the result panel. In the default setup this is not configured however. The condition "s" will introduce this for any rule. Make a copy of the rule and add ",cond:s" to any rule. When, for example, only the Normalisation is to be hidden in Simple Mode, only this changed rule needs to be in the configuration file:

     [PanelElements]
     ;when add-mode is off, at startup no default rules will be added.
     ;with add-mode on, default rules will be added except for rules with the same ID.
     add=1
     ;a short overview of all components
     doc=v#,id,curve,eval.type,gain,errorval,"label",deci,unit,col,row,mod,energy,scan[,cond:-][,annot:-][,color:-]
     ;normalisation value
     1=v597,1,-1,n,1,0,"Normalisation",2,,0,0,XEPO,0,A,annot:rcnS,cond:s
     ;normalisation position
     2=v597,2,-1,N,1,9e9,"Norm position",2,,0,1,XEPO,0,A,annot:rnS,cond:s

    Because a rule with a existing id is reïntroduced, this will override the existing rule.

    Setting up rules and avalailable evaluation types

    Getting the current setup
    A good starting point for making new rules is the standard available rule set. This can be acquired by saving either a configuration or a preset.
    Comments are added for convenience. This example might not be up-to-date.

     [Comments]
     file=panelsetup!.ini
     time=20-1-2018 11:59:13

     [PanelElements]
     ;the separator is set to the already assumed value
     sep=,
     ;when add-mode is 0, at startup no default rules will be added.
     ;with add-mode 1, default rules will be added except for rules with the same ID.
     ;with add-mode -1, all rules are cleared.
     add=0
     ;a short overview of all components
     doc=v#,id,curve,eval.type,gain,errorval,"label",deci,unit,col,row,mod,energy,scan[,cond:-][,annot:-][,color:-]
     ;normalisation value
     1=b597,1,-1,n,1,0,"Normalisation",2,,0,0,XEPO,0,A,annot:rcnS
     ;normalisation position
     2=b597,2,-1,N,1,9e9,"Norm position",2,,0,1,XEPO,0,A,annot:rnS
     ;maximum value
     3=b597,3,-1,m,1,-9e9,"Maximum",1,%,0,2,XEPO,0,A,annot:rnS
     ;absolute flatness for conventional profiles
     4=b597,4,-1,f,1,-1,"Abs. flatness",1,%,0,3,XEPO,0,H,annot:rzs,cond:-F,color:n
     ;absolute flatness for FFF profiles
     5=b597,5,-1,f,1,-1,"Abs. flatness",2,%/cm,0,3,XP,0,H,annot:rzs,cond:F,color:n
     ;relative flatness
     6=b597,6,2,d,1,-1,"Rel. flatness",1,%,0,4,XEPO,0,H,annot:rzs,cond:d
     ;symmetry
     7=b607,7,-1,s,1,0,"Symmetry",1,%,0,5,XEPO,0,H,annot:rzs,cond:-F
     8=b607,8,-1,l,1,0,"Symmetry",1,%,0,5,XEPO,0,H,annot:rzs,cond:F
     ;extended symmetry according to user's choices
     9=b597,9,-1,S,1,9e9,"-",1,%,0,6,XP,0,H,annot:rzs
     ;maximum within In-Field area
     10=b597,10,-1,+F,1,0,"Max In-Field area",1,%,0,7,XEPO,0,H,annot:rnS
     ;minimum within In-Field area
     11=b597,11,-1,-F,1,0,"Min In-Field area",1,%,0,8,XEPO,0,H,annot:rnS
     ;profile center (according to user's choices)
     12=b597,12,-1,c,1,9e9,"Center",2,,1,0,XEPO,0,H,annot:!rzcCS
     ;position of top of FFF profile (according to user's choices)
     13=b597,13,-1,T,1,9e9,"Top",2,,1,1,XEPO,0,H,annot:!rzcST,cond:F
     ;width of profile
     14=b597,14,-1,w,1,0,"Width",2,,1,2,XEPO,0,H,annot:!urzecS
     ;left edge of profile according to user's choices
     15=b597,15,-1,-b,1,9e9,"Left",2,,1,3,XEPO,0,H,annot:!urzecS
     ;right edge of profile according to user's choices
     16=b597,16,-1,+b,1,9e9,"Right",2,,1,4,XEPO,0,H,annot:!urzecS
     ;left penumbra width based on configured penumbra levels
     17=b597,17,-1,-p,1,0,"L",2,,1,5,XEPO,0,H,annot:!rz,cond:-W
     ;right penumbra width based on configured penumbra levels
     18=b597,18,-1,+p,1,0,"R",2,,1,6,XEPO,0,H,annot:!rz,cond:-W
     ;PDD maximum
     19=b597,19,-1,M,1,-9e9,"dmax",2,,1,0,XPE,0,V,annot:!rfS
     ;photon PDD10
     20=b597,20,-1,P10,100,-1,"-",2,,1,1,XP,0,V,annot:!rfRS*,color:n 
     ;photon PDD20
     21=b597,21,-1,P20,100,-1,"-",2,,1,2,XP,0,V,annot:!rfRS*,color:n
     ;photon PDD20/10
     22=b597,22,-1,P20/10,1,-1,"-",4,,1,3,XP,0,V,annot:!rfRS,color:n
     ;electron D80
     23=b597,23,-1,D80,1,-1,"-",2,,1,1,E,0,V,annot:!rfRS*,color:n
     ;electron D50
     24=b597,24,-1,D50,1,-1,"-",2,,1,2,E,0,V,annot:!rfRS*,color:n
     ;confidence limit for gamma analysis
     25=b597,25,2,G0,1,0,"Conf.Limit",1,,1,8,XEPO,0,H,annot:rzs,cond:rg
     26=b768,26,2,V0,1,0,"Pass Rate",0,%,1,7,XEPO,0,A,annot:rzs,cond:rg
    Some bonus examples
     25=b597,25,-1,x+21,1,0,"-",2,%,1,7,XEPO,0,H,annot:rzs
     26=b597,26,-1,X+21,1,0,"-",2,%,1,8,XEPO,0,H,annot:rzs
     31=b698,31,-1,-R60,1,9e9,"pep",2,,0,9,XEPO,0,H,annot:!rzecS,color:c,size:>35
     ;based on selftest02_real.txt
     ;'x' absolute position
     ;'X' relative to found center position
     

     27=b597,27,-1,y+50,1,0,"-",2, cm,1,7,XEPO,0,V,annot:rzs
     28=b597,28,-1,Y+50,1,0,"-",2, cm,1,8,XEPO,0,V,annot:rzs
     ;based on selftest03_pdd.txt
     ;'y' value with maximum scaled to 100
     ;'Y' value aplied to scaled curve as seen
     


    Rule to Panel mapping
    At startup, and also by pressing <End>, a mapping of each rule id per location is displayed.


    Rule list format
    Each rule consists of a series of values separated by a delimiter. The default delimiter is a comma (","). This may be changed at any time and will be used for all following rules.

    ;changing the delimiter
    sep=,

    ;adding to existing rules (1), start from scratch (0) or clear all existing rules (-1)
    add=1

    Therefore the general format is:

    unique_ident_string=item{delimiter}item[{delimiter}item]

    As ident for each rule is the id-number taken, but it can be any text except "sep", "add" and "doc".
    The current setup of a rule is given by the "doc" string.
    doc=v{build},id,curve sel,eval.type,multiplier,errorval,"label",deci,unit,col,row,mod,energy,scan type[,cond:-][,annot:-][,color:-]

    b{build}
    The build number is not checked at this moment, but might be used in future. A legal integer value must be given. The "b" is just for readability.

    id
    The identification number is a positive integer. When a rule with the same id is found in the list, that rule will be removed. A line having a negative id will remove all rules for that number. In this case the remaining part of the line may be omitted.

    curve selector
    The curve selector is an integer value. It decides which curve is used as source for the data. 
    With a value of -1 the appropriate default is taken.
    Other legal values are 0=dsMeasured, 1=dsMeasFiltered, 2=dsCalculated, 3=dsReference, 4=dsBuffer, 5=dsRefOrg, 6=dsUnrelated.

    evaluation type
    The currently supported evaluation data types are listed below. These are used in both Results panel rules and special modes. In the first route only a single parameter per position on the Results panel can be used. Special modes allow to combine these parameters. Each evaluation type is called with a case sensitive single character.

      EvaluationXtypes=['a','b','c','C','d','D','e','F','f','g','G','i','I','K','L','l','m','M','n','N','p','P','q','Q','r','R','s','S','t','T','u','U','v','V','w','X','x','Y','y','Z','z',EmptyXtype];

    Parameters with the exclamation symbol (!) have a left and right result. Therefore the left result is obtained as "-{evaluation type}" and the right results as "+{evaluation type}". When no sign is given the result will be the average of left and right value.
    Check latest implemention in code.

        a   Area ratio based on user's choices for center position
         wSource[Xsource].twSymAreaRatio
      ! b   Border position based on edges user choices
         wSource[Xsource].twLevelPos[twUsedEdgeLevel].Penumbra[side].Calc;
        c   Center position as defined by user's choices
         wSource[Xsource].twCenterPosCm as defined by choices
        C   Curvature (quadratic parameter) of fit of Top, always in [cm^-2]
         wSource[Xsource].twTopModel.Qquad
        d   Relative flatness 
         wSource[dsCalculated].twFlatness*100
      ! D [20|50|80|90] The result is the depth for a pdd or the edge of a profile
         wSource[Xsource].twLevelPos[dxx].Penumbra[side].Calc;
         xx=20,50,80,90
      ! e   Derivative edge
         wSource[Xsource].twLevelPos[dDerivative].Penumbra[side].Calc
        F   Relative Min | Max of In-Field area
         ifthen(Xsign<0,wSource[Xsource].twRelMinFlattened,wSource[Xsource].twRelMaxFlattened);
        f   Absolute flatness
         wSource[Xsource].twFlatness*100;
        G[0]  Gamma analysis within In-Field area [the '0' will take the range from the settings tab in the user interface]
         GammaAnalysis(dsMeasured,dsReference,dsCalculated,True,twGammaLimited,False,NormAdjustNumEdit.Value/100);
         wSource[Xsource].twConfidenceLimit[gGammaLimited]
        g[0]  Gamma analysis over complete profile [the '0' will take the range from the settings tab in the user interface]
         GammaAnalysis(dsMeasured,dsReference,dsCalculated,True,twGammaComplete,False,NormAdjustNumEdit.Value/100);
         wSource[Xsource].twConfidenceLimit[gGammaComplete]
      ! i   Sigmoid edge
         SetLengthUnits(Units_in_numerator)*
            ifthen(twLevelPos[dInflection].Penumbra[side].Valid,twLevelPos[dInflection].Penumbra[side].Calc,0);
      ! I   Sigmoid based 50% level
         SetLengthUnits(Units_in_numerator)*
            ifthen(twLevelPos[dSigmoid50].Penumbra[side].Valid,twLevelPos[dSigmoid50].Penumbra[side].Calc,0);
        K   relative heigth of Top position for Top model
        100*wSource[Xsource].twTopModel.Ytop/wSource[Xsource].twAbsNormVal
        L   Linac error 
         100*wSource[Xsource].twSymLinacError
        l   Elevation
         100*wSource[Xsource].twLinSlope*
             (GetPosition(Xsource,twFlatArr[twcRight])-GetPosition(Xsource,twFlatArr[twcLeft]))/twAbsNormVal
        M   Max position
         wSource[Xsource].twTopModel.Xtop
        m   Relative maximum
         100*wSource[Xsource].twTopModel.Ytop/max(1,wSource[Xsource].twAbsNormVal)
        N   Norm position
         wSource[Xsource].twAbsNormPosCm
        n   Norm value 
         wSource[Xsource].twAbsNormVal
      ! p  [|1|2]  Penumbra width according to standard definitions for conventional fields
         GetPenumbraWidth(XSource,side,ApplyDynamicWidth)
         1: ApplyDynamicWidth:= False
         2: ApplyDynamicWidth:= True
        (nothing) or other: value according to Field Types tab
      ! q   Slope of sigmoid model (always positive in this implementation)
         Y[side]:= wSource[Xsource].twSigmoidFitData[side].twNMReport.BestVertex[sigmoid_Slope]/Ynorm   
      ! Q   Sigmoid slope in the inflection point
         Y[side]:= wSource[Xsource].twSigmoidFitData[side].twFitResult2/Ynorm   
        P [10|20|20/10] Percentage depth dose
         wSource[Xsource].twPDD10,twPDD20,twPDD20/twPDD10       
      ! r [nn]  Profile value at fraction nn% of border relative to center of field, 
         The actual position (PEP) presented is at SSD.
         GetScaledQfValue((2*Ord(side)-1)*abs(nn/100)*edge+center,relative,scNormalised,Xsource)
      ! R [nn]  Profile value at fraction nn% of rounded border position 
         Border and center rounded to steps of 5 mm for field sizes <= 11 cm, 1 cm above.
         No rounding for field sizes smaller than 2 cm.
        s   Symmetry
         100*wSource[Xsource].twSymmetry
        S   Extended symmetry according to menu choices
        T   Top position according to users' choices 
         wSource[Xsource].twTopModel.Xtop or wSource[Xsource].twFFFslopesTop
        t   Top position for Top model.
         wSource[Xsource].twTopModel.Xtop
      ! u   Border at user value
          wSource[Xsource].twLevelPos[dUser].Penumbra[side].Calc
      ! U   Border at user value, using Sigmoid
          GetNormalisedRevLogistic(Side,Xsource,UserBorderDoseEdit_perc.Value)
        V[0]  Gamma Pass rate within In-Field area [the '0' will take the range from the settings tab in the user interface]
         GammaAnalysis(dsMeasured,dsReference,dsCalculated,True,twGammaLimited,False,NormAdjustNumEdit.Value/100);
         wSource[Xsource].twGammaPassRate[gGammaLimited]
        v[0]  Gamma Pass rate over complete profile [the '0' will take the range from the settings tab in the user interface]
         GammaAnalysis(dsMeasured,dsReference,dsCalculated,True,twGammaComplete,False,NormAdjustNumEdit.Value/100);
         wSource[Xsource].twGammaPassRate[gGammaComplete]
        w   Width according menu choices
          wSource[Xsource].twLevelPos[twUsedEdgeLevel]
        X|Z[[-|+]value] y value at X or Z*(1+depth/SSD)
           center based  GetScaledQfValue((2*Ord(side)-1)*abs(X),relative,scNormalised,Xsource)
        x|z[[-|+]value]  y value at x or z*(1+depth/SSD)*(SSD/Nominal_SSD)
           absolute   GetScaledQfValue((2*Ord(side)-1)*abs(X),absolute,scNormalised,Xsource)
        Y  [[-|+]value] x value at Y 
          if (ScanType in twcVertScans) and (ConvStg='100') and (Selection='Y') then
            Y[side]:= twPosCm[twMaxArr]
          else
           user scaling      Y[side]:= GetPenumbraValue(Xsource,X,side);
        y  [[-|+]value] x value at y 
           if (ScanType in twcVertScans) and (ConvStg='100') and (Selection='Y') then
            Y[side]:= twPosCm[twMaxArr]
          else
           standard scaling  Y[side]:= GetPenumbraValue(Xsource,X/twAbsNormVal,side);
                                    

    For some types adding a sign will explicitely taken the "left" or "right" for minus and plus respectively. The sign may be placed either before or after the type character.
    The most evaluation types are limited certain modalities or scan types. This is regulated by other parameters.
    Legal examples:
     m relative maximum value
     M position of maximum
     P10 pdd at 10 cm
     P20/10 pdd ratio
     -X10 value at 10 cm left from center position
     -x10 value at -10 cm
     x-10 value at -10 cm
     D50 depth at 50% of normation point for depth dose
      average of left and right border position at 50% for profile
     D+50 equals to +D50
     +D50 depth at 50% of normation point for depth dose
      right border position at 50% for profile
     -D50 left border position at 50% for profile


    multiplier
    The result can be multiplied with a non-zero value. The default is 1. Note that automatic conversion of lengths and distances to mm through the View menu option will only work if the multiplier is the default value of 1. A value of 0 will be interpreted as 1 but without length conversion.

    error value
    The when the result equals the error value it is replaced by a minus sign "-".

    "label"
    The label needs double quotes when there is a space in the text.

    decimals
    The number of decimals for the result.

    "unit string"
    Some text following the result. The unit string needs double quotes when there is a space in the text.

    column
    Position of label/result output. Legal values are 0 and 1.

    row
    Position of label/result output. Legal values are 0 to 12. The Result panel height is adjusted as needed.

    modality selector
    The rule is only activated for designated modalites.
    It is at least one character from the selection "XEPO".
    The P is preserved for protons. The Orthovolt radiation type was never found.

    energy selector
    When the value is set to 0 any energy is accepted.
    Any other value will be used to compare with the actual energy. Because comparing floating points may be 'risky' due to type conversions there always needs to be an uncertainty range. This is set to 0.01 MeV. Therefore the energy is converted to 'energy steps' as round(energy/uncertainty) to make the comparison fast and robust. Now it is also easy to introduce a simple range by allowing "<" or ">" as preceding character.
    Legal examples:
     0 any energy is acceptable
     {value} the energy must equal the value in MeV
     <{value} the energy must be smaller than the value in MeV
     >{value} the energy must be larger than the value in MeV

    scan type selector
    The scan type can be A (all), H (horizontal), V (vertical) or a series of ones and zero's (i.e. "100100")..
    The latter makes a select from the basic scan types: 
    (snGT,snAB,snPDD,snAngle,snGenericHorizontal,snFreescan,snGenericProfile,snFanLine,snHDFprofile,snPlane,snUndefined)
    The maximum meaningful length is the number of scan types. When the string is shorter, a zero is assumed for the following scan types.
    Special notes:
     Pyy The label will be filled automatically with "PDDyy" or "RDDyy"
     Dyy The label will be filled automatically with "Dyy"
     Xyy The label will be filled automatically with "Xyy"
     xyy The label will be filled automatically with "xyy"
     p The label will be filled with "Left" or "Right"
     S The label will be filled with the parameter name as decided by user's choices

    cond:
    Extra conditions to be fullfilled. The conditions are all flags set for the data source or the user interface. In capitals all Field Types are supported (Standard="N", Small="S", FFF="F", MRlinac="M", Wedge="W", Electron="E"). Field Types are mutually exclusive; only one Field Type can be assigned to a curve.
    Each character may be preceded by a minus as "not" statement. Multiple characters can be set in one condition string. Multiple condition statements for one rule are legal also. All stated conditions have to be met. Therefore conflicting conditions (for instance "MF") will block the rule.
    When a condition is not mentioned, it is handled as "don't care".
    Therefore for each character "X" there are three states: "", "X" and "-X".
    There is no prescribed ordering for conditions.
     N Standard Field Type
     F FFF Field Type (and therefore is also a profile)
     S Small Field Type (and therefore is also a profile)
     W Wedged Field Type (and therefore is also a profile)
     M MRlinac Field Type
     E Electron Field Type
     r FFF features detected (in MRlinac or FFF Field Type).
     f There is a valid reference loaded for the measurement.
     d The reference is used as divisor for the measurement.
     g The reference is used to calculate a Gamma curve.
     u There is no related action for the calculated curve.
     s This rule will not be active in Simple Mode.
    Legal examples:
     cond:V-Fd
     cond:Fs

    annot:
    BistroMath can show a lot of annotations with each label.
    When an annotation rule is matched it also sets the color.
    The annotation rules are executed in the order below, irrespective of the given order in the annotation string. The last triggered annotation will decide the color, possibly based on previous triggers.
    There is no risk in adding not applicable annotations (i.e. R for a profile); they will just not be triggered. It is legal to have multiple annotation statements in one rule.
     r The curve is resampled.
     ! The curve is synthetic made.
     F The curve has FFF properties.
     z The curve recalculated to another ssd.
     C The mathematical base of the center position. 
      Display values are
       b: conventional border (not displayed)
       e: derivative edge detection
       i: sigmoid inflection point detection
       s: sigmoid based 50% calculation
       o: origin
       m: maximum
       T: FFF top with Top model
       S: FFF top with slopes model
       u: undefined
     n The normalistion is not in the center of the field.
     e The result is based on edge detection.or the sigmoid model
      Display values are
       b: conventional border (not displayed)
       e: derivative edge detection
       i: sigmoid inflection
       s: sigmoid based 50% level
       snn: sigmoid based nn% level (needs also 'u')
       o: origin
       m: maximum
       T: FFF top with Top model
       S: FFF top with slopes model
       u: undefined
     f The curve is the result of a pdd-fit.
     * The PDD curve is normalised to configured settings.
     T Top modeling (S/T).
      Display values are
       S: based on Slopes model
       T: based on  Top model
     S The curve is shifted.
     c The curve is centered.
     s The curve is made symmetric.
     u The result is based on borders at users level.
       The percentage level will be displayed.
     R The PDD curve is not normalised to the maximum, it therefore is a RDD curve.
       The label is changed from PDD to RDD.
     X Position values in the Results Panel rules can be referenced to the nominal SSD distance, 
      using the 'z' rule or expressed as fraction of the field size ('r' rule). 
      When X is added, the actually used position will be shown.
    Legal example:
     annot:!rzcST

    color:
    The color rule is basically an annotation rule with only the color effects. Color rules are handled along with the annotation rules. There is only a limited number of fixed, predefined colors. Only the application of these colors is regulated here. There is also a hierarchy in the application of colors depending on the combination of annotations and/or color definitions.
    Legal example:
     color:n

    size:
    The size rule is way to set a limit on the field size. For Depth dose scans the set (given) field size in cm is used, when available with a default of 0. For profiles the measured field size in the scan direction, normalised to the default SSD, is taken. A lower limit and an upper limit can be set. A valid limit is any value preceded by "<" or ">".
    Legal examples:
     size:>0
     size:<20
     size:>0<30
     size:<30>0


    Relevant items in the configuration
    The lines below state that the standard rules are not loaded. Two rules are given as a comma separated list.
    [AnalyseForm]
    ViewStandardPanelsetup=0

    [PanelElements]
    sep=,
    doc=v(build),id,curve sel,eval.type,multiplier,errorval,"label",deci,unit,col,row,mod,energy,scan type[,cond:-][,annot:-][,color:-]
    0=v596,0,"optional: this will clear all existing rules"
    1=v596,1,-1,n,1,0,"Normalisation",1,%,0,0,XEPO,0,A,annot:rcn
    2=v596,2,-1,N,1,9e9,"Norm position",2,,0,1,XEPO,0,A,annot:rnS




    See also:
     Results panel
     View menu
     Evaluation Types


    Keyboard functions
    general information

    All menu items have keyboard shortcuts. Different modifiers are used for each menu

    <Ctrl>+<...> File menu


    <...> View menu


    <Shift+<...> Measurement menu


    <Alt+<...> Reference menu


    Keys without menu interface
    Points size
    "(" and ")" respectively decease and increase the display size of the measurement value points. Enlarging automatically activates the visibility of the points, a zero value unsets the visibility.


    Line width
    When a graphical element is selected, its line width can be changed with "{" and "}". Selection is reported in the message bar.


    Line selection in the data plot of the Analysis tab
    Use the spacebar to cycle through all selectable elements.


    Profile shifting
    With the key combinations <Shift>+<,> and <Shift>+<.>, actually being the keys "<" and ">" respectively, the profile is shifted to the left or right in configurable steps.


    For files with multiple scans
  • <numpad +>, <PageDown>, <F4>: next scan
  • <numpad ->, <PageUp>, <F3>: : previous scan
    When combined with <Alt>, BistroMath will loop through the whole file once automatically (autolooping).
    Note that paging will unfreeze the data.
    For multiple single-file scans in one file, paging up will jump to the start of the file since only the current location in the file is maintained.


    Paging through the history list
  • <Ctrl> + [ <numpad +> or <PageDown> or <F4> ]: next file
  • <Ctrl> + [ <numpad -> or  <PageUp> or <F3> ] : previous file
    The history list behaves cyclic for paging.


    Alias list
  • <Ctrl>+<Delete> exit


    During selftest mode
  • <Esc> exit
  • <F5> halt at a failed test (normal state)
  • <F6> step mode
  • <F7> fast mode with halt on failed test
  • <F8> fast continuous mode


    Related to graph area
  • <arrow-Up>/<arrow-Down> change the vertical range in zoomed state or right axis in unzoomed state. For a gamma plot or a histogram the Histogram range is changed.

    Zooming of the vertical scale can be done with the <Up> and <Down> keys. The keys <Z> and <U> set or unset zoomed state. Graphical zooming can be done with mouse left button pressed selecting an area from top-left to bottom-right. The other way around for unzoom.
    The "cursor" can be moved with the <arrow-Left> and <arrow-Right> keys, combined with several combinations of <Shift>, <Ctrl> and <Alt> for larger steps.

    See also
     Graph area


    Aliases tab

    aliases tab 



    With different versions of files it is possible that some string values may differ which should be the same to select the correct reference file. With this alias list this may be corrected.
    This feature may also be used to "rename" a linac and thus use reference curves from that linac. Starting with version 2.10 the alias list is not applied on the linac name itself but only on the file name of the reference file.
    New lines can be inserted with the <Insert> button. To remove lines use <Ctrl>+<Delete>. There is also a pop-up menu to support these actions. Don't forget to save the aliases if you want to use them permanently. Actually applied aliases for the current measurement are marked red and bold.
    When using aliases to cross-reference alternative normalisation methods might be preferred.

    See also:
     Configuration
     Center of Field and Normalisation of profiles


    Statusbar
    window elements



    The statusbar is used to display a lot of messages about files being opened, analysis results and menu commands. At the right side in a separate panel the number of data points (<number>p) for a single scan file or the scan number (#<number>) is given.


    Sigmoid analysis of penumbra
    general description 



    Introduction
    The penumbra region can with good approximation be modelled with a sigmoid function. The general description, also known as Richard's function, can be found in Wikipedia and MyAssays.Here a reduced four parameter version is used:

    where:
     A: the low level of the function
     B: the approximate inflection point
     C: the slope of the sigmoid
     D: the high level

    The real inflection point can be found as:

    The inflection point correction is very small as the slope has typically a value in the order of 100.
    The function does not perform well for x=0. Therfore the data are shifted if needed to guarantee that the whole range to fit does not include the origin. As the inflection point is closely related to the peak in the first derivative of the data this is an excellent initial value of B. Around this point a range of typically 2 cm is chosen. The first and last data point can used to low level (A), high level (D) and slope (C) as initial values for a fitting procedure. Such a procedure needs only a few loops to converge.
    The inverse function can be used to calculate the position of other levels around then inflection point:


    Finding the function parameters
    The function parameters can easily be accurately initialised. As the inflection point is closely related to the peak in the first derivative of the data this is an excellent initial value of B. Around this point a range of typically 2 cm is chosen. The first and last data point can used to estimate the low level (A), high level (D) and slope (C). Then a Nelder-Mead procedure is started with the overal difference between data and function as penalty to optimise all parameters with very few cycles.

    See also:
     Settings tab
     Results panel
     Edge detecttion
     Nelder-Mead optimisation



    Field Types
    general description 

    Introduction
    During analysis are marked with a Field type:
  • Standard all profiles not assigned to another type and all depth dose curves,
  • FFF  Standard (conventional) photon profiles with proven FFF characteristics or assigned as such in file data (OmniPro v6, v7/8 and PTW supported).
  • Small  profiles with a field width smaller than the given limit,
  • MRlinac profiles measured on known MRlinac treatment units,
