  • Wedge photon profiles with proven wedge characteristics,
  • Electron all curves set as "Electron".
    Field Types are mutually exclusive: there can be only one Field type assigned to a curve. However, FFF features are a shared property of both the MRlinac and the FFF Field Type. Therefore the FFF feature detection is available for profiles already designated as MRlinac and undesignated Standard profiles. When FFF features are detected this is stored in a "FFF shape detected" flag for that profile. A Standard profile will be set as FFF Field Type in this case.
    Bistromath makes no assumptions on the size and position of the profile in relation to the origin, nor the position of the normalisation point. This introduces the need for a dual loop analysis in which first provisional, on the maximum based, borders are evaluated to set a provisional center and or normalisation point. In the second loop all these values are finalised.

    Field type assigment rules
    With the exception of explicite wedge angle information are assigned to a non-standard type only when proven against the set rules.


    FFF
    There are three mechanisms to assign the FFF Field Type. All have their pros and cons:
  • Detection of profiles by shape,
  • Identifying labels in files,
  • Explicit manual assignment.
    This is further explained in the FFF overview topic.


    MRlinac
    There are no fail prove methods to distinguish a MRlinac profile in the data. Therefore a mapping is available to link treatment unit names to this field type which is applied in the early stages of the analysis. These profiles will be tested also for FFF features as described for FFF. When found the Field Type will stay MRlinac. Detection of the FFF Field type does not need to be activated for this test.
    For this file type FFF assignment is written into the output data for OmniPro v6, v7/8 and PTW.


    Small field
  • Small field detection must be activated.
  • The field width should be smaller than n cm, with a default value of 2.5 cm.
    This value can be set in the Edge detection box on the Field Types tab.

    Wedge field
    At least one of the criteria should be met:
  • The given wedge angle is non-zero.
  • f * Left 90%-position is larger than the field center or f * Right 90%-position is smaller than the field center.
    The factor f has a default value of 1 and can be set in the Edge detection box on the Field Types tab.
     

    See also:
     Field Types tab
     Advanced settings tab
     Measurment menu
     Edge detection
     FFF profiles


    Challenges for profile evaluation
    general description 

    Parameters for simplified, theoretical example


    A profile can be described by these parameters (or variations):
  • Field size
  • Position
  • Center
  • Flatness
  • Symmetry
  • Normalisation level


    Dependencies and complications


    Conceptually all available protocols assume symmetric borders, i.e. field center, origin and normalisation point being equal to zero.
    Therefore, half fields and partial fields outside the main axis, having become much more important. cannot be evaluated without further choices. 
    Also, this approach needs a CAX-procedure during measurment setup. Residual errors might still occur.
    When loosely defined, dependencies arise.
  • Choices have to be made on field center definition.
  • Choices have to be made on the normalisation point.
  • With the increased accuracy in radiotherapy, origin and field center can not be assumed to be identical.
  • Field size: derived from location of sides (edges?, normalisation?)
  • Position: distance of center tot reference position (origin?)
  • Center: average of position of sides (edges?)
  • Flatness: only within analysis area (edges?)
  • Symmetry: maximum ratio of symmetrical points around center (edges?)
  • Normalisation: value in center (edges?)
    BistroMath solves these dependencies with a double loop of the analysis process.
    For a lot of choices multiple options are available in BistroMath to comply with local preferences.


    What is "good"?

  • Absolute deviations from set values?
     and / or
  • Comparison with commissioning/TPS data (reference)?


    Comparison with reference

  • Works for any profile or depth dose
  • Works also for non-flat profiles


    Comparison with reference: complications

  • Profiles may not have the same center
  • Choices have to be made on the normalisation point
  • The reference itself might not be perfect
  • How to compare?


    Practice

  • Reference needs to be shifted
  • Reference (possibly and uninteded) asymmetric
  • In penumbral area no information on fluence: In-Field Area
  • Noise
  • Tiny differences
  • How to compare?


    Zoomed in

  • Reference aligned on center
  • Reference (possibly and unintended) asymmetric
  • Noise
  • Relative deviation much smaller than absolute flatness
  • How to compare?


    A solution: evaluate the ratio of both profiles

  • Measured data receive a filtered copy for analysis purposes
  • Reference data receive a filtered copy for analysis purposes
  • Reference aligned on center
  • Reference corrected for unintended asymmetry
  • The ratio reveals in great detail the relative flatness after median filtering
  • The ratio can be analysed within the IFA to evaluate the relative flatness.
  • The symmetry is derived from measured profile


    Alternatives: Profile Evaluation Points
    Without any reference a profile or depth dose curve can be described with a small series of relative dose values (DPEP) at selected Profile Evalation Points (PEP). This approach will be proposed in the upcoming NCS-33 report since these values can be handled with statistical process control methods.
    PEP's be defined as absolute positons in cm (PEPxx see 'x' in the Results Panel rules), to nominal SSD rescaled positions ('z') or as percentage of the field radius (PEPnn, see 'r').
    With a special annotation 'X' the actually used position can be displayed.


    Choices revisited
    In the process described above a lot af choices have to be made.
  • Data may be noisy. This may be problematic for penumbras and analysis of the IFA. BistroMath solves this by using a filtered copy of the data when appropriate and applying models to evaluate the penumbra.The filter wdth can be set.
  • Different types of fields may need different handling.
  • The borders definition: the 50% level might not work as expected and shows non-linear behavior with field size anyway (still unpublished work).
  • The CoF might be defined in several ways: the average of the borders, the origin, the 'near origin' (collapsing to origin when sufficiently small), or the maximum. As the reference shift is based on the CoF the will influence the outcome markedly.
  • The normalisation point might differ from the CoF.


    See also:
     Comparison with References
     Quik Start guide
     Center of Field and Normalisation of profiles
     normalisation of depth dose curves
     Results panel


    Conversion File Name Format

    File conversion tab 

    When selected, output file names will be generated according to a configurable format. There are three format strings: general, photons and electrons. An example is: "{X:SEEFddd}{E:SEEllddd}". 
    The following syntax is used.

     Syntax Value   Result
     { | }  none   grouping
     X: | E:  group label  photons | electrons  (optional)
     S  scantype  I   (Inplane, GT)
          C   (Crossplane, AB)
          D   (PDD)
          B   (Fanline)
          F   (Freescan)
          P   (Plane)
     EE  Energy [MV/MeV] 2 digits
     eee  Energy [kV/keV] 3 digits
     M  Modality  X | E | O
     DD  Profile depth [cm] 2 digits
     ddd  Profile depth [mm] 3 digits
     LL|XX|YY Field Size [cm]  2 digits
     ll|xx|yy  Field Size [mm]  3 digits
     I  Detector  (free text)
     F  Field type  W | O

    See also:
    Conversion of groups of files



    OD to Dose conversion

    measurement menu 


    OD to Dose conversion may be used for several types of files in the Dose conversion tab, but will be used only when the menu item is checked. The algoritm used is:

     dose= a + b*OD/f + c*(OD/f)^2 + d*(OD/f)^3 + e*(OD/f)^4

    See also:
     Measurement options
     Configuration tab
     Dose concersion and Background tab


    Profile analysis and finding field borders

    settings tab, advanced settings tab & measurement menu 

    Introduction
    In the classic radiotherapy the field border is defined as the full width half maximum (FWHM). Each part of this concept has its problems, even for standard flattened beams:
  • The maximum might be on a position far outside the field center (for instance wedged beams).
  • The field center might not coincide with the origin of the measurement system.
  • The assumption that the FWHM gives the best connection with adjacent fields may be wrong.
  • The field border clearly is not the FWHM for wegded beams and FFF profiles.
  • Methods may become problematic with sparse data points like 2D-array data sets.
  • Simple interpolation between two points is unreliable to find a border level.
  • There is also noise to deal with.

    Profile analysis
    The strategy of profile analysis in BistroMath has an elaborate design to get it as stable as possible. Flaws in the data which might lead to illegal mathematical operations are dealt with in the code by exception handlers. The data might be the raw data or a filtered version. When the data are a derivative or a division only relevant parameters are evaluated. The tasks related to analysis of a single profile can be divided into field border detection, center of field detectection, normalisation level calculation and final analysis results based on the In-Field area and penumbra region.
    If the user has chosen to move the center of the profile to the origin (see Move profile to origin), this is done first. The preliminary status of the 50% positions has a neglegible effect. Related curves (Calculated, Reference, Buffer) are moved over the same distance.
    A lot of options can be applied to the measurement data.

    Preliminary analysis
    In the first stage the data are scanned to find the maximum and minimum value. Further actions depend on a correct registration of the data (profile or depth dose curve).
    The maximum is used as a base for determination of 50% and 90% dose level positions. When these positions are highly asymmetrical it is concluded that the data describe a wedged profile. See wedged profiles below. The centre of the field is defined as the average of the 50% positions.

    Field border detection
    BistroMath detects the border at several levels: 20%, 50%, 80%, 90%, high, low, edge, sigmoid inflection, sigmoid model based level and user dose level. For each level and side the position is stored when succesful or noted as failure otherwise. The edge detection is based on the first derivative and statistical analysis and can be used as fallback when the 50% level detection fails or differs too much from the 50% position (user dose level may be used alternatively as "50%"). The high and low dose position are also user defined to comply with any protocol and used for the penumbra width calculation.
    Ultimately any border detection depends on the defined "100%" level an can be used with different reference levels. In first instance the reference level is chosen at maximum of the profile. The provisional borders are used to define the center of field which can be used to define the normalisation level. Dependent on user settings the final normalisation is used to calculate all borders again.
    To avoid misdetection all levels above 65% are searched inwards, all other positions outwards from the center of field. The final position is found by interpolation on a second order fit.
    The fixed levels 20%..90% do have a backdoor in the configuration file. 
    More details can be found in Edge detection.

    Center of field
    In standard software the center of field is limited to (the defined position of) the main axis. This works fine for standard symmetrical fields, but completely fails when the field does not cross the main axis as measured for jaw position calibration. Therefore a more general defintion is needed: the average of the two field borders at 50% or alternatively at a user defined level. See also the detailed discussion the Center of Field and Normalisation topic.

    Normalisation
    To reduce the sensitivity for noise in the normalisation level calculation some averaging is done. This range is configurable. See also the detailed discussion the Center of Field and Normalisation topic.

    Final analysis: flatness, symmetry and linac error
    The penumbra width is user-defined as the distance between the predefined levels high and low. The levels can be different for photon beams and electron beams. The definition is displayed as text with the penumbra values (for example: "L80-20").
    Flatness and symmetry are defined in the In-Field area and calculated on the filtered curve. The In-Field area is defined here according to NCS as 80% of the 50%-width for the major axis and 70% of the 50%-width on the diagonals for fields larger than 10x10 cm and 1 cm for smaller fields. This is more complicated for fields smaller than 3 cm and fields with a missing penumbra. If there is no penumbra detected and this situation is acceptable by the user, the field limits are taken at a higher level which is guaranteed to be available at both the left and right side of the profile.See flatness, symmetry Area Ratio, Elevation and Linac symmetry error.
    Wedged profiles
    For wedged profiles the field borders (normally defined as the 50% level positions) are presented as the position of the two peaks in the derivative. In this case the figures will be displayed in a deviant color. The derivative is displayed in the buffer curve. The peak values are calculated by interpolation with a second order fit.
    FFF profiles
    FFF-beams are detected and presented with alternative analysis results. The average of the (absolute) slope is presented in percent per cm. The symmetry is the normalised summed (positive and negative) slope multiplied by the width of the full analysis range ("In-Field area").

    See also:
     Measurement menu
     Edge detection 
     Settings tab
     Advanced settings tab
     Field types



    User dose level

    settings tab & measurement menu 



    The user dose level in the settings is used to calculate the width and penumbra positions of a profile. A value of 0 switches off this behavior. Any value in the range [0;100> is accepted. This value is only used however when the User Dose Level item in the Measurement menu is checked or the "u"-parameter is used in a Results panel rule.
    Note that user level can be combined with sigmoid analysis.

    See also:
     Measurement menu


    File menu
    file menu 



    Open...
    This item selects a file and tests whether the data are in some supported binary format or ascii format. A binary file is loaded into memory and written to the Editor; a text file is opened in the Editor. Thereafter the data is handled as any data put onto the clipboard.
    Also the multiple-curve formats rfb, PTW-mcc and RFA300 are supported. With the keyboard the appropriate curve may by selected. This number is stored when the preferences are saved.
    As alternative, a file may be dropped onto the graph area. Multiple files can be dropped or opened when the history list is activated.

    Open Temporary Reference...
    This item selects a file and stores it into memory as temporary reference. This is the equivalent of opening a file (as measurement) and Setting as Reference.  For unstructured multi reference files reference indexing needs to be activated.

    Load current data
    With this option the current data source (clipboard or file) is reread from the editor window with complete data-processing.


    Save Measurement as...

    When the editor tab is selected these data will be stored as plain text, otherwise the measurement curve can be stored to disk in the OmniPro_v6 format (most complete), PTW-mcc, wms-ascii, wms-binary and RFA-300 format.

    Save Selected Curve as...
    When the coloured name/date label is clicked, this will select the corresponding curve in the graph area will be selected.
    Then this curve can be stored as decribed above. 

    Ignore Clipboard
    As default the program hooks up to the chain of clipboard viewers in the windows system and checks all data that are placed on the clipboard. This behavior may be switched off. When switched off the program itself puts analysis information on the clipboard in Special mode 2.
    Loading a binary file, which is not supported through the clipboard, will lock the clipboard; loading a text-based file will restore the last know state for the clipboard. The user can change the clipboard state at any time.

    Accept multiple scans (open/drop/clipboard)
    There are four different routes which will effectively have the same result:
  • Opening a selection of files through the File menu.
  • Dropping a series of files,
  • Selecting a multiple-scan unstructurered, unorganised file as file.
  • Copying a multiple-scan unstructurered, unorganised data set to the clipboard.
    In all cases reading will be continued until no more data are available. Likewise, this is only meaningful if there is a history list and/or SpecialMode (#2 or #3) processing. With a history list the indivdual scans can be viewed. When the number of scans is larger then the history list, previous scans will be overwritten. If none of both conditions is met this option is disabled. However, the scans can be accessed manually.

    Save as Reference

    The current file, as found in the editor window, is saved as a reference under a specific name which is dependent on linac, energy, field size, wedge and type of scan. This generally covers all relevant parameters for a reference file as intended here.
    This feature is disabled by default and is reset at program start. To activate this item use <Ctrl>+<Alt>+<R>. Locking may be done again in the same way. See the Advanced Settings tab on how to make this menu item visible permanently.
    When a muitiple curve file is read and Device specific Reference is not active a single curve OmniPro_v6 text file will be written.
    The Reference directory is set at installation time but can be changed.

    Use History list
    When checked more data sets can be held in memory. See History topic and settings.

    The printing facility is kindly provided by Alan Chamberlain.
    Print Active page
    This will generate a pdf of the current tab. Note that the fonts directory must be installed.

    Print Selected tabs
    This will generate a pdf of all selected tabs. Note that the fonts directory must be installed.

    See also:
     Unlock/Lock critical options,


    Unlock/Lock critical options
    file menu, options menu

    By default saving of reference files or config files with non-default names as well as preservation of data on export is disabled and reset at program start. Locking and unlocking is done with <Ctrl>+<Alt>+<R>. When unlocked, also this menu item will be visible. See the Advanced Settings tab on how to make this menu item visible permanently.

    See also:
     Save as Reference),
     Measurement menu,
     Axis swappping,
     Options menu.

     




    Data input methods
    general description 

    There are three ways to pass data to BistroMath: 
  • the clipboard for all supported text formats,
  • drag-and-drop onto the graph area (both text-based and binary formats),
  • the File Open menu item.
    All these methods will produce a text file in the editor window. For large text files the transfer to the editor may take a considerable time. Therefore an intermediate memory structure (a stream) is used as source for the analysis. As a separate thread the stream is copied to the editor in the background which might finish much later.
    The fourth method is to open a file into the editor. Through this pathway BistroMath may become unresponsive for several minutes for very large files.
    The clipboard observer can be switched off. Also, clipboard data starting with "BistroMath" or equal or less than MinClipBoardBytes will be ignored.
    Multiple files can be dropped or opened when the history list is activated.


    See also:
     Supported file types
     Ignore clipboard
     Graph area
     Editor



    2D-arrays
    reference menu 

    The most 2D-arrays store the data as a multiple profile dataset. These files can be stored to disk with the measuring software. After this the files can be opened in BistroMath where they can be compared with reference files. The individual profiles can be stored for any direction as reference. Alternatively a complete dataset may be stored as reference or compared to an already available reference. This behavior is switched on with the Device specific Reference option in Reference menu. This option is only available for supported 2D-arrays and ignored otherwise. In that case the menu item will be disabled (grayed out). At this moment only the PTW StarCheck Maxi  and Sun Nuclear IC Profiler are implemented. The list of supported arrays is maintained in [WellhoferObject] section of the configuration file(s). The data format for the PTW 2D-array does not follow the conventions set out in the PTW documentation. For PTW there are limitations. The applications BeamAdjust and MultiCheck do write a different ordering for the profiles and cannot be mixed unless reference indexing is switched on. Other arrays can be added if there is any interest.
    The Sun Nuclear Profiler software export format can be written to either file or clipboard. In the latter case a full coupling with BistroMath is established.

    Example with an indexed multiple reference

    In this example a measurement generated by PTW MultiCheck is opened. This file starts with some data setes that do not qualify as scan. Therefore the first aceptable scan (5/20), being a crossline scan, is taken. As this is a registered 2D-array the standard multiple reference will be taken. Normally also the fifth scan in this reference would be opened as they are assumed to be well-structured. That scan is a point measurement and does not qualify as scan. BistroMath will cycle through the file to find the first legal scan. This happens to be the inline scan and no comparison will made. However, here the index takes over and loads the correct scan. The result of the comparison in this specific still is unusable as in the measurement the BQ-CHECK Test Object is placed on the StarCheck. It demonstrates clearly the flexibility of the indexing however. Indexing large files might take considerable time however. When multiple scans qualify, the first one will be taken.

    Configuration
    The support for multiple-scan references needs an entrance in the applicable configuration files (bistromath.ini and/or institute.ini). If missing, the Device specific Reference option will be disabled. Spaces must be removed from a name.

    [WellhoferObject]
    multiscan_list=STARCHECKMAXI,STARCHECKMAXI_MR,ICPROFILER


    Shared reference data
    To use multiple StarCheckMaxi devices in one institute, they need to have unique names. These names can be mapped to one single device name through the alias list.

    [Alias]
    STARCHECKMAXI_MR=STARCHECKMAXI





    See also:
       Institute defaults configuration


    Processing menu
    processing menu 



    Concepts
    In old versions of BistroMath the editor window was reread and processed when preferences or menu options were changed. This could also be enforced by the File menu option Load current data. For binary files with a single curve the data were converted to a text format and put in the editor for convenience and reload of the current data. For multiple curve binary formats like the rfb format this is not implemented. The Nelder-Mead PDD-fit introduced also the need for a reprocessing feature. This is covered in this menu. Also the Use as Temporary reference option is moved from the File menu to this menu.


    Autoscaling
    This fundamental feature of BistroMath should normally be switched on. It renormalises data to (mostly) 100 at some point, both on the screen and before doing any comparison. There may be situations where an absolute data set is compared with another one and no scaling is wanted. Note that with measurement renormalisation a data set can be made absolute. These renormalised data also can be set as Temporary Reference.
    Note: Autoscaling is locked in its on state by default. Unlock it with <Ctrl>+<Alt>+<R>. See the Advanced Settings tab on how to make the Unlock item visible permanently.

    Example with autoscaling switched off

    In this example:
  • Autoscaling is unlocked
  • Autoscaling is switched off
  • Measurement Norm adjust mode is switched on 
  • The Calculation result is set to Gamma analysis
  • A measured pdd is loaded
  • This pdd is normalised to give the expected dose at the reference point
  • The normalised measurement is set as Temporary Reference
  • The calculated pdd is loaded as measurement

    Assign FFF property
    Files of the Standard field type can be set to FFF or reverse. The initial state (checked or unchecked) is set when reading a file. This state is derived from two sources: identification in the file data and FFF detection for profiles.  For depth dose files no detection strategy is available.
    This is an Advanced Mode feature.


    Apply sigmoid model on Buffer
    Normally the buffer contains the derivative of a profile to show the results of the edge detection algorithm. The next level of edge detection is the inflection point of a sigmoid fit. To show the performance of this strategy, all the used data points are replace with the sigmoid fit. Typically this will be visible in the shoulder area where the fit starts to deviate from the data. The penumbra itself should closely follow the data. Note that the inflection point still might become less reliable when applied on conventional profiles where the penumbra becomes an almost straight line.

    Reprocess current data
    This will restart all processing on the raw data as read from file or editor window. The PDD-fit will be started with the current parameters for the best fit.

    Reset Nelder-Mead fit
    A restart as above. The PDD-fit will be started with the initial default parameters.

    Merge Source with measurement
    This activates merging of two scans. See the item Merging of scans.

    Set Measurement as Merge source ("stitching")
    This option sets the first part of the profile/depth dose to combined with (merged with, stichted to) a following scan.

    Clear Merge source
    This option frees the Unrelated curve which is used to store the merge source and thus making it available again for other tasks.

    Mirrored measurement as Reference

    When checked, the current profile is copied to the background reference storage. Then this copied profile is mirrored around the Center of Field. Now the Temporary reference item is activated and the new reference loaded as any other temporary reference. The state of this item will not change until switched off again and will therefore work on any next profile. Taking any other temporary reference or clearing the temporary reference will also unset this option. See the separate item for details.

    Make synthetic profile
    This option activates the creation of a virtual profile from a small(er) FFF-field and and a large FFF-field. 

    Set as Temporary reference <Ctrl>+<T>
    When a measurement is loaded this may be used as temporary comparison to all profiles/depth doses as long as this item is checked. The file is saved in memory. This option is not saved in the configuration file and defaults to "unchecked". See more details in the separate topic.
    Clear Temporary reference <Ctrl>+<Shift>+<T>
    The temporary reference buffer is cleared.

    Ignore name of Treatment Unit <Ctrl>+<U>
    For a quick comparison of two linacs the name of the linac should be ignored in the check of the scan type. By ignoring the linac name it is impossible to select automatically the correct reference. Therefore this works only for temporary references. A more general approach offers the Aliases tab. By making one name equal to another cross-referencing is automated.

    Check Temporary Scan type
    When this item is checked the temporary reference is only used when its scan type equals the scan type of the measurement. If unchecked the reference can be compared with any scan.

    SpecialModes
    The SpecialMode entries are only visible in advanced mode. Each state can be (de)activated here. These states are stored in any configuration file when saved. Can also be started from the command line. Note that extra information should be configured in the actually used configuration file.


    See also:
     Unlock/Lock critical options,
     Merging of scans,
     Nelder-Mead fit,
     Edge detection. 


    Set as Temporary reference
    processing menu
     
    When a measurement is loaded this may be used as temporary comparison to all next profiles as long as this item is checked. The scan is saved in memory. With this option the current data source (clipboard or file) is reread. All reference functionality is applied to this file. This option is not saved in the configuration file and defaults to "unchecked".

    The temporary reference can be unset with the Clear Temporary Reference item (<Ctrl>+<Shift>+<T>).

    Note that the temporary reference supersedes any automatically detected reference. The temporary reference is passed to the next element in the history list when you cycle through the history. Whether or not a reference is 'acceptable' depends on the circumstances. The actual mechanism works through generating curve names which is influenced by an ignore list. In the current version of BistroMath there is no option to acces this list. In the Messages tab more details can be found when a reference is not applied. Increasing the log level can give even more details.
    In principle only a reference which matches all parameters, including field size, scan depth, of the measurement will be applied. This can be relieved by:
  • Ignoring the name of the Treatment Unit.
  • Not checking the Temporary Scan type at all. In this case anything goes, even comparing a profile with a depth dose.
  • Also an alias can be set, notably for the Treatment Unit.

    A temporary reference can be:
  • Any single scan.
  • A structured multi-scan file for a 2D-array that is configured in BistroMath and Device specific Reference is activated.
  • Any unorganised bunch of scans when Index multi reference is activated. In this case the first applicable scan from the generated index is taken. Building an index may take some time. 



    See also:
     Processing menu,
     Merging of scans,
     Reference menu,
     History list.


    Merging of scans ('stitching')
    processing menu 

    Partial scans
    The circular water phantom of Sun Nuclear uses already this concept to create a larger scan area with one single detector. This guarantees accuracy of measurement positions and normalisation.
    For the Elekta MR-Linac a water phantom with a dual scanning head is developed to provide a reasonable scan width. With a horizontal beam also two partial depth dose curves can be created. Due to the nature of a dual scanning head the distance between the two detectors might not be fully accurate. Also the normalisation can be different. 
    The current implementation is based on the typical FFF-shape of the beam. Therefore a profile can be matched on the central part of the beam. A reasonable overlap is needed. A depth dose curve needs predefined information on the relative distance or consistent positional information in both scans. The merge procedure in principle offers both approaches. In future releases correct alignment might be set on base of the given field size.

    When the field to be measured is larger than the water phantom, it can be measured as two partial scans. In the MR-linac, due to the bore, the scan width is a trade-off with the wanted water depth. Therefore a dual scanning head was designed. 

    A general example is given above where one single profile was split into two separate partial scans with some overlap. One of the two partial scans was also shifted and rescaled to 120%. To show both scans in one image, the right scan was loaded as temporary reference, while Align with Measurement in the Reference menu was switched off. Then the left scan was loaded as measurement. The difference in scaling is lost in this representation due to rescaling of BistroMath.

    Now the Measurement (left scan) is copied to a background memory with the Set measurement as Merge Source option in the Processing menu. As a result this option will be shown as "Checked". Any next partial scan can be merged with the source using the Merge Source with measurement option. Note that both scans should have the same characteristics (treatment unit, energy, field size, depth). Failures are reported in the Messages tab.


    Profiles
    When the next loaded curve has identical parameters (amongst others scan type, scan depth, field size, energy and linac), the first measurement is merged with the second. When the merge procedure is completed succesfully the Merge option in the Processing menu is unchecked. In the overlap area the first curve is (optionally) resampled to the second curve. All other points are simple added to the second curve. With the data as presented above, this needs both shifting and rescaling. The shift can be any combination of a manual shift and a matching procedure. To get this working BistroMath needs to handle partial scans with just one penumbra correctly.

    Try it yourself
  • Open selftest33_FFF_p1.mcc.
  • Set as Merge Source in the processing menu (<Ctrl>+<Alt>+<Q>). 
  • Open selftest33_FFF_p2.mcc.
  • Shift it any distance you like with <Shift>+<,> or <Shift>+<.>.
  • Activate Merge (<Ctrl>+<Q>).



    Depth doses
    This proces works also for depth dose curves but the two parts are never matched. The correct shift has to be provided in that case. This might be used to combine the first part from a standard vertical depth dose and the lower part sideways at a 90° degree gantry angle with a different SSD. Here the Mayneord transform is applied automatically. This rather strange method is needed in the MR-linac where the available vertical scan range is limited.
    When the SSD's differ the lower part of the curve is added to the upper part. Therefore the header data of the upper part are conserved.


    Merge: Profile Shift (cm)
    Prior to the actual merging of two profiles, the profile to be merged can be shifted.

    Merge: PDD Shift (cm)
    Prior to the actual merging of two depth does, the lower part can be shifted.

    Merge: Use matching (cm)
    Prior to the actual merging of two profiles, the profile to be merged can be shifted by a matching procedure. The shape of the profile should be sufficient non-flat to work reliably. On the start of the match process the best result from either no shifting or preset shift is the goal to be improved.

    Merge: Scale overlap area.
    Possible differences in normalisation at measurement time can be corrected. The ratio all summed values in the overlap area (after shifting and/or matching) is used to rescale the scan to be merged.

    The final result is shown below for both a profile and a depth dose. Note the new description of the measurement curve which indicates both the composite nature and the applied shift of the data.




    Implementation
    The profiles to be matched can be set in the processing menu.

    Limitations
    The matching of partial profiles is not trivial. The shape needs to be sufficient non-flat to be succesful.

    See also:
     Processing menu,
     Profile matching. 


    Mirroring a measurement to Reference
    processing menu 

    Logics
    When checked, the current profile is copied to the background reference storage. Then this copied profile is mirrored around the Center of Field. Now the Temporary reference item is activated and the new reference loaded as any other temporary reference. The state of this item will not change until switched off again and will therefore work on any next profile. Taking any other temporary reference or clearing the temporary reference will also unset this option.

    Implementation
  • First the measurement is copied to the reference.
  • Any applied shift to the data is undone.
  • The double value of any given rotation point is added to the original shift value.
  • Then all position values are inverted, effectively mirroring around the origin.
  • The combined shift as defined above is applied, effectively mirroring around the given rotation point.
  • The data are re-ordered to a increasing position value.
  • The displayed name of the reference is changed to "composite(original name and date)"

    Postprocessing
    The new reference is handled as any reference according to the choices made in the Reference menu. The alignment to the measurement needs special attention here.
    If the reference is not to be aligned nothing is done to the position of the reference. Otherwise the chosen Center of Field definition for the measurement becomes important. The differerence in CoF between measurement en reference is applied to the reference.
  • Origin as CoF (all profile types): the reference will not be shifted.
  • Field edge as CoF (all profile types): basically the 50% points are used to determine the CoF. If a fallback strategy is set in the Advanced settings Tab this may be replaced by some "highest gradient" method.
  • Peak as CoF (FFF profiles only): the top position as derived from the Top model or the Slopes model is used.
  • The maximum is used as CoF (all profiles): this may have an unpredictable effect for most "real live" data.

    Review for FFF fields
    When either the Origin or Field edges are used as CoF a solid comparison is possible. Because a deviation from the Top position from the origin (if coincident with the collimator rotation point) is strongly related to asymmetry this choice amplifies the difference in symmetry between both profiles.


    Synthetic (virtual) profiles
    processing menu 

    IPEM topical report 1: guidance on implementing flattening filter free (FFF) radiotherapy
    In 2016 a comprehensive British report with guidances for FFF beams was published [G. Budgell et al: IPEM topical report 1: guidance on implementing flattening filter free (FFF) radiotherapy; Phys. Med. Biol. 61 (2016) 8360-8394]. One of the methods they propose, escpecially for field size evaluation is the the division of a small(er) field with a large field profile. The resultant profile assembles closely a conventional profile. In the report this is called a virtual profile.
    An alternative method is Edge detection with a sigmoid model.



    Implementation
    Although this is just the already available division of two data sets, measurement and reference, there are some differences.
  • The calculated output is in terms of Bistromath a real profile, not a relative curve.
  • All standard analysis results are derived from the calculated, synthetic profile. Therefore nearly all measurment results get an exclamation sign as annotation.
  • Where, for an standard comparison all parameters should be equal, now the field size and diagonal detection are ignored.
  • The field size of the divisior (reference) should be larger then the divident (measurement).
  • The calculation area is limited on each side to the minimum of the edge of the divident profile + 2 cm and the edge of the divisor profile - 2 cm.
  • Symmetry correction of the divisor (reference) is disabled, except when it is also applied to the measurement.
  • Automatic load of references is disabled, because it contradicts with using multiple data files.
  • The image is unzoomed.
  • This feature is a processing menu function that can be activated at any time.
  • The graphical analysis is done such that the shoulder match with the profile of the large field.

    Limitations
    There are no known special limitations other than already in place for curve comparison.

    Testing it yourself
  • Load selftest32_x7c40.txt.
  • Set this profile as Temporary reference (<Ctrl+T>).
  • Load selftest32_x7c15.txt.
  • Activate Synthetic profile in the Processing menu (<Ctrl+F>).

    See also:
     Processing menu,
     Profile matching. 


    Mayneord transformation
    processing menu 

    Theory
    For both photon and elctron fields the fluence at the surface is ruled (with good approximation) by the inverse square law. Below the water surface the behavior splits in two branches. 
  • All particles in a particle beam like electrons will loose energy over the whole path travelled from the surface into the water. This loss of energy is roughly constant and proportional with the elctron density of the material. Therefore the shape of a electron depth dose curve is almost independent of the source to surface distance (SSD).
  • Photons is ruled by the probability of the first interaction with the material and is by first approximation ruled by an exponential decay function. But the number of photons with the first interaction at some depth is therefore also dependent on the inverse square law. Thus the shape of a photon depth dose curve is dependent on the SSD. After the first interaction released energy is redistributed by electrons. Because the electron paths are dominated by forward scattering, dose will be transferred somewhat further along the beam direction. Near the surface some electrons will escape, lowering the deposited dose significantly. 

    Schematic plot of kerma and absorbed dose¹.
    [

    Mayneord function
    The Mayneord function handles the transformation of a photon depth dose curve from one SSD to another SSD. Almost all references to this function point to the (rather famous in radiotherapy physics) book of Khan². Online versions of that book can be found¹. A quick overview of all formulas can be found at wikibooks.org³.
    The depth dose curve (PDD) describes the dose as a function of depth (d) and is dependent on the type of material, photon energy (spectrum), field size and SSD. The relation between two PDD values at the same depth d in water at different SSD's can be described by

     PDD(SSD2,d) = PDD(SSD1,d)  f

    where f is the Mayneord factor.

    Mayneord factor taken from wikibooks³.
    As mentioned before, the full derivation of this result can be found in Khan².


    Limitations
    The field size is rather problematic in the Mayneord factor. In general the best results are got when the field size at the surface is kept constant. But still the divergence of the beam will be different, leading to differences in scatter contributions. In general the Mayneord factor overestimates the PDD at a larger SSD. As scatter becomes more important at larger depths and lower energies, the Mayneord function may produce significant errors.

    Implementation
    The transformation needs three parameters, SSD1, SSD2, and Dmax, which can all be derived from the measurment and general defaults. All can be set explicitely in the Settings tab.


    [1]  https://medicalphys.files.wordpress.com/2010/12/faiz-khans-02.pdf .
    [2] Faiz M. Khan: The Physics of Radiation Therapy (5th edition); Wolters Kluwer (2014, ISBN 9781451182453)
    [3]  https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Radiation_Oncology/Physics/Equation


    See also:
     Processing menu,
     Profile matching. 


    Depth dose interpretation
    general description


    The most essential configuration for daily use is the reference depth and value for photon beams. The user interface to these lines is the Configuration Tab.
    The reference depth is used to normalise depth dose scans. Thus all displayed analysis values are based on this normalisation  ("AbsDepth/AbsValue"). The graphical display of the depth dose curve has its own normalisation ("RelDepth/RelValue"). When combined with a reference file calculated division will be normalised at the same depth. Although the shape of the division will not change drastically the found minimum and maximum will be different. When using generic beams or reference dosimetry at a specific depth this might be the optimal setup.
    When the dosimetrical system is based on a depth beyond dose maximum, all depth dose curves should be evaluated relative to this reference point. The text "PDD" is then changed to "RDD".

    There are several possibilities to use this:

    No entries
    The program will normalise the depth dose curve to 100% at the depth of the found dose maximum.


    Normalise to maximum
      DRel VRel DAbs VAbs
    X06  0.0 100 0.0 100
    X10 0.0 100 0.0 100
    X18 0.0 100 0.0 100
    This is effectively the same as making no entries. See above.

    Dose maximum definitions
     DRel VRel DAbs VAbs
    X06  1.6 100 1.6 100
    X10 2.0 100 2.0 100
    X18 3.0 100 3.0 100
    This is the setup for intended use in previous versions. The institute works with fixed depths for dose maximum. All curves are normalised to this depth and therefore (slightly) higher values may be found around this depth.


    Fixed reference dose at a given depth
      DRel VRel DAbs VAbs
    X06  10.0 67.2 10.0 67.2
    X10 10.0 72.8 10.0 72.8
    X18 10.0 78.8 10.0 78.8
    With this setup curves are normalised to the dosimetry point in the planning system. 


    Mixed setup
      DRel VRel DAbs VAbs
    X06  1.6 100 0.0 100


      DRel VRel DAbs VAbs
    X06  1.6 100 10.0 100


    Extended entries
    Starting with version 4.25 there may be multiple definitions for one modality, representing different types of linacs with the same nominal energy. To make extra entries unique, a limiting list of Field Types and or linac names must be added. When lines with limitations are used, these are preferred. When more than one 'limited' line is applicable, the last one will be used. The ordering in the configuration file is leading. When both Field Type and linac name are specified, both criteria must be met and that line is preferred. As left-over option the 'unlimited' variant will be taken. Linac name matching is executed is case-insensitive search for the linac name in the limitation specifier. Both through the user interface as the configuration file, the field type names are case-insensitive converted to their index values in the software.
      DRel VRel DAbs VAbs Fields Linacs
    X06  10.0 100 10.0 100 
    X06  0.0 100 0.0 100 MRlinac   
    X06  1.6 100 1.6 100   selftest
    X06  1.8 100 1.8 100 FFF  U04



    See also:
     Save as Reference,
     Institute defaults configuration,


    History list
    general description


    When activated in the File menu or the Advanced Settings tab, BistroMath will keep then multiple data sets in memory. These data sets, multiscan files included, are complete data engines with all related parameters. When opening a new file always the actual settings from the user interface are taken. 

    The History list is a linear list but behaves circular, <Ctrl> + [ <numpad -> or  <PageUp> or <F3> ] will move to the previous data; <Ctrl> + [ <numpad +> or <PageDown> or <F4> ] will move to a later (or the oldest) data. When a data set from the history is presented (i.e. not the last loaded) then in the window title the 'historic position' and actual list size are shown as --i/n--. When frozen (see below) a asterisk is added. When data have to be pushed out because new data sets are added, the earliest opened will be replaced.
    This cycling feature is designed to be completely equivalent to using a single data set: also all buffers and the editor are restored to guarantee all functionality. When a temporary reference is set this will be transferred to the next data set upon cycling. This also works for multi-scan data sets. Whether or not such passed refference data will be used depends on the receiving data set and the settings in the Processing menu.

    Use history list
    When checked BistroMath will maintain a list of data sets. The first data set in the list will be displayed. All data will be set to (un)frozen when the state is changed to (un)checked. See below for explanation.

    Length
    This sets the length of the history list whether it is used or not. A value of 1 will uncheck Use history list and disable No recalculations on history data. When the displayed data set is removed from the history list by reducing the list lenght, another data set in the list will be displayed.

    Temporary reference
    When a temporary reference is apllied this will be transferred to other data sets on paging through the histrory list.

    Put history data in frozen state
    When checked the data sets are not compressed but stay in a "frozen" state. No synchronisation is done between user interface and a frozen data set. Note that loading new data will always unfreeze the current data set. Using <PageUp> or <PageDown> without <Ctrl> to step through multiscan data will also unfreeze that data set. With unfrozen data the reference is loaded again and all necessary calculations must be done again. Also a manual applied shift is lost.
    In all cases, when data are unfrozen, the current settings from the user interface will be taken and differences with the state before might occur.
    There are both advantages and disadvantages to using the frozen state:
  • Freezing takes much more memory.
  • Frozen data are loaded much faster as no recalculations will be done.
  • Frozen data might not reflect the current settings in the user interface which might also be exploited by loading the same data with different settings.
  • A temporary reference is not passed to a frozen data set.



    See also:
     Keyboard functions,
     Advanced Settings tab.


    Files tab
    files tab


    The Files tab offers a scan of any directory for registered file types, based on the known file extensions, presenting the most essential data of any file. When a multi-scan file is selected, its contents will be presented as a virtual directory.

    Opening a file or scan
    A file or scan in a multi-scan file can be opened by double-clicking or right-clicking and then selecting "Open".

    Deleting a file
    A file can be deleted with right-clicking and then selecting "Delete". Deleting a scan from a multi-scan file is not supported.

    Changing the reference directory
    In the example above first with the radio button "References" the reference directory C:\Documents and Settings\All Users\Application Data\BistroMath\References was selected.and then the directory C:\Documents and Settings\All Users\Application Data\BistroMath was chosen in the directory box. This has enabled the buttun "-> set path". Clicking this button will set the reference directory to the chosen path C:\Documents and Settings\All Users\Application Data\BistroMath which is also displayed at the bottom in the next image. This can be made permanent by saving a configuration in the options menu.

    Alternative axis mapping
    When all files have a non-standard data representation axis mapping may be used. With a mixed set of standard/non-standard files there is no optimal choice. This option is probably never needed but introduced here to comply with the internal standards of BistroMath.

    File sorting
    When the file scan is finished, the list will be sorted on the file name. Any column header can be double-clicked to change the sorting order to that column.


    See also:
     Installation and configuration,
     Configuration files,
     Save as Reference,
     Institute defaults configuration,
     Command line options.




    Conversion of (groups of) profiles
    conversion tab 


    On this page all files in the Source Directory of the selected file type will be written to the Output Directory in the also slected type. When, for whatever reason, the input filename equals the output file name, nothing is 
    done. Nonexistent output directories will be made as needed. For the conversion of individual files the Analysis page is more suitable as any file can be read and saved again in any format. For multiple scan files all scans in the file will be converted. Note that this need a well configured file name generation.

    Options:
    Recursive search: also subdirectories will be searched; the extra path elements will be added to the outpout path.

    Same Path as Source: when checked, the output path equals always the input path.

    Lowercase name: this will set the file names only to lower case. The directory part of the file path is written as is.

    Generate file names: when checked, output file names will be generated according to a given format.


    See also:
     File Name Format


    View menu
    view menu 



    There are a lot of graphical elements. See Graph area for methods for selecting and bringing them to the foreground.

    Measurement, Points, Calculated, Reference and Buffer curve
    The shortcuts "M", "P", "C", "R" and "B" can be used to selectively show one of these curves.
    The Points curve is a series of points, linked to the values as stored in the Measurement curve.

    FFF indicators
    The shortcut "F" toggles two elements:
  • Left and right slope: the length of these lines represents the calculation area.
  • Top model: the width represents the data range used for this model.

    In-Field Area indicators
    The shortcut "I" toggles two dotted vertical lines which show the limits of the In-Field area where flatness and symmetry are calculated.
    Note that this curve is shown when at least one of the options FFF indicators or Top Model is activated.

    Penumbra sigmoid indicators
    The shortcut "E" toggles the sigmoid model for the penumbra of a profile.
    The sigmoid fit data will be taken from the selected curve (if applicable and valid) in a darkened color of the selected curve.

    Top Model
    The shortcut "T" toggles the second order Top Model curve.
    Note that this curve is shown when at least one of the options FFF indicators or Top Model is activated.

    Values
    The shortcut "V" toggles the display of yellow dots. The normalised value for each shown curve is displayed in the bottom right corner.
    Accelerator keys are (any combinations of) <Ctrl>, <Shift> and <Alt>.

    High resolution values
    When checked an extra decimal is displayed.

    Measurement Norm Adjust mode
    The primary function of BistroMath is the comparison of relative data. Both measurement and reference are scaled to the same value at some point. For a division this scaling is not critical and made convenient by applying the same scaling point. For gamma analysis the scaling has a major effect on the results. Therefore an additional normalisation factor can be introduced. This function is explained 

    Standard Panel setup
    When this option is activated the default Results panel rules will be added to the rules list, overwriting all rules with identical rule id's. As they are added to the bottom of the list all "surviving" rules will be executed first, but these results will be overwritten mostly by the standard rules. The standard rules are within the code and therefore independent of any configuration file.
    When deactivated all panel rules will be removed. 

    Zoom profiles
    When "Zoom profiles is checked, profiles will be zoomed to the value defined by ZoomRange in the configuration file. The default is 1.03. The <arrow-Up> and <arrow-Down> key may be used to change the ZoomRange. If unzoomed <arrow-Up/Down> are linked to the right axis. Note that the <Z> key is attached to this function.

    Unzoom
    The Unzoom function unzooms the profile. The Zoom key-status is not changed however, thus preserving the autozoom behavior. Note that the U-key is attached to this function.

    Unzoom FFF autmatically
    When set, always Unzoom is done for a profile with proven FFF-features. The underlying criteria are explained here.

    Unzoom PDD autmatically
    When set, always Unzoom is done for a depth dose curve.

    Left Axis lower limit is zero 
    When set values below zero, as found in the first derivative will not be shown.

    Right axis linked to grid

    The horizontal grid lines are based on the left axis. When the right axis is linked to the grid the number of labels is decied by the grid, resulting in "less nice steps" (right part of example above).  When unlinked nice steps can be set freely, mostly resulting in a more quiet view (left part of example above).

    Smart scale electron PDD 
    When checked, the bottom axis maximum will be set around 2*R50.

    Positions in mm
    This will present all lengths and posiitons in mm. For the analysis results in the Results panel this will be done only if the configured multiplier is left at the default value of 1.

    Bottom axis always black
    When checked axis swapping will have no color effects. 

    No default Edge annotation
    When edge related results in the results panel reflect the primary edge settings, the related annotations can be suppressed.

    See also:
     Measurement options
     Axis swapping
     Graph area


    Measurement Normalisation Adjust Mode
    view menu 



    Measurement Norm Adjust mode
    The primary function of BistroMath is the comparison of relative data. Both measurement and reference are scaled to the same value at some point. For a division this scaling is not critical and made convenient by applying the same scaling point. For gamma analysis the scaling has a major effect on the results. Therefore an additional normalisation factor can be introduced.

    Relevancy
    Any renormalisation is only meaningful when a comparison with a reference is done.

    When not activated
    BistroMath will follow the basic rules. No effects are visible. The renormalisation is always reset to 100.

    When activated
  • It is only effectively activated in Advanced mode
  • A renormalisation input field is visible after a file is opened.
  • The "cursor" position is set to the absolute normalisation position.
  • When you move the "cursor" (not the mouse cursor) off the the absolute normalisation position the input field will disappear.
  • The renormalisation value will be reset to 100 every time a measurement set is read.
  • In the graph display the measurement data and all directly related data are multiplied with the renormalisation factor.
  • The division result is scaled accordingly.
  • The measurment data get the same multiplication factor as input to the Gamma analysis.
  • When the data are set as Temporary Reference, the measurement data are multiplied with the renormalisation factor. The factor itself is reset.

    See also:
     View menu
     Processing menu


    Measurement menu
    measurement menu 



    All items in this menu can be (un)checked to (in)activate the option. For most options the current profile is automatically reloaded to reflect the changes.

    Symmetry correction of Measurement
    See the Symmetry correction item for details. For the measurement it should stay unchecked mostly.
    The Flatness and Symmetry label will get a "s" as annotation.

    Move profiles to origin
    When checked, for all profiles which are measured at one fixed depth, the Center of Field value will define the shift of the complete profile. The Center of Field is default at the symmetric 50%-values of the filtered profile, but might also be determined by the edge positions or the field maximum. This should not be confused with manually shifting profiles.
    The Center, Width, Left and Right label will get a 'c' as annotation.

    Mirror profile
    The measurement curve is mirrored. Analysis results are given for the mirrored profile.

    Resample data
    This item must be checked to resample data to a fixed grid, which is defined in the Settings tab.

    Mayneord transform
    This applies a Mayneord transform to the current photon depth dose curve. The default SSD is the target value for the transformation.

    The application is clearly indicated in the lables.



    Extended symmetry submenu

    One of the items will be displayed below the standard symmetry item in the results panel, all are evaluated every time however. See the explanatory item for details.

    User Dose Level
    A non-standard level for field border detection may be defined in the Settings tab but will be used only when menu item is checked.

    Use PDD-fit results
    When checked, the fitted pdd will be used for data analysis.
    This option is grayed out when the cpu-intensive pdd-fit is not activated in the Settings Tab. For the used model and backgrounds see Nelder-Mead fit.


    Detect FFF


    A set of rules is applied to find FFF-profiles. The flatness is the slope in percent per cm.

    FFF Center of Field submenu
    The center of the field can be derived from either the penumbras (Border/Edge), set to zero (Origin) or taken from the position of the peak (Peak). The center of the field is displayed as "Center" in the results panel. Note that the analysis region (In-Field area) dpends on the center position.

    FFF Normalisation submenu
    A separate setting for FFF fields, further identical to conventional field sub menu above.

    FFF peak submenu
    This submenu offers the possibility to calculate the top position with alternative methods. These alternative methods are only applied when a FFF profile is detected.
  • Top model: the top is fitted with a model. The position of the maximum is taken as center position.
  • Slopes: the crossing point of the calculated slopes is taken as center position.
    Note that, as in the image above, for the non-default options the annotation and color for the center change.


    Detect Small fields
    When fields are smaller than a set limit, they are treated as small fields.

    Center of Small field submenu
    Appropriate choices can be made.

    Normalisation Small field submenu
    Appropriate choices can be made.


    Center of Wedge field submenu
    Appropriate choices can be made.

    Normalisation Wedge field submenu
    Appropriate choices can be made.


    Mirror to Buffer
    A mirrored version of the measurement is copied to the buffer.

    Local Peak Analysis at Cursor
    See the Local Peak Analysis item for details.

    Shift to Left / Right
    This is equivalent to to using "<" and ">" respectively and will shift the profile with a configurable step.



    General detection strategy submenu


    Accept bad penumbra's
    When checked any value for the penumbra is displayed, otherwise a configurable limit will be used. When the average of the penumbra's is above this limit, no punumbra information is displayed. You will also get the message "Penumbra too wide".

    Accept missing penumbra's
    When checked a best guess of the In-Field area is made to calculate the symmetry and flatness.

    Accept zero steps
    When checked multiple contiguous data points with the same position/depth are acceptable.

    Generic to PDD
    When a generic, untyped two-column data set, or a free scan is encountered this will be interpreted as PDD when checked.

    Generic to Electron
    When unknown assume electrons when this item is checked, otherwise the default is photons.

    Generic positions in mm
    When the file format contains no (implicit or explicit) information on the interpratation of positional values, these will be interpreted as mm when checked. Otherwise they are handled as cm.
    Currently this is only implemented for the truly generic two columns ascii data type.


    SSD scaling submenu


    Profiles scaled from SDD to SSD
    When checked for all profiles which are measured at one fixed depth, the positions will be scaled back to the distance of the SSD, i.e. the water surface.
    Field positions are denoted with "(r)". Note that only a geometrical scaling is applied.

    Profiles scaled to default SSD
    When checked for all profiles which are measured at some SDD, the positions will be scaled back to the default SSD. The default SSD can be configured in the Settings tab. When also the option Reference at default SSD in the Reference menu is checked, profiles at some SSD can be compared with original profiles at the default SSD as shown above. Field positions are denoted with "(r)".  Note that only a geometrical scaling is applied.


    Signal correction submenu


    Background correction
    See the Background correction item for details.

    OD to Dose conversion
    OD to Dose conversion may be used for several types of files in the Settings tab, but will be used only when menu item is checked.

    Ionisation to Dose conversion
     This menu item cannot be checked to activate it for all following data like other items in the Measurement menu. Its intended use is application by the user (<Shift>+<D>) after the date have been read. When the conversion is succesfull the menu item will be checked to reflect the current state. It is always reset for the next curve. The user is responsible for applying this function to the appropriate data: electron depth dose curves measured with ionisation chambers. There is no way to detect the used detector type in BistroMath. The other two conditions (electrons, depth dose) will be checked however. This function can be applied only once on a data set. Returning to the original data is possible by rereading the data (<Ctrl>+<L>). See also the scientific backgrounds.

    Renormalise source data
    When checked the source data of the measurement will be normalised to the actual normalisation settings. This opens to possibility to save normalised data.

    Axis manipulation submenu


    Preserve original data on export
    This option in the Measurement menu regulates the effects of axis swapping on export. Its default state is on. Switching off this option introduces serious data integrity problems because swapped data will be interpreted as original, unswapped data when opened again from file. This can undermine institution wide conventions for data interpretation. Therefore the state of this menu item is always on at startup and is not taken from any configuration file. Moreover the item is locked at program start.

    Invert axis (axis swapping)
    The direction of the data representation on the screen may be inverted when comparing side by side with the measuring system. The axis designations and/or the axis direction might be wrong. With these inversion options the axis sign (direction) is inverted at file read time and is reflected in the bottom axis labels. This has effect on all relevant analysis results..

    Alternative axis setup
    When, for any reason, the data columns for the coordinates do not meet the format conventions or are registered as the wrong scan type, this can be corrected by specifying the correct order of Inplane, Crossplane and Depth in the advanced settings tab. The feature is only used if Alternative axis setup checked. Axis swapping and axis sign inversion are applied as configured.




    See also:
     Configuration
     Settings
     Generic to PDD
     Center of Field and Normalisation of profiles
     Axis swapping
     Analysis results


    Generic/Free scan/Point to Point scans to PDD
    measurement menu 

    When the option Generic to PDD is checked, a generic, untyped two-column data set is encountered this will be interpreted as PDD. As this is a 1D dataset, the conversion to pdd is trivial.
    For Point to Point scans and Free scans the data are represented in a 3D set. When checked and the difference in depth between start of scan and end of scan is more than 3 cm, the correct path length is calculated along the scan axis. The zero position is set to the water level. The 3D data set is recalculated to represent a pure PDD preserving any offset along inplane and crossplane direction as refered to the water level.
    In the rather extreme example below the path length changes about 1%. For more realistic angles this effect is neglegible.

                              Original file                                    Recalculated and stored
    Start Point [I,C,D] [cm]: 2.3904  3.5067  39.04  Start Point [I,C,D] [cm]: 2.00 -3.00 39.58
    End Point   [I,C,D] [cm]: 1.9997 -3.0050  -0.03  End Point   [I,C,D] [cm]: 2.00 -3.00 -0.03 
    difference                0.3907  6.5117  39.07  End Point   [I,C,D] [cm]: 0.00  0.00 39.61

    See also:
     Measurement options


    Resampling data
    measurement menu 

    Many application cannot handle irregular sampled data. With Resample data in the Measurement options this can be corrected.
    Resampling is done by applying a local fit to the data and thus, by its very nature, involves filtering. It is controlled by two values in the Settings tab:
    - Resample grid: The distance between the resampled points. A zero value will use the average sampling distance.
    - Calculation width: the region that is used to apply the local fit. When there are less then two points in this region, the two adjacent points will be used for interpolation.

    See also:
     Configuration
     Settings


    Shifting profiles
    keyboard functions



    With the keys "<" and ">"  (on most keyboards <Shift>+<,> and <Shift>+<.>), the profile is manually shifted to the left or right in configurable steps. Although the analysis is repeated, the reference profile will not be shifted. It stays in the position decided at read time. The Move profile to Origin in the Measurement menu first moves the profile center to the origin and then matches a reference to this profile.
    When files are saved from the main window, any shift will be incorporated in the data. The editor window always contains the original, unshifted data and has its own file write options.

    See also:
     Keyboard functions
     Advanced Settings Tab


    Background correction
    measurement menu 


    The subtracted background value is stored internally with the profile. This enables the user to switch on/off the correction or to change its value, with an immediate update of the results without rereading the profile. The background correction can be applied selectively to certain types of files. See the Dose Conversion and Background tab.
    For a simple background subtraction an energy must be given and the Background box must be checked as shown above. Note that it will be only applied when also background correction is activated in the Measurement menu or, less likely, the Reference menu.

    See also:
     Measurement options
     Reference options
     Dose Conversion and Background tab


    Ionisation to Dose conversion
    measurement menu 

    The conversion from Ionisation to Dose is only valid for electron beam data measured with a ionisation chamber. The energy deposition of a high energy electron starts as soon the electron enters the water. This is fundamentally different for photon beams where energy deposition starts where at some depth the photon interacts with the water. The energy dependent stopping power ratio from air to water for electrons should be used to aquire a true dose. Therefore this should not be applied to diode or likewise solid state detector data. 
    The detection of the detector type from different data sources is unreliable and therefore ignored however. The users awareness on this is required. The conversion is actively limited to unconverted depth dose curves or fanline curves of a electron beam or undefined beam. 
     When the conversion is succesfull the menu item will be checked to reflect the current state. It is always reset for the next curve. The user is responsible for applying this function to the appropriate data: electron depth dose curves measured with ionisation chambers. This function can be applied only once on a data set. Returning to the original data is possible by rereading the data (<Ctrl>+<L>). 

     
    The algorithm is taken from the Dutch code of practice for high energy photon and electron beams, NCS 18.(http://radiationdosimetry.org/documents/ncs-18-).
    As can seen above this based on a original article by Burns et al. This is to my knowledge not online available freely. I do have a copy of this article. 

    [31]
    Burns D.T., Ding G.X. and Rogers D.W.O., R50 as a beam quality specifier for selecting stopping power ratios and reference depths for electron dosimetry, Med.Phys. 23 383-388, 1996.
    [32]
    Ding G.X., Rogers D.W.O., Mackie T.R., Calculation of stopping-power ratios using realistic clinical electron beams, Med. Phys. 22 489-501, 1995.


    Local Peak Analysis
    measurement menu 



    After default analysis the cursor is moved to the normalisation position. When there are multiple peaks in a single profile, the cursor can be moved to another peak. With this menu item or the keyboard shortcut Ctrl-Q, a peak search will be limited to levels higher than 50 percent of the local maximum. A local normalisation value will be found to start the peak analysis.

    See also:
     Measurement options


    Settings tab

    settings tab 



    General settings can be found here.

    Filter width
    Noise reduction is archived by application of a moving second degree polynomial function. The filtering witdth can be set through this option. The width in mm can be set for all filtering actions with a default value of 6 mm.


    Calculation width
    The width in mm can be set for the used number of points for normalisation. At least two points are used, to accommodate for interpolation. This width is also used for the calculation of dose levels (d90, d80, d50, d20). See also the notes on extracting data.
    The width in mm can be set to use multiple points in the calculation of values along the profile. A minimum of two points is used always for fallback to linear interpolation. This feature is used for the normalisation value and penumbra positions. The default value is 2 mm.
    When the Center of Field definition Near Origin is used any border/edge calculated CoF will be set to origin (equal to zero) when the difference is less than the Calculation width.


    Resample grid
    When a fixed data point spacing is needed, this can be set here. It is only used when the Resample data item in the Measurement menu is checked.
    The spacing is set in mm; a value of zero is interpreted as resampling with the average sample width. 


    Normalisation level
    The standard normalisation level may be adjusted to any convenient level. This feature produces results outside the scope of the current conventions in radiotherapy and is neither stored or read in the configuration.


    User Dose Level
    A dose level defined by the user may be used to calculate the width and penumbra positions of a profile. A value of 0 switches off this behavior.


    X / E penumbra h/l levels
    The high and low level for the profile penumbra width can be defined here for photons (X) en electrons (E). Defaults are 80% - 20% and 90% - 50% respectively.


    Default beam energy [MV / MeV]
    When no information on the energy is found in the data, this energy will be assumed.


    Histogram range
    For a division of measurement and reference the results within the In-Field area are sorted to bins from [-range;+range]. For gamma analysis all available results are sorted in bins from [0;+range].


    Assign origin to all 2D array lines
    Specific implementation for the StarCheckMaxi 2D-array. The measurement point in the origin is only assigned to the TG line. With this setting it can be inserted into the other lines.
    This will be allowed only when the device is in DOSE mode, not in DOSERATE mode (TASK_NAME=DOSE).


    Use nominal field size for In-Field area
    When this is checked the nominal field as found in the header is used. This will be only applied if the difference with the actual field size (after rescaling to SSD) differs less then 1 cm. This might give a more stable result but in practice difference will be neglegible as the actual range is data points based.


    Shift Settings: Inplane/Crossplane/Beam-offset
    A profile may be given a fixed offset manually for user specific reasons. This value is not stored and is always reset to 0 at program start, but will be applied to every  or depth dose profile. This can be practical for devices which cannot set the origin easily.  Note that these values are introduced in the preprocessing stage immediately after the axis mapping. The old PDD shift was set as a postprocessing shift.

    Shift Settings: Shift step
    With the keys "<" and ">" the profile or pdd may be shifted to the left or right in steps. The step size can be set here and is stored in the configuration. The same step size is used to move the cursor.




    Merge settings: Profile Shift (cm)
    Prior to the actual merging of two profiles, the profile to be merged can be shifted.


    Merge settings: PDD Shift (cm)
    Prior to the actual merging of two depth does, the lower part can be shifted.

    Merge settings: Use matching (cm)
    Prior to the actual merging of two profiles, the profile to be merged can be shifted by a matching procedure. The shape of the profile should be sufficient non-flat to work reliably. On the start of the match process the best result from either no shifting or preset shift is the goal to be improved.

    Merge settings: Scale overlap area
    Possible differences in normalisation at measurement time can be corrected. The ratio all summed values in the overlap area (after shifting and/or matching) is used to rescale the scan to be merged.


    Mayneord settings: Dmax
    Any negative value for Dmax will override the value as found from the beam analysis.

    Mayneord settings: SSD org
    Any non-zero value for SSD org will override the value for the original SSD as found with the beam data.

    Mayneord settings: SSD new
    Any non-zero value for SSD new will be taken instead of the Default SSD. This value will be set to the configured default SSD at program startup when no value is found in the configuration file.


    Gamma analysis settings: Dose norm
    The equivalent dose difference to agreement in percent for gamma=1.

    Gamma analysis settings: Distance norm
    The equivalent distance to agreement in mm for gamma=1.

    Gamma analysis settings: Cutoff Depth (mm)
    The lower depth limit in mm for gamma analysis at which dose points are incorporated in the results for depth dose curves.

    Gamma analysis settings: Cutoff Percentage
    The lower limit for gamma analysis at which dose points are incorporated in the results.

    Gamma analysis settings: Search Steps per mm
    The number of steps on each mm from the calculation point at which the reference dose is calculated. Without this interpolation the gamma analysis will give far too high outcomes. A minimum of at least 5 steps per mm is adviced.

    Gamma analysis settings: Search factor
