    A limiting value at which the search is aborted. The starting value is the dose difference in the evaluation point with a minimum of 1, multiplied with the Gamma Search factor. When lower Gamma values are found the limit decreases subsequently.



    PDD fit

    When the option Fit PDD to buffer is checked, a model will be used to fill the buffer. Also the difference between data and model is plotted as dots. This difference also drives the model optimisation in the right direction.
    For photons the model works extremely well, and the results of the (noise free) model can be used for analysis by checking Use PDD-fit results in the measurement menu option.
    The difference between model and data is ultimately expressed into one single value: the cost function. It consists of several components:
  • The summed squares of the difference between model and data over all depths.
  • A buildup power factor in the model itself for the photon model to avoid oscillation of the fit, which was sometimes observed. It can be set to a fixed value between 0 (now power factor) and 5. Alternatively the difference from 1 can be optimised.:
     pdd = I1*exp((-mu1+(mu2+(mu3+mu4*z)*z)*z)*z) - Ib*exp(-mub*z^mub_power)
  • The summed squares can be weighted by depth by dividing each squared difference with z^z_power. A value of 0 sets the power funtion to 1 for all depths and a value of 1 equals the function to z. Increasing the z-power will shift the weight to lower depths.
  • The Error to Noise Ratio is an estimate of the slowly evolving differences between model and averaged data in relation to the noise level. In the cost function this is for speed reasons implemented by summing the squares of the summed signed differences within a small number of overlapping regions. In the final calculation after optimisation a sum of signed diferences is calculated within a individual region for each point. The noise level itself is calculated from the difference between data and a filtered version of the data. When this ENR is above the limit the fit will be restarted until the maximum number of restarts is reached. Since the inherent noise level in the data is highly dependent on detector characteristics, averaging (measuring speed, number of points) and electronics, no general advise can be given here.
  • The Nelder-Mead optimisation is an endless loop. The code has to decide how to stop it. In general there are three parameters involved: the rate of change of the cost function, the number of cycles and the calculation time. The latter two can be set. A zero value for the cycles is set to a default of 100+3^#parameters.
  • The Nelder-Mead method may give much better results by restarting is several times. The actual applied number of restarts is somewhat fuzzy. At the start the number of restarts is calculated as: EngineMaxRestarts:= Ceil(twcNMrestarts/Max(1,(Amoebes-1)/2)); where the number of amoebes is set to the available CPU's (cores) minus 1. Afterwards the ENR is calculated. If this exceeds the set ENR criterium, the number of engine restarts is decreased by 1 and the loop is repeated until the number of restarts reaches zero or the ENR criterium is met. Always the total sum of restarts by engine and loop is reported.
  • The parameters mu3, mu4 and mx2 are related to the photon model and electron model respectively. When checked they will be given a meaningful start value and will be part of the optimisation. When unchecked their starting values are set to zero. The Nelder-Mead method will leave them unchanged as all changes are a (randomised) multiplier with the original value. In general the result will degrade significantly when pameters are switched off.
    The buffer data are normalised to the dose maximum and can be saved as selected curve, including all fit parameters.
    Starting with version 3.08 the optimisation engine is made multithreaded. On every restart the best result is distributed over all threads.
    Note: the Nelder-Mead engine is also used for fitting the dose maximum of a pdd, the top of a FFF profile and the sigmoid fit, but in all these cases the number of parameters is low and with good starting values, these models are completely stable and will reach their optimum values quickly. Time and number of cycles are not relevant here.


    See also:
     Configuration
     Background correction item
     Matching profiles
     Gamma analysis
     Advanced Settings
     Fit of pdd with the Adaptive Nelder-Mead method


    Center of Field and Normalisation
    measurement menu 

    Design goals of BistroMath
    Virtually all commercial available software assumes that the center of the field is in the origin. When both penumbras of the profile are on the same side of the origin, this field cannot be analysed. These fields are part of a jaw calibration procedure and therefore should be processed in BistroMath as design goal. This design goal was met by defing the center of field (CoF) is the average of left and right penumbra positions. As further expansion of this design setup this point should also be taken as normalisation point.
    Taking the origin as CoF imposes the need for a careful setup of your data collection system. Water phantom scanning software offers a CAX-procedure to accomplish this. However this is also prone to analysis challenges and residual errors. With a symmetric field the CoF can be taken as alternative for the origin, offering the option to skip the CAX-procedure. Any reference profile can be easily moved to the same CoF position as the reference. Therefore a twofold uncertainty in the CAX-procedure can be avoided. Of course, any deviation in the jaws/leaves will also introduce small errors in the correct CoF. For very small fields always the CoF (=maximum) should be taken as unertainties in jaw/leaf-posiitons becomes dominant and the origin clearly is not the correct choice. The design goals of BistroMath overcome all these difficulties.



    Calculation of normalisation value
    These settings are found on the Field Types tab.
    Normalisation of noisy data at a position possibly without data is non-trivial. Poor vertical alignment results in visualy exaggerated differences. Also the Gamma analysis will degrade. For the division of measurement and reference this is not a problem as this curve is rescaled after median filtering anyway.
    The standard approach of Bistromath is to calculate an avarage over a small area, the user configurable setting Calculation width. This gives mostly a reliable result. 
    For comparison across different linacs there might be more pronounced differences. Also the exchange of a gun filament may introduce unexpected differences. In the classical approach all differences are shown in relation to the central normalisation point.
    To evaluate what is "acceptable" alternative normalisation points can be used. In the example above both measurement are normalised to the average over their In-Field area. Now both curves are not set 100% at the normalisation point as can be readily seen. The measurement normalisation may also be multiplied by the normalisation Level to shift it to any level. These actions influence the results for normalisation value, maximum, and minimum and maximum over the In-Field area. Therefore these values are displayed in red.


    Alternative setups
    For both CoF and normalisation can be chosen separate strategies. By making different choices these points can be coupled or decoupled.

    Center of Field
    There are three options for setting the CoF
  • Border/Edge (design goal of BistroMath)
  • Origin (default for most software)
  • Maximum (a meaningful alternative)

    Normalisation
  • Center of Field
  • Origin
  • Maximum
  • Average of In-Field area


    Effect on FFF profiles


    A FFF profile can only be detected after primary analysis of a profile, including determination of CoF and normalisation. But when a FFF field actualy is detected there are more meaningful options for the Center of Field:
  • Default/Top (follow strategy for flattened fields, report with Top model)
  • Default/Slopes (follow strategy for flattened fields)
  • Top (use the central dome)
  • Slopes (the intersection fitted lines to the area outside of the central dome)
    The background for the alternative definitions is documented in the FFF-profiles topic.


    When the CoF is set to the origin and a FFF profile is detected and one of the default options above is selected, the top will be reported according to one of the models.

     
    Consequences for moving profiles to the Origin
    Moving profiles to the origin can only be done after basic analysis. As alternative definitions become active during analysis, previous derived results might not be entirely adequate. Therefore the complete analysis is repeated when necessary.

    See also:
     Measurement options
     FFF-profiles
     Settings


    Advanced Settings tab
    advanced settings tab 



    More advanced settings can be found here.

    Add date and time to filename
    When checked the date and time will be added to the proposed file name. This option is also used for SpecialModes 2 and 3.

    Advanced Mode at startup
    When this option is checked and stored in a configuration file, the program will start in Advanced Mode.

    FFF property in file
    Starting with version 4.25 BistroMath can read and write explicit FFF assignments in OmniPro and PTW file formats. Also, "FFF" will be added to the energe for standard (reference) file names. For strict backward compatibility this feature can be unchecked.

    Show "Lock Critical Items" in File menu
    In the intended design a series of menu items is disabled or hidden as non-configurable default:
  • File > Lock Critical Items
  • File > Save as Reference
  • Options > Config save as...
  • Process > Auto Scaling
  • Measurement > Preserve data on export
    To enable all these items the Lock Critical Items menu item itself has to be unchecked with <Ctrl>+<Alt>+<R> as it is hidden. It was reported however that this menu combination was unresponsive. This could not be reproduced on any other system to my knowledge. To access these critical options anyway, the Lock Critical Items menu item can be set to a visible state. This item can be stored in the configuration file to override the standard design.

    Show warnings
    The status bar at the bottom will show extra information on the analysis process.

    Use history list
    When this option is checked a series of data sets will be kept in memory. Also multiple files can be dropped or opened at the same time, limited by the size of the history list. This checkbox is linked to the Use History list in the File menu. The number of files in the history can be set here.

    Log Level
    When set to 0 all logging is stopped. The maximum level is 4.
    In level 3 a lot of details of the analysis can be observed:
     ->FindLevelPos[Measured] at normalised level 0.50: -19.932 (-20.10|-19.80|-19.80) cm / 19.969 (19.80|20.10|20.10) cm
    In this example, for the procedure and curve, the left and right border positions ((leftmost data point for the analysis range, nearest point, rightmost analysis point) are given.

    Use always matching for profile alignment
    When checked always matching will be done to align measurement and reference profile, even when all penumbras are available.

    Auto set decimal separator for: (a list of characters)
    In countries with the comma as standard numeric decimal point symbol files might be stored with the comma is separator. BistroMath expects a dot symbol as decimal separator and will not start when the localisation does not meet this requirement.
    Still there can be files with the wrong format. When this option is checked, BistroMath will first count the number of occurences for each of the symbols given. The most-found symbol will be applied. The drawback is that this will be done for every ascii file which takes extra processing.
    A caveat might be that for a correctly formatted file wit a lot of commas in the header and few data points the wrong symbol is selected. Therefore it is advised to use this feature only when needed. When a file fails to open unexpectedly it will be retried when this option is checked and the user returns to the Analysis tab. Before deciding so please check the raw data tab whether this might be meaningful.

    Filter width outlier analysis
    With few points and much noise or gradient changes a second order fit may give unwanted results. When the fit is signifcantly outside the vertical range, several techniques are used to find a better estimation. When the used number of points exceeds the given number of points, no fallback methods are used.

    Bad penumbra
    When the average of both penumbra's exceeds this limit, it is considered 'bad'. In the measurement menu these can be accepted or not. When not accepted you will get the message "Penumbra too wide". The original design goal of this rule was to discard nonsensical profiles. The mechanism is switched on/off through the Measurement menu option Accept bad penumbra's.

    Pips pixel size
    Pips profiles are presented as a one dimensional array without explicit position information. The positition can be  reconstructed when the effective pixel size at isocentre level is given in mm.

    Origin min. level
    When due to missing penumbra(s) the center of field position is not valid the origin can be used for normalisation. This will only be done if the value at the origin is an acceptable fraction of the maximum. When not fullfilled, the maximum will be used.

    Colors
    Bothe grid color and background color of the graph panel can be changed. Also the background color for most oither panels can be set. These colors can be stored in a presets file, giving each "task" its own symbolic colors. 

    Axis remapping
    When the measurement option Alternative axis setup is checked, the axis mapping of Inplane, Crossplane and Depth can be changed here when, for any reason, the data columns for the coordinates do not meet the file format conventions. When intentionally changed to non-standard also Alternative Axis setup in the File menu is checked.

    Swapping GT | AB | UD | LR indicators
    The direction of the data representation on the screen may be inverted when comparing side by side with the measuring system. 
    With these swapping options only the axis designations (GT/TG | AB/BA | UD/DU | LR/RL) are swapped. Nothing is changed to the data or analysis results.
    The diagonal scan indicators are handled as LR-type here.
    When swapping is active the bottom axis title is red except when the view menu option Bottom axis always black is checked.
    The data itself may also be swapped independently at file read time. 




    Match settings: Range divider
    During each iteration cycle the total span of the profile is divided by the Match Range divider. Thus in the first cycle the measurement is shifted half this width. See Profile matching for more details.

    Match settings: Step number
    The number of steps that is made over the Match Range. See Profile matching for more details.

    Match settings: Normalisation Percentage
    The maximum amount that the normalisation value of the measurement is corrected for at each step to find the lowest cost function. See Profile matching for more details.

    Match settings: Inclusion Limit
    The data point should exceed this limit to be included in the matching evaluation.




    Linac symmetry error
    When in the Measurement menu the option Linac symmetry error is checked, the Linac symmetry error is calculated within a ring shaped area of the beam. The inner and outer radius (as defined at 100 cm) can be set here. The result sign can be inverted by checking the relevant Invert sign checkbox.


    See also:
     Edge detection
     Settings
     SpecialMode



    Field Types tab
    field types tab 



    Field Type related settings for both detection and analysis for all defined types can be found here. See also the introduction to the concept of Field Types. 

    On Borders and Edges
  • A Border is defined as the position a certain fraction of the normalisation value on both sides of the penumbra. Therefore these points have by definition the same level. Possible values are 'dLow', 'dHigh', 'd20', 'd50', 'd80', 'd90' and 'dUser', where dLow and dHigh are configured as 20% and 80% respectively for photons and 50% and 90% respectively for electrons. dUser is open for the user to set at any level.
  • An Edge is a position defined by some mathematical function at a (somewhat) variable, unknown, level. Possible values are 'Derivative' and 'Inflection'.
  • An in-between value is 'Sigmoid50' which is based on the Sigmoid model, but uses this function to calculate the 50% level. It should be very close to the classical d50 position but more stable for sparse data.
    Therefore a Border is dependent on the Normalisation position which might be also depend on the Center of Field definition. This basically is an endless loop as one might depend on the other. Bistromath resolves this complication by doing a dual loop analysis in which preliminary results lead to stable final results.


    Detect
    Whether or not detection rules are applied for a certain field type. The Standard type is anything that is not assigned to another type. Therefore detection is not relevant for the Standard type.


    Detect diagonals
    With "diagonals" are meant collimator angles of 45+n90 degrees for measurements along the main axes. When a value for the field width is given with the measurement data and the actual field size exceeds this value with more than 5%, then it is assumed the profile is a diagonal measurement or the collimator angle deviates more than 20 degrees from the principal directions (0, 90, 180, 270). The In-Field area for these measurements is 70% of the nominal width. When the diagonal-rule is used, the In-Field area indicators will be red in stead of blue.


    Measurement symmetry correction
    Asymmetry of the measurement can be corrected. The methods are described in a separate topic. Normally this should be off. During beam adjustment it might be handy to separate energy effects and beam alignment affects. Note that this setting is smart linked to symmetry correction setting in the Measurement menu: changing it in the menu will be reflected om this page. With every new profile the menu setting is set to the state on this page for the detected field type.


    Reference symmetry correction
    Also reference data might be prone to small assymmetry effects. These can be corrected. This is the most relevant for Standard profiles. This setting is smart linked to the Symmetry correction in the Reference menu.


    Dynamic penumbra width
    NCS-33 introduces the penumbra width based on levels scaled with the height of the inlection point:


    In Bistromath this is available as "dynamic penumbra width". For each field type a preference can be set. Note that this can be overridden in the Results Panel (rule 'p'). When actively applied, the label is denoted with a asterisk ('Left*80-20).



    Primary border/edge definition and Fallback border/edge definition
    The primary definition of the field border is applied unless its application is overruled because the primary definition fails or defined rules for that Field type dictate to use the Fallback definition.


    Center of Field definition
    BistroMath leaves it to the user to use appropriate choices. Possible values are 'Border/Edge', 'Origin', 'Near Origin' and 'Maximum'. Please note the general remarks above on the recursive character.
    The 'Near Origin' setting will collapse the CoF to 'Origin' when the edge-based field center position is smaller than the Calculation width value. This enables a stable outcome when the calculated CoF is almost zero. In this scenario only shifts will be applied to a reference when no CAX-procedure was executed during measurement setup or the field setup itself is asymmetric.




    Normalisation definition
    BistroMath leaves it to the user to use appropriate choices. Possible values are 'Center', 'Origin', 'Maximum' and 'In-Field area'. Please note the general remarks above on the recursive character.
    The normalisation of depth dose curves has its own rules and is highly configurable to local standards or protocols.
  • Center of field: This option forces the normalisation point, for profiles only, to be taken at the geometrical centre of the field. If unchecked the central axis is taken. When there are no data for the central axis (origin) or the central axis value is less then 10% of the maximum, also the centre of the field is taken.
  • Maximum: the maximum within the profile is taken as normalisation.
  • Origin (central axis): the standard in classical radiotherapy.
  • Average In-Field area: the normalisation value will be adjusted to the average over the In-Field area. This feature produces results outside the scope of the current conventions in radiotherapy.


    Center Model radius (cm)
    The range of data around the maximum or center of a profile, always limited to the In-Field area, used to fit a second order polynomal function, the Top model. This feature is designed to describe the position and shape of the top of a FFF profile. The top of these profiles might differ from the field center as defined by the field borders. The difference can be used to adjust the beam parameters. For this application a radius of 2.5 cm is shown to work reliably. A value of zero will ignore this model.
    There is a wider application for this model: it can be used to describe the overal shape of (a part) of the In-Field area of any profile. This might be used to set the volume correction for a detector. As such there is no advice for how to set the range; it depends highly on the intended use.
    The display of highest order parameter, the curvature, can be configured in the Results Panel, but is not in the standard panel list.
     

    Default SSD [mm]
    When no information on the SSD is found in the data, this value will be assumed. It is also used for scaling calculations involving the In-Field area.


    FFF detection
    These parameters are described in the FFF profiles topic. Activation of these detection rules is governed above.


    Edge Detection and related parameters
    As base rule the field border is found at 50% of the normalisation value. For wedged fields this gives an unacceptable result. This is tackled by using a derivative function combined with statistical analysis to find the edges. See Edge detection for details of this advanced process. The same can be done to detect non-flat beams like the FFF beams. Based on the found derivative edges a sigmoid function can be applied on the edges.
    When the the derivative edge position differs more from the 50% than a given value Edge fallback (mm), and this function is activated the "fallback" method will be used. Center and border values are displayed in a teal color. For film data the difference limit is ignored and edge data is used when this option is checked.
    Setting the difference limit to zero will force using the fallback method for any profile.
    For double-wedge profiles this option should be switched off as for these profiles the steepest slope position might significantly differ from the 50% position. The latter is usually the objective for these profiles.
    When Edge Detection results are actively applied, results are denoted with "(e)" for derivative, "(inn)" for the sigmoid inflection point where nn is the level at the inflection point and "(s)" for the sigmoid based 50% value. These annotations can be suppressed when used as primary method.


    Sigmoid radius
    For sparse data the sigmoid model offfers slightly better results. The radius should (roughly) cover the full range of the penumbra region. The default of 10 mm showed to work fine for all tested cases.
    For conventional profiles the sigmoid model may be used as an alternative model for the penumbra to calculate either the inflection point, the 50% level or even the nn% user's level. BistroMath has a reverse calculation model for this purpose. There are rules to use other levels than the inflection point: the ratio of requested level and low sigmoid level should be larger than 1.1, with the high sigmoid level smaller than 0.9 and within a range of 0.85-1.15 with the level at the inflection point. These rules will not be met for FFF profiles.


    Small field width
    Below this value fields will be assigned to the Small Field type.


    Wedge 90% level shift factor
    When the Right 90% level position is on the left of the field center or the Left 90% level position is on the right of the field center, a field is considered to be of the Wedge type. A more negative value will increase the sensitivity, a zero or positive value will swicth off wedge detection.


    MRlinac detection
    There is no fail safe profile based detection rule. Therefore the name of the treatment unit is compared against a comma separated list.


    See also:
     Configuration
     Background correction item
     Matching profiles
     Gamma analysis
     Advanced Settings
     Sigmoid function
     Edge detection


    Symmetry correction of Measurement / Reference
    measurement / reference menu 

    If this item is checked a measurement profile will be corrected for asymmetry as far as this can be descibed with the slope of a straight line fitted over the data in the In-Field area after this profile is loaded. This is meaningful in the process of adjusting beam parameters tot discriminate between several types of asymmetry.
    There are two limits involved here with no access through the user interface but available in the configuration files.

    [WellhoferObject]
    SymmetryCorrectionLimit=2.00 When the symmetry is above this limit it will not be corrected to avoid extreme results. 
    SymmetryCorrectionLevel=0.10 The correction is clipped to the last value when the data fall below this level. 

    The method described above does not work well for FFF-profiles. In that case the slope is defined as the sum of the left and right slope of the FFF-profile. For symmetrical profiles the sum will be zero.
    For reference profiles with some kind of asymmetry it may be useful to correct this before it is used as divisor on the measurement profile.
    When symmetry correctien is applied to the measurement, the flatness and symmetry results are denoted with "(s)".




    See also:
     Measurement options


    Automatic load of reference files
    reference menu 

    There is a list reference measurements that are used to evaluate differences in a measurement. To be as unobtrusive as possible in the QA process the given characteristics of the measurement are used to find a reference.
    When checked the relevant reference profile is loaded and presented as the Reference curve.
    All reference files are selected by the user the first time and loaded as a primary measurement and then stored as reference with a automatically generated name that reflects the contents.
    Although the name of the reference file may be correct and the file actually is loaded, it migth not be used for comparison as depicted below:

    In this case the internal values for parameters in the reference file lead to a 10x8 field and should have another file name the actual file name. Therefore there is a conflict.


    See also:
     Save as Reference,
     Divide by Reference,
     Reference Menu.


    Divide by Reference
    reference menu 

    If this item is checked a measurement will be divided by the relevant reference and shown as the Calculated profile. Both curves are filtered first and then aligned. A medianfilter is used for post-processing.


    See also:
     Reference menu.


    Align reference with measurement
    reference menu 

    If this item is checked the reference is shifted towards the measurement, based on the difference in center position. If no penumbra is found for both measuement and reference the center position is estimated from the derivative. Note that when a division of measurement and reference is generated, both curves are filtered first and then again aligned. Both shifts are controlled with this item.
    As fallback there is also a matching method included.

    See also:
     Profile matching
     Derivative of profile


    Reference menu

    reference menu 



    The reference menu regulates the core features of Bistromath. All items in this menu can be (un)checked or to (in)activate the option. For most options the current profile is automatically reloaded to reflect the changes.

    Automatic load of Reference
    When checked the relevant reference profile is loaded and presented as the Reference curve.

    Device specific Reference
    This option is intended for selected 2D-arrays with multiple curves with a fixed order in one single file. When applicable a reference may be stored in the original file format. The appropriate curve will always be taken from the reference file.
    At this moment only the PTW Starcheck Maxi and Sun Nulear IC PROFILER are supported. Other devices may be added on request. This option needs specific information in the configuration file to work properly. When this information is missing, this menu item will be disabled.

    Reference from Generic Beam List
    With this option switched on, Generic Beam list becomes available in the Confiuration tab. Both this setting and the list can be stored in any configuration file.

    Index multi reference
    With this option switched on, much more possibilities are opened by making an index of all the scans in a reference file. Of course, this may take sisgnificant time as all these scans have to be analysed. Now different file formats for the PTW Starcheck can be mixed and unsorted multi reference files can be opened as temporarary reference. Note that any entry in a multiple scan file that cannot be analysed as qualified scan is simply ignored. Indexing large files might take considerable time however. When multiple scans qualify as reference, the first one will be taken.

    Reference at default SSD
    When a measurement at some SSD is rescaled to the default SSD, this option allows to take automatically the appropriate reference at the default SSD. Note that this option is deactivated (grayed out) when the measurement is not rescaled.

    Background correction
    See the Background correction item for details.

    Symmetry correction of Reference
    See the Symmetry correction item for details. For the reference it might be used as standard behavior.

    Align with measurement
    If this item is checked the reference is shifted towards the measurement, based on the difference in center position. As (mostly) there are small errors in the setup of the watertank, the standard choice is to activate this option. When unchecked also differences in block/leaf calibration are much more relevant.

    Align on Top for FFF
    If this item is checked (and enabled) the reference is shifted towards the measurement, based on the difference in position of the top for a FFF profile using the choosen model to calculate the top.

    Normalise reference
    With this setting normalisation of the reference curve is forced. Under most circumstances this will have little effects as the file comparison mode uses specific strategies to optimise the graphical overlay of the reference and the division itself will be normalised anyway. With the addition of the reference to the measurement this might be a matter of choice.

    Calculation is ...
    The result of comparing the measurement with the reference can be
     - a division of measurement and reference,
     - a gamma analysis,
     - the addition of measurement and reference,
     - none of the choices above.


    See also:
     Center of Field and Normalisation of profiles
     Compare with reference,
     Add reference to measurement,
     Automatic load of reference,
     Profile matching.




    Gamma analysis
    settings tab 





    With gamma analysis the differences between a measurement and its reference can be condensed to one number which combines dose errors, typically in the In-Field area and position errors in the penumbra region on a normalised vector base. This vector gives the smallest distance of combined dosimetric error and position error. The unit length is defined as a reference distance in mm (Distance norm) and dose difference in percent (Dose norm). A dose difference can be calculated in two ways: as percentage of the local dose or as percentage of the normalisation value of the profile. In an area around each measurement point the smallest vector is searched. Very fine steps (Search Steps/mm) with interpolation between points of the reference curve are needed to find a meaningful gamma value. Since the calculation is sensitive for noise a median filter is applied afterwards. The analysis of profiles is only done for relative values above a given threshold (Cutoff Percentage) and beyond the buildup region of depth dose curves (Cutoff Depth). Also, the search is stopped when no better point is found within the region limited to the initial distance to agreement mulitiplied by the Search factor. The result can be shown as calculated curve or histogram. The Confidence Limit, defined as the sum of the mean value of the gamma curve and the standard deviation multiplied with 1.5 of the same curve. The Gamma pass rate is defined as the percentage of points with a gamma value less or equal to one. 
    The vertical range of the Gamma curve in the graphical display is set with the Histogram range in the Advanced settings tab. Note that changing any settings will make the Histogram tab temporarily invisible to force recalculation in the Analysis tab.
    Any renormalisation will change the result markedly.



    Limit to 'In-Field area'
    When checked the analysis will be limited to the In-Field area. This setting is available for all classes of profiles.
    Note that this setting is only relevant for the graph panel and the histogram. The confidence limit in the standard rule setup for the results panel is always limited to the In-Field area.

    Dose norm 
    The equivalent dose difference to agreement in percent for gamma=1.

    Local dose
    When checked the difference between measurement and reference is scaled to the local measurement value, otherwise the difference is scaled to the normalisation point.

    Distance norm 
    The equivalent distance to agreement in mm for gamma=1.

    Search steps per mm
    The number of steps on each mm from the calculation point at which the reference dose is calculated. As the resolution of most data sets is low a number of at least 5 is advised. Although the result will be derived by interpolation, the outcome is much more realistic.

    Cutoff percentage
    The lower limit for gamma analysis at which dose points are incorporated in the results.

    Depth dose cutoff  (mm)
    The lower depth limit in mm for gamma analysis at which dose points are incorporated in the results for depth dose curves.

    Search factor
    A limiting value at which the search is aborted. The starting value is the dose difference in the evaluation point with a minimum of 1, multiplied with the Gamma Search factor. When lower Gamma values are found the limit decreases subsequently.


    See also:
     Settings


    Adding two profiles
    reference menu 



    It is also possible to set the calculation as the addition of measurement and reference. Mostly this is done with a fixed reference (loaded as temporary reference) without position or symmetry correction of the reference. Also the reference might or might not be normalised before the addition is done. Here this task is loaded as the preset 'addition'.



    The calculated curve is a completely valid data set which, when selected, can be saved in the same way as any measurement.





    See also:
     Configuration,
     Presets menu,
     Reference menu.


    Penumbra searching with the first derivative
    background information 

    The derivation function includes histogram analysis of a single positive and a negative peak.
    From the histogram the range with low values is defined as a "dead band". The peaks should cross this dead band for robust edge detection. If such a peak in the derivative is cut off by the scan limit before showing a maximum the edge is set to the scan limit. True peaks are modelled with a second order fit for interpolation.

    See also:
     Aligning the reference profile


    Profile matching
    background information 

    If both standard penumbra analysis and first derivative fail, there is a matching method to align the reference.
    The reference is shifted through an iterative process. In the first cycle the measurement is shifted to the left over the total profile span divided by the Match Range factor. In a number of steps, defined as the Match Step factor, the profile is shifted to the right. At each step the sum difference in the overlapping area is minimised by moving the reference vertically. This vertical movement is limited by the Match normalisation percentage at the position with the lowest cost function. Centered around this position the cycle is repeated along a smaller span. The iteration stops when the profile movement steps are smaller than half of the smallest distance between data points. It may be problematic to use the penumbra for matching. Therefore a Match inclusion limit is available.
    The optimum vertical shift can easily found with good approximation by interpolation between the largest negative and positive correction.


    Some tested situations:







    See also:
     Aligning the reference profile,
     Advanced Settings,
     Edge detection.



    Options menu

    options menu 



    Advanced mode
    To assure an uncomplicated standard mode almost all settings and menu's are locked and can be unlocked by checking Advanced Mode. However, loading presets can and will set all items regardless the state of Advanced Mode. The Advanced Mode state itself is not configurable. When advanced mode is preferred at startup this should be set in the Advanced Settings tab and stored in a configuration file.
    On returning to standard mode the last known configuration and preset will be restored from disk, ignoring the stored Advanced Mode preference.
    Note that depth dose curve fitting will only be done when Advanded Mode is checked.
    SpecialMode options in the Processing menu are only visible in Advanced Mode.

    Simple Mode
    When this mode is checked, less items will be visible. This behavior can be extended to the results panel through the configuration file.
    Note that Simple Mode might hide wrongly configured settings. Therefore, BistroMath should be configured with Advanced Mode switched on and Simple Mode off. Then save this configuration (mostly as institute.ini) with optionally Advanced Mode off and/or Simple Mode on.



    Filter width...
    Noise reduction is archived by application of a moving second degree polynomial function. The filtering width can be set through this option. The default value is 6 mm.
    For a large step size combined with a large gradient changes a second order filter might produce unwanted results. These can be found with statistical methods. When found there are two levels of fallback: a linear fit and taking the original value.

    Normalisation width
    This links to the Calculation width item in the Settings tab. To avoid noise of normalisation to a single data point, a range in mm can be given.

    Load/Save config
    See configuration for details.

    See also:
     Configuration
     Institute defaults


    Edge detection
    settings tab 

    Parameters
    Activation and limit can be found in the Field Types tab. In the current version of BistroMath there ara a primary and fallback method to find edges. The primary method might just fail on the data or differ too much from expected, for instance when the d50 is chosen as primary method. Edge detection as described below is now always done.

    Function and application

    As base rule the field border is found at 50% of the normalisation value. For wedged fields this gives an unacceptable result. This is solved by using a derivative function. The same can be done to detect non-flat beams like FFF beams and double-wedge profiles. When the difference is more than the given limit, the peak of the derivative is assumed to give the correct border. Center and border values are displayed in a teal color.

    In the example the 50% values clearly differ from the derivative peaks. The difference exceeds the (default) threshold of 2 mm and therefore the derivative method is used. For film data the difference limit is ignored and edge data are used when this option is checked.
    Setting the difference limit to zero will force using edge detection for any profile.
    Using a user dose level will override any edge detection.
    With double-wedge profiles the FWHM is obtained to relate it to the beam energy. In this case both FFF detection and edge detection is not wanted because it will not produce field borders at 50%. Either switch off edge detection or introduce a high threshold.


    Derivative method
    For a standard field the derivative of the profile will produce a clear maximum and minimum which can be used to find the inflection points in the penumbra. For the most beam limiting devices this closely resembles the 50% values. But the field edge detection for non-trivial fields like wedged profiles or partial profiles, where it is much more needed also needs much more analysis of the derivative. Here statistical approaches are used.
    1 The profile is filtered (optionally) with a quadratic filter.
    2 The first derivative is calculated.
    3 The derivative again is cleaned with a quadratic filter. The result is the brown Buffer curve in the examples above.
    4 Then repeatedly a histogram is made until a reasonable number of bins is achieved.
    5 Now the largest bin is defined as "dead band".
    6 The first and last crossing of the derivative through the dead band are detected.
    7 The minimum and maximum of the derivative within this area are searched. These are the nearest data points to the edges.

    This process works well for complete profiles, including wedged profiles but fails for incomplete profiles. Therefore additional analysis is needed.

    8 A profile is marked as "wedged" when the ratio of the profile data at the max and minimum of the derivative is larger than 4 (or smaller than 1/4).
    9a For non-wedged profiles the dead band should fall within the central 80% of bins. When the dead band is in the upper or lower 10% respectively the left edge or the right edge is declared invalid.
    9b For wedged profiles the histogram is made around the area of the left and right edge. Now the upper and lower limits are 3% of the total range in the subset. This works well for a 60° wedge. A more shallow wedge will produce a much more markedly penumbra and should be found without problems.
    10 For valid edges the exact position is calculated by applying a quadratic fit to the found (nearest points to the) edge positions. 

    Partial profiles will produce one valid edge which still can be used for profile alignment. When one edge is missing the center of the field is unknown and no shift to the origin can be calculated. Note also that no use is made of any accompanying information of the profile.

    Sigmoid fit
    After edge detection as described above, the area around the calculated edge will be used to fit a sigmoid function.
    This sigmoid can be initialised right away from the already known edge information and is optimised using a Nelder-Mead optimisation. The cost function is the summed quadratic difference between model and data over the penumbra region.

    For noisy data sets or sparse data sets like the Starcheck Maxi the sigmoid fit possibly performs slightly better than the derivative based method because it uses all data in the penumbra region. For profiles with sufficient points the differences are small. In the example below the original data set (left) is resampled to a 3 mm grid (right). The inflection point of the sigmoid model is marked with "+". Both derivative approach and sigmoid model do not produce the 50% level. The Sigmoid model might also be used to derive the 50% level.
    The sigmoid results can be applied on the Buffer curve. Note that the inflection point still might become less reliable when applied on conventional profiles where the penumbra becomes an almost straight line.



    [Richards, F. J. (1959). "A Flexible Growth Function for Empirical Use". Journal of Experimental Botany 10 (2): 290-300. doi:10.1093/jxb/10.2.290.]

    When also edge detection fails the two curves will be matched to find the best alignment. The user can opt to always use this method.


    See also:
     Results panel,
     User dose level,
     Settings Tabl,
     Advanced Settings Tab.




    FFF beams
    settings tab, measurement menu 

    Introduction
    Flattening Filter Free beams are beams without a so-called flattening filter which produces a more or less homegeous ouput across the whole field. Essentially this is only optimal for a certain region of depths and large enough fields. With modern planning systems, the need for such a flattened field is not critical anymore. When the flattening filter is removed the output will typically be tripled resulting in much shorter treatment times. The main application is brain tumors, where small fields and high doses are needed. For wide fields the advantage disappears because the intensity has to be adapted by a beam shaping device like the MLC to get the correct dose at each position.
    By its nature the Flatness parameter is meaningless for FFF beams. Also the symmetry calculation will perform different on these profiles. Handling these data needs specific detection and analysis.
    There is also discussion on the definition of "center of field". The classical approch is to take the average of both field borders. For FFF beams alternative calculations can be chosen.

    There are three mechanisms to assign the FFF Field Type. All have their pros and cons:
  • Detection of profiles by shape,
  • Identifying labels in files,
  • Explicit manual assignment.

    Detection
    There are a lot of non-flat beams which are not FFF. Still the specific features of FFF-class beams need a special treatment. Therefore a number of detection criteria is used which all have to be fullfilled. This behavior can be switched on/off as item the Field Types tab. By its nature it will not detect FFF in depth dose curves. Small FFF fields will go undetected.
    Beside of the FFF Field Type, BistroMath uses also a flag "FFF detected". This is set by this detection mechanism and is needed for FFF-specific analysis results.
  • The field size must have a minimal value, otherwise it will not show FFF features anyway.
  • Both penumbra's must be found. Incomplete fields are ignored.
  • The scan should be of the AB, GT or Angle type. A diagonal scan with a shifted measuring device will become a "free scan" when the origin is not crossed within 0.5 cm. Shifted scan parallel to the main axes are acceptable.
  • The dose value at the edge of the "analysis area" (in flattened beams the "In-Field area") should drop at least with a given percentage [Minimal dose difference (%)].
  • The inflection point should differ noticeably from the 50% border [Min. edge difference (mm)].
    The latter two criteria are configurable and can be changed in the Field Types tab.

    Identification
    Starting with version 4.25 there are two more methods to identify a FFF data set. For OmniPro v6/7/8, IBA RFA300 .asc, PTW and Sun Nuclear .snctxt and clipboard file formats the FFF state can be identified in the data. Information on other formats is appreciated.

    Assignment
    Files of the Standard field type can be set to FFF or reverse. The initial state (checked or unchecked) is derived from the two sources above: detection and identification. 


    FFF beam tuning
    There is a strong relation between symmetry and center of field. Therefore it can be extremely practical to compare the profile with a mirrored version of itself in the Processing menu. Note that this can be combined with the measurement options for the Center of Field. There is no clear rule whether or not these should be combined. User discretion and insight is essential here.

    Analysis and used parameters
    There is not yet a general agreement on criteria for FFF beams. For QA comparing with a reference profile and evaluating the relative flatness, the core feature of Bistromath, is by far the best choice. For comparing different FFF beams some standard description is needed. The "roof shaped" area can be fitted with straight lines. The length of these lines represent also the calculation range for the slope. The central dome can be modelled with a second order function, in BistroMath called the Top model.
    Both the maximum of the Top model or the intersection of  the slopes can be used to define the center of the field. Alternatively, the top can be used as alignment criterium without choosing this as center definition.
    The slope area is at the outside based on the definition of the In-Field area (for a flattened beam) and at the inner side on the radius of the central dome shape. An extension value [In-Field area extension (cm)] in the Settings tab can push the outer side further outwards or inwards with negative values.
    The gradient is a measure for the FFF shape. The difference in measure can be a measure for the symmetry.
    Thus the average of the (absolute) slope is presented in percent per cm. The symmetry is calculated conventionally. Symmetry correction is done by applying the average of upward and downward slope over the whole profile.
    The definition of relative flatness remains unchanged.
    The related graphical objects can be hidden through the view menu. 




    See also:
     Concepts,
     Results panel,
     User dose level,
     Measurement menu,
     Processing menu,
     Settings Tabl,
     Advanced Settings Tab.




    Presets menu
    presets menu 



    Preset files contain a limited range of settings, mainly the menu options that can be checked/unchecked. There are a lot of meaningful combinations however that can be related to some "task". As tasks can change a new preset can be loaded. Presets can be made and/or changed by the user. Also, as any ini file, they can be changed with any text editor like Notepad.
    The axis swapping options (view menu) and axis sign inversion (measurement menu) are excluded from the presets files when axis remapping is not checked as they are considered as configuration data.
    The presets menu is generated from all available presets files. The current preset in use, if any, is checked.
    Presets can be loaded from the command line.

    Save Preset as...
    This is the only fixed item in this menu. A presets file can be saved with this menu option.

    -------------example--------------
    [AnalyseForm]
    EdgeDetectionCheckBox=1
    IgnoreClipboardItem=0
    MatchingCheckBox=0
    MeasBackgroundCorrItem=0
    MeasBadPenumbraItem=1
    MeasCenterItem=0
    MeasDetectDiagItem=1
    MeasDosecConvItem=0
    MeasGenericToPDDItem=0
    MeasMirrorItem=0
    MeasMirrorToBufferItem=0
    MeasMissingPenumbraItem=1
    MeasNormFlattenedItem=0
    MeasNormOnCenterItem=1
    MeasResampleItem=0
    MeasScaledToSSDItem=0
    MeasSymCorrectItem=0
    MeasUserDoseItem=0
    MeasZeroStepsItem=1
    PDDfitCheckBox=1
    PlotColor=$B1BCD6
    ReferenceAddToItem=1
    ReferenceAlignItem=0
    ReferenceAutoLoadItem=0
    ReferenceCorrectItem=0
    ReferenceDevSpecItem=0
    ReferenceDivideByItem=0
    ReferenceGammaItem=0
    ReferenceNormaliseItem=0
    ReferenceNormFlatItem=0
    ReferenceUnrelatedToItem=0
    UserDoseEdit=55.0
    ViewBufferItem=0
    ViewCalculatedItem=1
    ViewHighResValItem=0
    ViewIndicatorsItem=1
    ViewMeasuredItem=1
    ViewReferenceItem=1
    ViewValuesItem=1
    ViewZoomItem=0

    [Comments]
    file=addition!.ini
    time=31-12-2013 15:49:28


    See also:
     Configuration,
     Advanced settings,
     Data axis conventions,
     Command line parameters.


    Fit Results tab
    fit results tab 


    When the PDD-fit is activated and results are available the Fit Results Tab will become visible. With clicking on a data column of the table, these data are put on the clipboard in a text format that is compatible with a spreadsheet for pasting purposes. Optionally labels are added.

    I1  108.3761077
    mu1  4.128276595
    mu2  -8.462979663
    mu3  23.50478120
    mu4  -22.20914730
    Ib  71.11381785
    mub  249.4882955
    Power mub 1.15
    dmax  1.49

    Note that the number of parameters used is accessible in the Settings tab.
    Both electron and photon fit are scaled to dose maximum. Any other scaling can be applied on the output by the user. For graphical presentation within Bistromath onto the screen the standard scaling strategy is used. The simplified photon model can be used for extrapolation when limited data are available. The latter model is scaled to the full photon fit around the 50% level.

    Also the messages tab gives the actual fit values for the best solution. 
    This information is also added to the OmniPro-v6 .txt, Scanditronix .wtx and PTW .mcc format. An example is given below,

    See also:
     Adaptive Nelder-Mead fit,
     Messages tab,
     Settings tab,
     Measurement menu,
     Options menu.


    Dose Conversion and Background tab
    dose conversion tab 


    In this tab configured Film to Dose settings are selected and can be activated per energy. Also the background offset can be set and activade here per energy. The purpose of this tab is to add flexibility to the configuration files.

    To work with Film to Dose settings:
  • A Film to Dose curve must be defined for tha actual energy.
  • On the tab that energy must be selected.
  • The name of appropriate the film type must be selected.
  • The Dose conversion must be activated (checked) in this tab.
  • The general Measurement menu option OD to Dose conversion must be activated.
    Now Film to dose conversion will be applied for each activated and correctly configured energy.
    The example below shows where this can be found in the configuration file.

    [WellhoferOD2dose]
    X6.00=EDR2|-163.990|611.910|-504.380|343.770|-84.840|1000.000
    X10.00=EDR2|-72.640|197.240|38.760|-45.010|11.200|1000.000
    X18.00=none|0.000|10.000|0.000|0.000|0.000|10.000

    To work with Background subtraction:
  • Add a line in this tab and select the correct energy.
  • Set a background level.
  • Activate Background correction for selected energies
  • The general Measurement menu option Background correction must be activated.


    See also:
     Configuration tab,
     OD to Dose conversion,
     Background correction,
     Measurement menu.


    Configuration tab
    configuration tab 


    The Configuration tab provides access to essential energy dependent settings in the configuration file. These lines are used for the normalisation of Depth Dose curves , Film to Dose conversion and cross-referencing for multiple generic beams.


    Normalisation of Depth Dose curves

    See Depth dose interpretation.
    Section: [WellhoferRefDepths]


    Film to Dose conversion

    See OD to Dose conversion and Measurement menu.
    Section: [WellhoferOD2dose]


    Cross-referencing for multiple generic beams

    See cross-referencing for multiple generic beams and Reference menu.
    This list is only visible if the Reference menu item Reference from Generic Beam List is switched on.
    Section: [WellhoferGenericBeams]
