    -----------------------------------------------

    Sun Nuclear clipboard format
    -----------------------------------------------
    Delivery System U09 
    Energy 10 MV (FFF)
    Scan Type Crossline 
    Depth 5.00 
    Field 21cm x 16cm (Jaws) 
    Wedge Open Field 
    Comments 26x26 cr 

     5.00 cm : ScanId=406 
    -18.075 2.44 
    -17.825 2.56 
    (...)
    17.175 2.97 
    17.425 2.77 
    17.675 2.59 
    17.925 2.45  
    -----------------------------------------------


    hdf ascii (txt)
    This file format is generated by volumeTool. These file can only be read. The first column gives the relative position as a fraction of the scanlength. Coördinates are given in meters. When for some reason the defined track does not coincide with the voxel center, the offset of the pixel center relative to the scan start is given. In the example below the X-value of the center of the first voxel in track coordinates is the track start value {0.0134} + the fraction of the scanlength {-0.000424} * (scanstop-scanstart) {0.2494-0.0134}.
    -----------------------------------------------
    # Track: (0.013400, 0.140700, 5.0000E-4) -> (0.249400, 0.141300, 5.0000E-4)
    # Length: 0.236000
    -0.000423727 365 -0.0001
    4.24E-04 368 1.00E-04
    0.001271177 367 3.00E-04
    (...)
    0.997033916 348 0.235300774
    0.997881368 343 0.235500773
    0.99872882 343 0.235700773
    0.999576273 344 0.235900772
    -----------------------------------------------

    Pips ascii (dat)
    The Pips profile is an export format from the Pips programme. The range of data is from 0 to 255. The data are inverted however, the background being at 255 and all other signals lower. The intrinsic pixel size is unknown and must be added separately.
    -----------------------------------------------
    Type of Cross-Section: row
    Index: 515
    Highest pixel: 254
    At position: 0
    Number of points: 1024
    254
    239
    240
    (... peak has low values)
    253
    253
    253
    -----------------------------------------------

    generic ascii (txt)
    This is an extremely basic file format for fast input and can only be read. The first colum gives the position in cm.
    When configured in the General detection strategy sub menu, positions can be interpreted mm.
    -----------------------------------------------
    -23.04  5.90
    -23.00  6.00
    -22.92  6.20
    (...)
    22.65  6.90
    22.73  6.70
    22.84  6.50
    -----------------------------------------------

    Varian w2CAD (asc)
    This format is used in Varian Eclipse for input of beam data. My documentation on this format is limited. More info is highly appreciated! Multiple profiles in a file is supported. The is no ordering expected data and labels within one measurement. Unknown labels are ignored.
    For fast recognition the label "$STOM" should be within the first 255 bytes. Theoretically the top lines could be used for comments.
    As far as I know there is no field for the lnac name. BistroMath therefore assumes this is set into the comment.
    -----------------------------------------------
    $NUMS 040              not mandatory!
    $STOM                  start of one measurement (indentifier for this file type)
    #
    # Comment:
    # Detector: CC 13 Field
    # Operator:
    #
    %VERSION 02            W2CAD version, not mandatory
    %DATE 20-09-2011       dd-mm-yyyy
    %DETY CHA              CHAmber|DIOde|DIAmond
    %BMTY PHO              PHOtons|(ELEctrons??)
    %FLSZ 030*030          x,y IEC1217 in mm, format "030*030" or "30 * 30"
    %TYPE OPP              OPD(open field pdd)|OPP(profile)|DPR (diagonal)|
                           WDD(wedge pdd)|WDD_SSD80|WDD_SSD120|WDP(prof)|WLP(longitudinal)
    %WDGL xx               wedge name, 2 characters, (wedge angle?), wedge only
    %WDGD L                L (toe to neg X)|R (pos X) wedge direction, wedge only
    %AXIS X                X,Y,Z,D (IEC1217?)
    %PNTS 755
    %STEP 002              in 0.1 mm
    %SSD  1000             SSD in mm
    %DPTH 015              scan depth in mm for profiles only
    <-065.2 +000.0 +015.0 +000.5>  x,y,z (mm), dose (%)
    <-064.9 +000.0 +015.0 +000.5>
    (...)
    <+065.2 +000.0 +015.0 +000.5>
    <+065.4 +000.0 +015.0 +000.5>
    $ENOM                  end of one measurement
    $ENOF                  end of file
    -----------------------------------------------

    Varian Eclipse output (*.txt)
    This format is used in Varian Eclipse as output of the TPS. The format is only specified as "text output". This is not compltely correct however.
    -----------------------------------------------
    Patient Name: Water, Phantom  Actual string is xEFxBBxBF+'Patient Name:'.
    Patient ID: WP001   Patient ID in TPS
    Plan: QA1-6MV    Plan name
    Course: C1    course ID in TPS
    Date: 06 October 2020 11:41:15 AM Might be dependent on local settings.
    Exported by: xxxx

    Start: (-0.42, 4.78, 14.77)  Order is LR / UD / AP
    End:   (-0.42, 4.78, -14.77) Which translates to AB / Beam / TG

     20x20-6MV   free field comments; BistroMath supports this format.
    0.000000 6.259351
    0.020008 6.288248
    (...)
    29.511242 6.251996
    29.531250 6.223303
    -----------------------------------------------

    CMS ascii (no extension)
    This file format is generated by CMS XiO.
    -----------------------------------------------
    00001090  (indentifier for this file type)
    Patient ID: phantom
    Studyset ID: 40x40
    Plan ID: (null)
    Doc: 19220100118.093907.001
    S:  0.00 cm  (S=Inline; T=CrossLine)
    Y:  0.00 cm  (Inline:Y; CrossLine or PDD:X)
    Z: 10.00 cm
    Angle:  0.00 deg. (0.00=Inline or CrossLine; 90.00=PDD)
    Distance (cm) Dose (cGy)
      -20.000     0.000
      -19.900     0.000
      -19.800     0.000
    (...)
       19.800     0.000
       19.900     0.000
       20.000     0.000

    Depth dose curve (XiO) 
    00001090
    Patient ID: phantom
    Studyset ID: 40x40
    Plan ID: (null)
    Doc: 19220100118.093907.001
    T:  0.00 cm
    X:  0.00 cm
    Z: 20.00 cm
    Angle: 90.00 deg.
    Distance (cm) Dose (cGy)
      -30.000   338.000
      -29.800   341.600
    (...)
       -1.600  1491.100
       -1.400  1493.200  (maximum)
       -1.200  1488.100
       -1.000  1469.700
       -0.800  1427.900
       -0.600  1347.300
       -0.400  1212.900
       -0.200  1019.300
        0.000   213.000

    Depth dose curve (Monaco) 
    00001090
    Patient ID: 00000000
    Studyset ID: 00000000
    Plan ID: 0000
    Doc: 0000
    T: 0
    X: 0
    Z: 0
    Angle: 90.00 deg.
    Distance (cm) Dose(cGy)
    0.00 0.00
    0.40 57.25
    0.80 81.79
    1.20 91.72
    1.60 98.14
    2.00 99.52   (maximum)
    (...)
    34.60 23.07
    35.00 0.00

    -----------------------------------------------

    Schuster ascii (txt)
    This file format is generated by the Schuster diode array.
    -----------------------------------------------
    doserate=300
    Profile measured on 04/01/2006 14:15:32 (indentifier for file type)
     with Software BMS 2.202
    Linac: U9
    Photons at 6.0 MeV
    crossplane
    Buildup: 5.0 cm
    doserate=300
    449.1;567.4;(...);550.7   (88 values)
    -----------------------------------------------


    Internal data representation and scan angle
    technical information

    All data are internally represented in an extendend version of the OmniPro v6 format. The axis representations are from G to T, A to B and U to D repectively. Through time date structures were adden when needed. Therefore all file types are converted into this format on read time. For relevant file types like the MCC format separate data objects were written to hold the data in their original format.
    The direction of the data along the axes and/or the axis labels can be swapped by the user. Depending on the choices this might have consequences for `left` and `right` analysis values. As the same conventions are used for reference files this is of no consequence.
    There is a caveat for the scan angle definition. The TA-GB diagonal nowadays is mostly noted as 45° angle with a positive T to G axis. In the OmniPro v6 format the positive direction is from G to T and hence the same diagonal is noted as 135°. This information is inserted in the reference file name and must be user independent. In short: the scan angle is always represented in the OmniPro v6 convention. 



    A test setup has been made with StarCheckMaxi. The data can be found in selftest31_BeamAdjust.mcc.




    Data validation
    technical information

    If you want to help with data validation then please collect the folowing data. Describe the corner defines the negative values for inline and crossline positions.
  • Inline profile with wedge field with toe (high values, thin side) towards G. Specify the collimator angle.
  • Crossline wedge profile with toe of wedge towards A. Also specify the collimator angle. 
  • A pdd.
    To be sure also rotate the tank by 90 degrees and repeat the measurements above after correct setup of the measuring software. Alternatively you might only virtually rotate the tank in the software. Turn the collimator in the same direction with the scans above.

    Send all data to bistromath@kegge13.nl. Thanks a lot.


    Data type identification
    technical information

    Due to the large variation in data types with sometimes multiple varieties the file type recognition is an important issue in BistroMath. The general strategy is to try any known file type until succesful interpretation. When all options fail the last error is displayed in the statusbar while the history can be found in the Messages tab. When a data type is not recognised at all this is concluded at the first line mostly.



    On this page the identification rules used by BistroMath are presented in the applied order.

    IBA binary rfb format (as file from disk only)
    The file must start with a P-type string of the version of the file. The string itself starts with "Version:". The first byte is the length of the string. In all investigated versions this was 14 ($0e). The next two bytes represent the integer type for the number of scangroups and, after a spacing of 6 bytes, the untyped string of 5 characters " CBEAM" should be detected for a valid header.

    0E 56 65 72 73 69 6F 6E 3A 36 2E 36 2E 32 36
        V  e  r  s  i  o  n  :  6  .  6  .  2  6

    01 00   FF FF   01 00 05 00  43 42 65 61 6D
    int(1) $FF$FF   (?  ?  ?  ?)  C  B  E  A  M

    IBA Wellhöfer v6
    The file should start with 'Clinic:'.

    IBA Wellhöfer v7
    The file must start with a 'Measurement time:'.

    IBA Wellhöfer v8 clipboard format
    The file must start with a date and time where both '-' and '/' are acceptable as separator in the date. When all digits are represented with n, the pattern
    'n/nnnn nn:nn:nn' or 'n/nnnn n:nn:nn' should be found to start within the first five characters in the text. The AM/PM format is also supported here.

    Sun Nuclear disk file
    The file must start with 'Tab-Delimited Scan Output'.

    Sun Nuclear clipboard format
    The file must start with 'Delivery System'.

    Sun Nuclear ICPROFILER export format
    The file must start with 'Filename'.

    WMS binary
    The file must start with the binary representation of the file header size (588). The first integer in the header should be 6..

    4C 02     06 00   
    int(588)  int(6)

    WMS ascii
    The file must start with a double quoted file name with the extension '.wda' or '.wtx': '"xxxxxxx.wxx"' or a double quoted date string '"dd-mmm-yy"'.

    RFA ascii
    The file must start with ':SYS'.

    MCC ascii
    The file must start with 'BEGIN_SCAN_DATA'.

    Elekta CMS ascii
    The file must start with '00001090'.

    generic ascii
    The file must contain two colums of data values without any header, interpreted as position and dose.

    Varian W2CAD ascii
    The string '$STOM' must be found somewhere in beginning of the file. BistroMath reads a maximum of 255 bytes to validate this.

    HDF ascii
    The file must start with '# Track:'.

    Pips ascii
    The file must start with 'Type of Cross-Section:'.

    Schuster ascii
    The file must start with 'Profile measured on '.



    Multiple scan text files
    technical information

    By definition binary files are well-structured. The same true for most text based data formats, although there is much more variation. For files that contain one single scan there is no ambiguity.
    For data files with multiple scans there can be distinguished three types:
  • Structured, organised multi-scan files: This class of files is generated by devices with a fixed number of scan lines (2D-arrays). Date are written in as numbered scans with predictable order. This type of files can used as multil-scan reference. The user can page through the scans. The scan with the same scan number will be slected from the reference.
  • Unstructured, organised multiple-scan files: Particularly water phantom software can export a series of measurements as one file with numbered scans with no particular ordering of the data sets. The user can page through the scans. This type of file can also be loaded manually as a reference file. BistroMath will then index such a file and try to select an appropriate reference scan from this file.
  • Multiple single-scan data sets gathered in one file: This type of file is generated by the IBA OmniPro software for the clipboard when multiple scans are selected. Where normally BistroMath would just consider a file as completely processed when all data points are read, there is an extra option in the file menu to search for more data. When found these will be processed. This is a forward, continuous procedure. Therefore this is only meaningful if there is a history list and/or SpecialMode (#2 or #3) processing. With a history list the indivdual scans can be viewed. When the number of scans is larger then the history list, previous scans will be overwritten. If none of both conditions is met this option is disabled. This file will be handled as single scan file, with scan count equal to one, where just the starting point for reading is moved to the appropriate line. Manual paging is supported.


    Special modes
    general information 

    Mainly as specific expansions on standard applications, "speical modes" are available. The number of configurable parameters will be expanded as needed in new versions. To start BistroMath with a specific mode add one or more "-SpecialMode{number}" strings to the command line by changing the shortcut:

    C:\Program Files\BistroMath\bistromath.exe -SpecialMode1

    These modes are also available in the Processing menu, but only visible in Advanced mode and can be stored in a configuration file.

    Further behavior of a special mode must be set in a configuration file, like bistromath.ini or institute.ini (noted below in blue). Note also that configuration file overloading is a solid method to combine SpecialMode settings with a reliable basic setup. To create such a file use a plain text editor like NotePad and save the file with a '.ini' extension. 

    Starting with version 3.23 the SpecialMode-strings as decribed below can be placed into a separate [SpecialModes] section. The section reading order is [AnalyseForm], [SpecialModes]. On writing a config file the data as found in the [SpecialModes] section will be written back into the file. Strings in the [AnalyseForm] section are lost. Also strings commented out will be lost. Advised is to preserve settings into a separate file with only a [SpecialModes] section; a combined ini-file is more convenient however.


    Special Mode 1
    This mode can load any measurement at startup. There is one mandatory string parameter, the file to load:
    [AnalyseForm] (or [SpecialModes])
    SpecialMode[1]String[1]=C:\Program Files\Bistromath\U04X10i40.txt


    Special Mode 2
    Special mode 2 displays extra information on the statusbar, to the clipboard, and also writes it to the data window which is saved to a file.


    There are four mandatory strings for respectively: 
  • profiles [1], 
  • wedge profiles [2], with float[2] for wedge detection as lower limit for the symmetry of a wedge field
  • FFF profiles [3],
  • depth dose curves [4]. 

    And optional parameters:
  • Float 1 positive values are rounded to the nearest integer number of decimals to display the results.
  • Float 3 positive values put the resulting line on the clipboard.
  • Float 5 positive values start the export scheme as explained below.
  • String 5 is the path name to a directory or a file. When the path is an existing directory this path is used to write the measurement, otherwise the file is used to add the data as described above.
  • If set, string 6 holds the extension (and therefore file type) of the measurement file. The measurement will be stored on the configured path with the set extension.
  • If set, float 6 selects the curve to be exported:
      0=Measured, 1=Reference, 2=MeasFiltered, 3=RefFiltered, 4=Calculated, 5=Buffer, 6=RefOrg, 7=Unrelated, 8=Default

    Each string consists of code expressions, separated by ",". Parts within brackets are [optional].

    [-|+]{parameter}[curve selector] [ [-|+]{value} ] [ {operator} [-|+]{parameter}[curve selector] [[-|+]{value}] ]

    parameters: 
    Supported parameters can be found in the Evaluation Type section.
  • For the evaluation "u" which calls for the border postiton at users value, there is an added bonus: it be extended with any numeric value like "unn" where nn will be replaced with the used dose level.
    curve selector:
    The curve selector is optional: F (dsMeasured, default), M (dsMeasured), C (dsCalculated), R (deReference), B (dsBuffer).
    Moreover, the curve selector might be overruled when muptiple curves are involved in the calculation.
    operator:
    Valid operators are, -, + , *, / and & for average.
    value:
    The result for a value results in the average for left and right when no sign is found.
    A minus sign (-{value}) and plus sign construct (+{value}) evaluate to left and right results respectively.

    Examples
     "xR+{position}" gives the value of the curve at +{position} on the Reference curve. 
     "y{value}" gives the average of left and right positions at {value} for profiles and right position for pdd's. 
    The construct "y{value1}-y{value2}" is supported and will produce the average of the (absolute) distances at left and right side when no sign is given. For non-wedge profiles "x{position}" gives the average for symmetrical positions around the center position.
    Small wedged fields without indication of that state might fail to be detected as such. Therefore a threshold value (Float[2]) may be introduced for the symmetry. When the actual symmetry is above this level, a open field will be handled as wedge field. Note that meaningful values are in the range of 1.0 to 1.5. Values smaller than 1 will ignore this threshold.

    Examples:
    When left and right y90 values are -8 and +9 respectively and y50 values -9 and +11 for a electron profile then
     y90       =  8.5
     D90       =  8.5
     y-90      = -8.0
     y+90      =  9.0
     y-50+y+50 = 20.0
     y90-y50   =  1.5
     p         =  1.5
     y-90-y-50 =  1.0
     p-1       =  1.0
     y+90-y+50 =  2.0
     i         =  0.5
     i-1       = -8

    Likewise x5 will produce the average y at x=-5 and x=+5 for open field profiles wher x-5 and x+5 will return only the value at the denoted position.
    When activated, PDD-fit parameters are also written to the data window.
     

    [AnalyseForm]
    ;number of decimals
    SpecialMode[2]Float[1]=4
    ;profiles, non-wedged
    SpecialMode[2]String[1]=b,c,-b,+b,-i,+i,d,f,s,L,a,w,-p,+p
    ;wedge detection symmetry value
    SpecialMode[2]Float[2]=1.1
    ;wedged profiles
    SpecialMode[2]String[2]=b,c,-b,+b,-E,+E,d,w,
    ;FFF
    SpecialMode[2]String[3]=a,x0,-i,+i,i,T
    ;PDD
    SpecialMode[2]String[4]=M,m,P20/10,P10,D80,D50
    SpecialMode[2]String[5]=c:\temp\results.txt
    ;put result on clipboard
    SpecialMode[2]Float[5]=1
    ;SpecialMode[2]Float[6]=0
    ;SpecialMode[2]String[6]=*.wtx

    Note: files with multiple scans may be looped automatically after opening by using <Ctrl-PageDown>.

    Example in messages:
    stored: c:\temp\selftestx6c40_ssd100_d050m.wtx (Filtered)


    Special Mode 3
    Special mode 3 clears the editor window, puts a set of filtered data points in this window and saves the resulting file to a predefined file name. Also, the measurement curve is saved with a predefined name in the directory defined by String[1]. The data format is taken from the last saved profile or configuration (see [FileSaveDialog]DefaultExt, with legal values of .txt, .asc, .mcc, .wda, .wtx), whichever is most recent. It can also be set with String[2] at startup, but the last chosen output format after startup of BistroMath is leading. For profiles the range of points is chosen as the In-Field area, rounded up to the step size. Depth dose curves start at 1 cm. The stepsize is defined by Float[2]. The data source to write to file is set with Float[3].
    Float[1]: the filter width in cm. A value of zero or lower will use the default value defined in the configuration.
    Float[2]: the step size in cm
    Float[3]: 0=write original measured data, 1=write filtered version of measurement.
    Float[4]: 1=write resampled data in editor to text file.
    Float[5]: AutoCenter: 0=menu setting, 1=always AutoCenter, 2=no AutoCenter
    String[1]: the destination directory for output.
    String[2]: the output file type as defined by the extension: *.wtx / *.wda / *.asc / *.txt / *.mcc.

    [AnalyseForm]
    SpecialMode[3]Float[1]=0.0
    SpecialMode[3]Float[2]=0.5
    SpecialMode[3]Float[3]=0
    SpecialMode[3]String[1]=c:\temp
    SpecialMode[3]String[2]=*.wtx

    When activated, PDD-fit parameters are also written into the saved file for selected formats.
    Note that multi-file formats are supported. Going to the next/previous scan with <PageUp>/<PageDown> will execute the SpecialMode3 routine for that scan.

    Note: files with multiple scans may be looped automatically after opening by using <Ctrl-PageDown>.

    Special Mode 4
    This mode starts the selftest.


    See also:
     Configuration
     Ignore clipboard
     Evaluation Types


    Installation and configuration issues
    general information 

    Application
    Although BistroMath can be used as a stand-alone analysis tool it is intended as extension to water phantom systems in radiotherapy and therefore should agree with viewing conventions in the water phantom system. As BistroMath has many features this might become confusing when different users use one or more installations of the software over one or more Windows platforms. Mostly an institute wide default behavior on all installtions for all users might be preferred. This page tries to address all aspects of installation and configuration.


    Decimal separator

    BistroMath reads most data in text formats. Virtually all scanning software applies a "." (period) as decimal separator. Therefore BistroMath conforms to this standard. This should be set in the regional settings of Windows. BistroMath checks for the correct separator and will not continue otherwise. Also the installation program reviews this setting.


    Configuration file consistency
    The installation program can convert all old parameters to the new standards in all configuration and preset files in the data directory. This feature can also be run without installing Bistromath on any other directory. Just run the installation file, select the data directory and deselect installation of BistroMath.






    Setup on different Windows platforms
    Starting with version 2.50 the datastructure is reorganised to conform with Windows standards. The setup program will adjust this automatically.

    Windows XP
    executable C:\Program Files\BistroMath
    selftest data C:\Program Files\BistroMath
    data  C:\Documents and Settings\All Users\ApplicationData\BistroMath
    institute.ini C:\Documents and Settings\All Users\ApplicationData\BistroMath
    bistromath.ini C:\Documents and Settings\All Users\ApplicationData\BistroMath
    references C:\Documents and Settings\All Users\ApplicationData\BistroMath\References

    Windows Vista and later
    executable C:\Program Files\BistroMath
    selftest data C:\Program Files\BistroMath
    data  C:\ProgramData\BistroMath
    institute.ini C:\ProgramData\BistroMath
    bistromath.ini C:\ProgramData\BistroMath
    references C:\ProgramData\BistroMath\References

    Installation on network
    The installation onto a network drive should be done manually.
    executable any path
    selftest data same path as executable
    institute.ini same path as executable
    bistromath.ini same path as executable as default
    data  any path
    references any path configured in ini file or on command line

    Startup logistics
    At startup Bistromath will look for institute.ini in the standard datapath. If not found bistromath.ini will be used. On a default installation Bistromath will start correct without any configuration file. Of course, settings will not be as expected.
    Alternative configurations can be used on the command line: bistromath.exe -config path_to_ini_file.
    The user can load bistromath.ini after program start. See Institute defaults configuration for more details.
    The philosophy behind this behavior is to archive a uniform analysis outcome for all users on all platforms without losing the opportunity to store specific user settings. When a configuration file is opened, a line is written to the messages tab. Additional, a preset can be loaded to support a dedicated task.


    Lost information without any configuration file
    Depth dose curves might not be scaled as expected.

    Command line
    The command line offers opportunities to use alternative configurations. See command line parameters for details.

    Interpetation of Depth dose curves
    Both analysis values as graphical representation are highly configurable and most problably should be set to institute wide preferences. See Depth dose interpretation for details.

    Various settings

    The most settings are described in the Settings tab.

    Graph view configuration: axis swapping

    For most users it is prefered that the graph view matches with the profiles as seen in the watertank software. Notably the GT-axis is handled inconsitent by different vendors or even different versions of one vendor. Therefore BistroMath offers Axis swapping.


    See also:
     Data axis conventions
     Depth dose interpretation
     Configuration
     Settings Tab
     Command line parameters
     Institute wide defaults


    Quick Start guide
    general information 

    This guide tries to describe different application scenarios and is work in progress. All comments are highly welcomed.

    Before you start
    In most cases Bistromath will be used in combination with some scanning software. It is advised to configure the presentation of profiles (orientation and sign) on the screen such that it corresponds with the representation of the scanning software. Notably for inplane profiles there is a large variation between vendors. There are also choices to make how depth doses should be normalised for calculations and presentation relative differences with a reference curve. As default Bistromath calculates a division of measurement and reference profile. But this might also be a gamma analysis.
    If the the choices above are based on an institution wide policy, they should be stored in the locked file institute.ini.

    Adjusting beams
    Although absolute criteria are certainly important, the essential feature of BistroMath is the detailed comparison with some reference situation. Bistromath offers you both in one go. 
    The process starts with choosing a reference scan. Open this file and store it as temporary reference. If the reference is of another machine you should ignore this to make the reference acceptable. Now each measurement of the same type, depth and field size will be readily compared with the reference.

    QA of linacs
    In the opinion of the author of Bistromath QA-measurements should always be compared with a predefined reference. Also this is the unique feature, not offered by any major vendor. See the reference overview topic for all details.

    Save as reference
    This option is locked at startup.


    Config file documentation

    To be completed
    key value type scale Explanation Interface

    Wish list
    general information 

    Future developments are dependent of user proposals. Give me a challenge...

    Things that might appear in coming releases:
  • configurable applicator source distance default
  • XML-input/uitput
  • x/y/z/dose raw data lines

    See also:
     Update policy


    Known limitations
    general information 

    18/09/2020
    Graphic window zoom does not respond keyboard beyond initial zoom value
    When using <arrow-down> in zoomed state repeatedly the graphics will not respond beyond the initial minimal zoom range.
    It is adviced to configure the ZoomRange with a maximum of 1.04.
    There are two work-arounds:
  • Use the mouse to draw a rectangle from uppr-left to lower-right of intended range.
  • Use <Z> twice.



    See also:
     Update policy


    Update policy
    general information 

    The development strategy for Bistromath is based on small changes with extensive testing on location and are driven by local needs, my personal interests and user requests from other institutes. This leads to a high update frequency but reduces the risk of major design errors staying undetected for a while.

    See also:
     Wish list


    Configuration files
    general information 

    In the configuration topic a complete overview is given.
    A limited number of configurable settings can be accessed through the configuration tab:

    The most essential configuration for daily use is the reference depth and value for photon beams.
    The reference depth is used to normalise depth dose scans. Thus all displayed analysis values are based on this normalisation  ("AbsDepth/AbsValue"). The graphical display of the depth dose curve has its own normalisation ("RelDepth/RelValue"). When combined with a reference file calculated division will be normalised at the same depth. Although the shape of the division will not change drastically the found minimum and maximum will be different. When using generic beams or reference dosimetry at a specific depth this might be the optimal setup.
    When the dosimetrical system is based on a depth beyond dose maximum, all depth dose curves should be evaluated realative to this reference point. The text "PDD" is then changed to "RDD".

    Starting with version 4.25 multiple normalisation lines with the same modality can be configured. The interpretation is explained on the Depth dose interpretation page. Here only the consequences for the configuration files are mentioned. The user interface to these lines is the Configuration Tab.
    BistroMath can read multiple lines with an identical modality (see 'legal alternatives' below) but the ini-file mechanism does not allow to write identical entries. Therefore some two-digit number and an underscore ("01_") are added to to the modality. These are dropped on read time when the lines are interpreted. For manual adjustments this number is not needed.
    The file types (second to last column) is a single string wih all needed  types. The dashes are just there for readabilty. The interpretation searches case-insensitve for a match of the available types ('Standard','FFF','Small','MRlinac','Wedge','Electrons'). The result is binary stored in memory.
    The linac list (last column) is one contiguous string of needed linac names. The characters ",", ";", "=" and "|" are not allowed. Any other character may or may not added to separate the names. At application time a search for case insensitive match of the linac name is done on this list.
    [WellhoferRefDepths]
    ;new format starting with v4.25
    01_X6.00=10.000|100.000|1.600|100.000|Standard-Wedge|
    02_X6.00=1.600|100.000|1.600|100.000||selftest
    X18.00=10.000|100.000|10.100|100.000
    X10.00=10.000|100.000|2.000|100.000
    X7.00=0|100.000|0|100.000|MRlinac
    ;legal alternatives for new format starting with v4.25
    X6.00=10.000|100.000|1.600|100.000||
    X6.00=1.600|100.000|1.600|100.000||selftest
    ;old format
    E6.00=1.320|100.000|1.320|100.000
    E8.00=1.800|100.000|1.800|100.000
    E10.00=2.270|100.000|2.270|100.000
    E12.00=2.710|100.000|2.710|100.000
    E15.00=3.460|100.000|3.460|100.000


    These values are joined with Dose Conversion parameters. Because there can be different film types this may lead to multiple dose depth definitions for one energy. Starting with version 2.00 all definitions for one energy are kept uniform.



    Settings without application interface

    BistroMath maintains a configuration file, bistromath.ini / institute.ini, which stores all settings from menu's and windows.
    Also some extra data are read from this file.

    The ZoomRange sets the scaling for zooming on profiles; a value of 1.03 will show the range from 97% to 103%.
    See Special modes for information on the SpecialMode items.

    [AnalyseForm]
    ZoomRange=1.03
    BadPenumbra=3
    ;the minimum size of data on the clipboard to be accepted as potential legal file format
    MinClipBoardBytes=100
    ;parameters for the Nelder-Mead optimisation engine
    ;the ENR lower limit for global fit restart as discussed above 
    ENR=2.0
    ;maximum calculation time per start
    NMsec=2.0
    ;maximum number of restarts
    NMrestarts=6
    ;number of significant digits in output
    NMdigits=8
    ;maximum number of cycles,
    NMcycles=0


    The directory for the reference files (RefDir) may be moved. The filterwidth (Filter) is given in cm. The default oriëntation of the watertank is given in the I(inplane)C(rossline)D(epth) item. The number of  points to calculate a dose in any curve using a second order fit (Dpt) can be increased above the minimum of 3.

    [WellhoferObject]
    RefDir=C:\ProgramData\BistroMath\references\
    Filter=0.60
    D20=0.200
    D50=0.500
    D80=0.800
    D90=0.900
    ICD=-YX-Z
    Dpt=3
    multiscan_nr=0
    multiscan_max=0
    ;the Derive function searches for the highest peak and the lowest valley, based on statistical analysis
    DeriveMinMax         :twFloatType= 0.9;  {allowed maximum value in first and last point for statistical analysis}
    DeriveBinFraction    :twFloatType= 0.25; {maximum of largest bin}
    DeriveLookAhead      :Integer    = 3;    {number of points to look ahead to decide on crossing bandlow and bandhigh} 
    ;parameters for Nelder-Mead fit
    ENR=2.0
    NMsec=2.0
    NMrestarts=6
    NMdigits=8
    NMcycles=0
    multiscan_list=STARCHECKMAXI


    See also:
     Configuration,
     Save as Reference,
     Filter width,
     Ignore Clipboard,
     Institute defaults configuration,
     Command line options,
     Interpretation of depth doses,
     Presets,
     Aliases.



    BistroMath v4 port to Open Source application in Lazarus/FreePascal
    general information 



    Up to v3.30 BistroMath was developed in Borland Delphi v7.2. Although that platform is old, it was convenient for this application.
    But it has become challenging to install it on Windows 7 and above. For the sake of the future of the concepts embedded in this application it was decided to leave Delphi with some sadness and port it to an open source environment.


     
    Lazarus is a Integrated Development Environment (IDE) with a large visual components library (LCL) and uses the Free Pascal Compiler (FPC). The latter was initiated as an open source alternative to the highly popular Borland Delpi Pascal visual component library (VCL) and compiler. Both Lazarus LCL and FPC offer a high compatibility with Borland Delphi. This reduced the amount of work drastically. Borland added the Steema TeeChart library for charting. In Lazarus this is offered through TAChart  which originates from the TeleAuto project. The differences between those are significant. Therefore the user interface itself needs to be rewritten, but a lot of code can still be reused. Moreover, large portions of the user interface have been copied/pasted from Delphi to Lazarus, which reduced the work also.
    During development Lcl 2.0.6/FPC 3.0.2, Lcl 2.0.8/FPC3.0.4, Lcl 2.0.10/FPC 3.2.0 and LcL 2.0.12/FPC 3.2.0 were used. Upgrades introduced no problems but some deprecated functions had to be replaced.

    Therefore:

     

     Le roi est mort, vive le roi !


    See also:
     Known limitations


    Upgrading from version 3.xx to 4.xx
    general information 

    Significant changes in configuration files
    With the port to the Lazarus/FreePascal platform all code has been reviewed. Large portions of the the user interface were reorganised and/or rebuild. Consequently visual elements were renamed or replaced with other structures. As configuration files use the name of the visual elements for storage, old configuration files, including presets, are not completely reliable. For renamed elements this is corrected automatically with the installed repair file BMnnn_renamed_elements.ini, were nnn is the build number. 

    After upgrading
    During installation there is the option to repair all configuration files. When this option is used the repair file (see above) can be removed.
    If the repair file is found by BistroMath this file will be applied on the in-memory version of loaded configuration files when needed; nothing will be written to disk.
    In all cases the user should check that all settings are as expected.

    Manually rewriting all configuration files
    When all configuration files are openend, checked for their result on all settings and rewritten, these files will be free from redundant data. Rewriting the institute defaults file must be unlocked.


    History v1.00 - v1.99
    general information 

    version 1.99 25/01/2011
    This version is a precursor of version 2.00 with a full selftest feature.
    In this version only bugs are repaired which have been around for a indefinite time but stayed undetected due to their specific nature in hardly used features.
    -parsing of floating point text-strings,
    -unresponsiveness of "Accept zero steps" menu item when the same data were read,
    -improved interpolation techniques for sparse data files,
    -handling perfect vertical slopes en perfect horizontal profiles, see calculation details.
    The usage of the OD to dose conversion parameters has been changed.

    version 1.98 17/01/2011
    Minor bug repair: the normalisation stategy in version 1.97 introduced a graphics-only inconsistent normalisation of reference profiles.
    As default name for the "File save" menu is now made from measurement parameters and measurement time.
    Resolved bug: due to a bug in a library the extension of files was not set as expected.
    Dutch/English translation mixup corrected.

    version 1.97 06/12/2010
    An optional dual normalisation of depth dose curves is introduced to separate analysis and graphical representation. It is backward compatible with configuration files of previous versions.

    version 1.96 29/10/2010
    normalisation of depth dose curves can now be done at a specific depth and normalisation value. See configuration for details.
    It is made backward compatible with configuration files of previous versions.
    The Alias tab now has a pop-up menu.

    version 1.95 13/09/2010
    A faster memory management utility with memory leak detection is introduced. No leaks were found.
    Resampling of data to a fixed grid is now supported. See Settings tab.
    The majority of the menu items which can be (un)checked now report their status in the message bar.
    The naming convention for reference files has been changed. The previous naming convention is still supported for backward compatibility.

    version 1.94 19/03/2010
    For SpecialMode2 the construct {constant}*x|y{[-|+]value} is supported.
    Also wedge information added. See SpecialModes.

    version 1.93 09/03/2010
    SpecialMode2 capabilities expanded: now for any y value the (right side only for pdd) x position is evaluated. In previous versions this was limited to 20, 50, 80, 90 en dUser.
    Small speed optimizations were introduced.
    Minor viewing bug repair: For pdd's the bottom axis minimum value sometimes was not reset when before a profile was displayed. To get a full window version again the unzoom or zoom command could be used. Now the bottomacxis is always set to the obeserved minimum and maximum position values.

    version 1.92 01/03/2010
    For noisy profiles with a low resolution the search strategy from center to outside for the penumbra values might end at the wrong calculation point because of the low slope in the beginning. Therefore now the search strategy is inverted: from outside to inside, which maximises the slope. Moreover a fallback to a linear fit is used when a quadratic fit might give extreme results. The number of  points to calculate a dose in any curve using a second order fit is now configurable.
    Small speed optimizations were introduced.

    version 1.91 11/02/2010
    The Wellhöfer scantype "Angle", used for diagonal profiles, is supported. However, when tested there where files found with missing axis definitions for the water tank. Therefore an extra entry is made in the [WellhoferObject] section of the ini-file to have default values: ICD=-YX-Z.
    More information is written to the status bar.
    Bug repair: due to changes in a base library the SpecialMode2 strings could not be handled.
    The relative flatness is no longer displayed witin brackets but as a second value after a "/".
    The error tolerance for inconsistent data is improved.

    version 1.90 01/02/2010
    Files produced by CMS XiO are now supported. 
    In SpecialMode3 the scan depth of a profile is inserted into the file name.
    The upper and lower level definitions for both photons and electrons can now be adjusted in the settings tab as a percentage with a arbitrary value. In previous versions these values could only be changed in the configuration file. where they were stored as percentage. As (undescribed) design limitation these values were exclusively limited to the set values for d90, d80, d50 and d20. In this version these values are stored as fractions, but for backward compatibility values higher than 1 are interpereted as percentage.
    For reference profiles the scan depth is now included in the file name to accommodate a wider range of references. When a file exists with the old name and no new one, the old file is renamed automatically.

    version 1.80 07/12/2009
    In SpecialMode2 the scan depth of a profile and both x- and y-size are given.
    A temporary reference is only used for curves of the same scan type.

    version 1.79 11/11/2009
    The concepts of SpecialMode2 are changed.
    Bug repairs:
     In SpecialMode2 string#2 in stead of string#3 was used for pdd's.
     With the "File/Save as" menu item data were always written as Wellhöfer ascii.

    version 1.78 29/07/2009
    An earlier revision of the shift-function introduced a bug.

    version 1.77 23/06/2009
    Now a derivative is calculated tot determine the field limits of a wedge field and therefore the effective field. 

    version 1.76 01/03/2009
    In one installation the penumbra-settings were not correctly deduced from the configuration file. Decent values are forced here.

    version 1.75 26/01/2009
    "SpecialMode"-options are introduced. See the Special modes section.

    version 1.74 03/11/2008
    Minor bug: after swichting back from Settings tab to Analysis tab, the profile was reread with all menu's still in a blocked state. Therefore the current profile was not divided again by the reference profile. Now the menu's are enabled in due time.

    version 1.73 04/04/2008
    Bistromath does not accept scans with a zero step. Now this can be overruled with a menu item.

    version 1.72 26/03/2008
    Bug repair for version 1.7: when the missing penumbra option was switched on the analysis of electron depth dose curves went wrong. This option is now ignored for depth dose curves.
    Minor bug repair for all previous versions: for non-wellhöfer data the filename of the imported file was not transfered.
    Display issue: the plotscaling for the measured curve was also used to scale the filtered curve. This guarantees an optimal aligment of both plots. However, the normalisation point in the graph may be slightly different from the actual value. Therefore, now the filtered curve is scaled with the normalisation point.
    Now extra information may by put on the clipboard (see configuration). This was made to produce data for the beam check.

    version 1.71 12/03/2008
    Bug repairs in the conversion tab:
    -the output type selection was messed up
    -the filepath edits did not respond to keys used as shortcut in the View menu.
    Also the result reporting in the conversion tab is extended.

    version 1.7 03/03/2008
    The analysis is revised to support diagonal profiles and profiles with missing penumbra's. This is now also handled correctly for reference files.

    version 1.61 26/02/2008
    Support for Schuster profiles is added.
    For stability more error-handling was added.
    Bug repair: symmetry values were calculated before an optional symmetry correction was done.

    version 1.60 15/02/2008
    A histogram page is added.
    The minimum in the In-Field area is displayed when applicable.

    version 1.5.10 07/02/2008
    Bugs repaired:
    -due to duplication of variable names the file name was not transferred in the file conversion tab (occurred only in version 1.59)
    -a binairy file could not be selected as reference
    -export to wms: mixup in coördinates
    -export from wms to wellhöfer format
    With the introduction of a temporary reference it is possible to use references of other linacs. As in the current concept the reference is added tot the measurement data, a lot of information is shared, which possibly no longer is identical. For now this is repaired partially. In the next major version each curve will have its own information data.
    Improvements:
    -profiles are filtered before division now,
    -the information on parsing errors is more accurate.
    Added functionality:
    -all profiles can be erased with the View/Clear menu item,
    -normalisation ont the field centre can now be enforced.

    version 1.59 28/01/2008
    Now a measurement can be used as temporary reference.

    version 1.58 30/11/2007
    Every curve has now its own position information. This leads to an improved positional accuracy when two curves are divided.
    A curve can be selected, which, in this version, has only visual effects.

    version 1.57 22/11/2007
    Wellhöferformat-fix: support for 'Point To Point scans'.
    Bug-fix in Filesave-dialog: the filename of the input was actually used. 

    version 1.56 01/11/2007
    Generic-format-fix: read error on two columns.

    version 1.55 25/10/2007
    WDA-format-fix: wda-files produced by recent Plato versions seem to produce a slightly different header. This is also accepted now.

    version 1.54 18/10/2007
    Position analysis at user dose levels can be toggled on/off.
    The help file is extended.
    When the mouse is clicked in the graph window, the cursor is moved to that position.
    Bugfix: the vertical alignment of measurement and reference profiles could go wrong due to wrong normalisation values.

    version 1.51 09/10/2007
    Position analysis at user dose levels is introduced.

    version 1.50 09/09/2007
    OD to dose conversion is added.

    version 1.41 03/09/2007
    Support for Pips profiles was added.
    The Editor window is set to Plain Text and no Word wrap explicitely before every read action.

    version 1.40 31/08/2007
    Support for generic profiles and hdf profiles was added. For selected file types a background may be subtracted.
    The configuration will only be rewriiten at program exit if an autosave option is set.
    Several minor bugs were repaired.
    The clipboard may be ignored through a new item in the File menu.

    version 1.35 10/12/2006
    The depth of dose maximum is given for pdd-curves.

    version 1.34 27/11/2006
    Minor bug: when a file is read from the references directory it cannot be saved. An appropriate message is produced.

    version 1.33 22/11/2006
    More efficient use of resources.
    Overwite file checkbox for file conversion.
    Added "Extra" curve for a new facility in future.

    version 1.32 14/11/2006
    Introduction of file name generation.
    Bug repaired in language library load procedure. Possible source of strange errors at startup in previous versions.

    version 1.31 13/11/2006
    Addition of "force lower case names" on conversion page.
    Addition of "Maximum within flatttened area" for profiles on analysis page.

    version 1.30 06/11/2006
    Introduction of a multi-tabbed layout.
    The wms-formats (*.wtx and *.wda) are supported in this version for import and export. On a separate page groups of files can be converted. Aliases are introduced. 

    version 1.22 16/08/2006
    Minor bug fix.

    version 1.21 12/07/2006
    The filter width can be accessed with a menu option.

    version 1.20 05/05/2006
    Bug fix: the penumbra-high value was read from the low value, therefore the "20-20" value was calculated (correctly) as zero.

    version 1.19 18/03/2006
    The penumbra definition is now split up in a electron value (default 90-50) and a photon value (default 80-20). Both have there own entry in the ini file and  will be used when appropriate.

    version 1.18 18/03/2006
    Bottom axis title in larger and bold format.

    version 1.17 08/03/2006
    For Measurement and Reference file, also the name of registrered linac is displayed.

    version 1.16 28/02/2006
    Bug repair: When there was no information on the reference directory, there was an incorrect default.

    version 1.15 02/02/2006
    Bug repair: An error in the reading of the filter value could lead to zero output of the filter.

    version 1.14 22/12/2005
    Film-scanner files are now supported.
    The filter width is made available within the program.

    version 1.13 19/12/2005
    For very narrow profiles the display-normalisation is improved.

    version 1.12 18/12/2005
    The BadPenumbra-limit is added to the configuration file. A menu item "Accept bad penumbra's"is added.

    version 1.11 14/12/2005
    The internal notation of the energy is changed to a floating type to accomodate kV-range energies. When the energy value (in MV) is less then 1, this value is presented as kilovolts.

    version 1.10 02/12/2005
    The color scheme is changed to a white background of the graph.
    The value of any position in the curve can be displayed (values are interpolated as needed).
    Profiles may be centered to make the 50%-point symmetric.
    Profiles can be scaled to the surface-distance.
    The total width of profiles is given.

    See also:
     Configuration
     Recent History
     History v2.00 - v2.69
     History v2.70 - v1.98



    History v2.00 - v2.69
    general information 

    version 2.69 17/08/2014
  • Improvements on the generic profile to PDD option for completely untyped two-column data. For the related FreeScans, typed data not representing any standard scan like Inline/Crossline/Depth dose/Fanline/Diagonal, this was fully covered already.
  • In the Fit Results tab, unchecking the Include labels box now also leaves out the name of the fit.
  • Minor bug: in the Files tab not the full path name was passed, failing to open a selected file. Also unrelated information from the Editor window was used.
  • Minor bug: in the Files tab an incorrect scantype could be set. As solution the axis (re)mapping (Alternative axis setup) is set explicitely in this tab.

    version 2.68 31/07/2014
  • Measurement comments can now be displayed optionally in the axis title.
  • The minimum zoom range has been changed from 1.01 to 1.011. This forces the 101% and 99% level always to be visible on the vertical axis.
  • For unzoomed views the <arrow-up>/<arrow-down> now work on the right axis.
  • Further improvements on unintentional file locking for writing files.
  • For supported arrays (at this moment only the StarCheck Maxi) the temporary reference can also be a multi-scan file. 
  • Bugfix: With some combinations of configured preferences hotkeys in the Reference menu got lost at startup.

    version 2.67 18/07/2014
  • Bugfix: In the penumbra evaluation engine valid results were not recalculated when the normalisation value changed. The effect is only significant when the normalisation value differs significantly from the maximum value or initial normalisation value. This might be the case with double-wedge profiles where the 50% width is critical, the slopes are less steep, and a higher maximum at (possible) lobes is not used for normalisation. Also, do not forget to switch off Edge Detection fallback as for these profiles the steepest slope position might significantly differ from the 50% postion.
  • Bugfix: For MCC files correct interpretation of the positions for diagonal scans would sometimes fail, leading to a zero scan length.
  • MCC files tend to represent absolute dose values in stead of relative dose values, thus leading to very small numbers (several orders of magnitude below 1). This messed up assumptions that can be made for relative profiles. Therefore, at conversion to the internal used data format, dose values are scaled to 100 when the maximu is below 50.
  • The annotations c,e and nn, where nn is a number, are added to positional results for profile centering, edge detection and user dose level respectively. See also the results panel.
  • The annotation (s) is introduced for symmetry and flatness when the measurement is symmetry corrected.

    version 2.66 12/06/2014
    The fit models for depth dose curves use more parameters now but can be limited to the original models also. The related documentation is expanded significantly.

    version 2.65 11/06/2014
  • Bugfix: True diagonal scans that were stored as reference became 'point-to-point' scans and were not recognised anymore as diagonal. This is repaired by saving these files as 'angle' scan. Also the detection diagonal scans is extended to overcome poor registration anyway.
  • The option [View]Bottom axis always black now also keeps the bottom axis label black;
  • The option [File]Load current data, which is equivalent to tab changing, now handles the OmniPro v6 binary (*.rfb) correctly. In previous versions only the editor was reread, which effectively disconnected the binary file.
  • The file locking problem (see v. 2.63) is now avoided by using alternative mechanisms for writing.
  • A Fit Results Tab is added to export pdd-fit results in a for spreadsheet acceptable format.

    version 2.64 05/06/2014
  • Bugfix: partially scanned profiles with very limited information (typically aborted scans, "garbage") could lead to calculation errors in the matching module and left the program in a locked state.

    version 2.63 27/05/2014
  • The temporary file is now written with a unique file name. On closing BistroMath will (try to) delete this file. This avoids multi user conflicts and possible file locking on a network drive.
  • The Linac Symmetry Error is only calculated for fields with left and right border values of opposite sign.

    version 2.62 20/05/2014
  • For extrapolation of photon data a second photon fit model is added to fit the data beyond d50. An overview of the results shows that the photon extrapolation model performs much better beyond the available data range.
  • When the coloured name/date label in the Results panel is clicked, this will select the correspondig curve in the graph area will be selected.
  • Support for the help in the 32-bit ".hlp" format is dropped. This was the standard on Windows XP but Bistromath could also work with htmlhelp on that platform. Now only the htmlhelp ".chm" format is available.
  • Bugfix: with a default installation on startup the path C:\ProgramData\BistroMath\References (or C:\Documents and Settings\All Users\Application Data\BistroMath\References) was not found due to a missing backslash in the path. Without explicit reference path in the configuration file this would lead to the conclusion that the reference directory is in the program directory. However other choices are made during installation. Please check your configuration file to include RefDir=C:\ProgramData\BistroMath\references\ in the [AnalyseForm] section. If there is no file with the name bistromath.ini or institute.ini in the directory C:\ProgramData\BistroMath then make one by saving a configuration.
  • In the selftest there is now a test on loading reference files (see bugfix above). If this test is not passed this is considered "fatal" for the selftest.
  • The zoom function (key Z) now also works on the right axis of the graph.
  • The Reference directory can now be set from within the program.

    version 2.61 09/05/2014
  • Bug: With the dropping of the multi-language support in version 2.59, also the labels of the curvee information lines ("Measurement:", "Calculated:","Reference:","Buffer:") became empty.
  • Minor bug: The View menu was kept disabled after tab switching combined with Advanced mode turned off. 
  • Minor bug: The combination of the settings [Measurement]Move profiles to origin, [Reference]Align with measurement, and [Reference]Calculation is Gamma analysis did not move the reference. The profile in the file selftest02_real.txt is moved by 2 cm to demonstrate and test this behavior.
  • The Editor can now be hidden through an option in the View menu.

    version 2.60 28/03/2014
  • Response of directory/file viewer changed from single click to double-click.
  • Improved error detection on unknown variants of rfb format.
  • Minor bug: directory/file viewer did not return to last selected directory.
  • Recently also a concepts help item was added.
  • A new option in the View menu: Bottom axis always black.

    version 2.59 11/03/2014
  • Introduction of directory/file viewer with support for files with multiple scans.
  • Problem on some Windows 7 platforms: the multi language support could lead to a run time error at startup. This is not yet fully understood, and therefore this facility is blocked. Only the hard coded English version is now available. This improves the startup speed significantly.
  • Minor bug: small memory leak for OmniPro v6 files with film data repaired.
  • Minor bug: on loading presets the userdose level was not set.

    version 2.58 20/02/2014
  • Introduction of Check Temporary scan type in the Processing menu. When unchecked the temporary reference can be compared with any other scan.
  • Review of help file with introduction of Concepts lemma.
  • Minor bug: correction of unintended application of  Alias list to radiation device for snc files.

    version 2.57 11/02/2014
  • Introduction of Advanced Mode in the Options menu. When Advanced Mode is not checked almost all menu's and settings will be blocked. Presets will set any item regardless the state of Advanced Mode. On returning to standard mode the last known configuration and preset will be restored from disk.
  • Introduction of Linac symmetry error.
  • Small patch for OmniPro v7 ascii files: the in the data mentioned detector type is copied to the detector name, thus overwriting the default name.
  • Improved, more efficient startup.

    version 2.56 20/01/2014
  • Support for Varian w2CAD format. Multiple scans in one file are accepted.
  • Since the Varian format does not contain beam energy information, a default can be set.

    version 2.55 15/01/2014
  • Introduction of axis remapping for files that do not meet the file conventions.
  • When axis remapping is activated, axis swapping and inversion will also be stored in a preset.
  • Minor bug in transfer of preset name would prevent loading some of the presets. Also, the "!" in the file name could get lost on writing which made them invisible as preset.

    version 2.54 08/01/2014
    Internal code optimisation for registration of actions on data. No effects on output.
  • Introduction of normalisation of reference as refinement for addition of profiles.
  • Minor bug: the state of the Normalise on center option for the measurement was not used for reading a reference file. This gave only (display) effects when adding two profiles.
  • The contents of a presets file are slightly changed.
  • The OmniPro v7 format accepts float point data in any data column now.
  • normalisation in the Measurement menu has become a submenu. normalisation on the dose maximum as added as option. The reference will be normalised in the same way as the measurement and therefore needs no more separate normalisation settings.
  • A small improvement in the penumbra level search strategy to avoid a deep minimum in the center of the field.
  • Added axis title display options.
  • Added post filter option for the calculated curve.

    version 2.53 27/12/2013
  • Introduction of Addition of measurement and reference.
  • Introduction of presets.
  • A user defined colored background of the graph panel, stored in presets.
  • The names of some settings in the configuration files have been changed.

    version 2.52 19/12/2013
    Small patch for OmniPro v7 composed profiles. The result of a mathematical operation puts all results in the Ratio column only. 

    version 2.51 10/12/2013
    Introduction of a manual shift for profiles.

    version 2.50 06/12/2013
    Introduction of usage of Common Application Data environment variable ("C:\Documents and Settings\All Users\Application Data" up to WinXP and "C:\ProgramData" from Windows Vista onwards.
  • New help lemma's on configuration and installation.
  • New Command line options.
  • Minor bugfix: the Mirror to Buffer item has to (temporarily) disable any comparison with a reference profile.

    version 2.40 25/11/2013
    Introduction of 'protected' configuration file to ensure uniform behavior with multiple users. This feature can be combined with a command line option.
  • Minor bugfix: for profiles with multiple peaks a multiple peak reference was scaled incorrectly when symmetry correction for the reference was switched off. Note that alignment of the reference with the measurement can go wrong and probably should be switched off.

    version 2.39 09/10/2013
    Small glitch in user interface: the "Use PDD-fit results" enabled state did not reflect changes in the Settings Tab. This is now simplified by removing the equivalent option in this tab.

    version 2.38 25/09/2013
  • Sometimes the Nelder-Mead fit derails completely, leading to floating point calculation errors. At that point the result function is set to a very high value, leading the optimisation away from that particular combination of parameters.
  • OmniPro v6.2a is reported to produce also files with positional information denoted in mm instead of cm. This unforeseen variant is now implemented. This file format is added to the selftest as test 106.
  • Slightly improved behavior for the secondary axis notation.

    version 2.37 22/08/2013
  • Minor bugfix: the fit parameters were not scaled properly to produce 100% at the chosen normalisation depth. To show that the fit is normalised, both the from fit parameters calculated pdd and the normalisation depth are put on the messages tab.
  • Additions to help file on problem solving.

    version 2.36 14/08/2013
  • Drag-and-drop functionality into the graph area introduced for by BistroMath readable files.
  • Install program: Option for removing the local user config for Windows Vista/7/8.

    version 2.35 17/07/2013
  • SpecialMode3-functionality moved back to to initial phase of the processing cycle. A pdd-fit will not be executed when already done in SpecialMode3.
  • Number of (visible) decimals set to two for the normalisation Level and PDD Shift in the Advanced settings tab.
  • Extended the help for the pdd fit.
  • Minor bug: the visability of the Use pdd-fit results option in the Measurement menu did not respond to the activation of this facility in the Settings Tab.
  • Repairs to the RFA-output format: %BRD was written twice, %ASC was not written into this format.

    version 2.34 30/05/2013
    Refinements in user interface. Right axis stays hidden when not in use.
    Help file revisions.

    version 2.33 22/05/2013
    Introduction of manual shift for PDD's (see advanced settings).
  • SpecialMode3-functionality moved to the end of the processing cycle. This guarantees a pdd-fit which is at least as good as the displayed data. The fit results are added to the output file.
  • For SpecialMode2 PDD-fit results, when applicable, are added to the output file.
  • Minor bugfix for rfb files: Trying to read a scan beyond the maximum number of scans, due to a larger previous opened file, was handled as read error. Now the last scan is opened in such cases.

    version 2.32 15/05/2013
  • Minor bugfix: mcc files produced by the MultiCheck programme do not contain the data field SCAN_DEVICE. Therefore the file was rejected as legal mcc file although the file does contain acceptabel data. These files are accepted now.
  • For SpecialMode2 PDD-fit parameters are written to the data window.

    version 2.31 09/05/2013
    Introduction of fit model for depth dose curves.
    Introduction of Processing menu.
  • Minor bugfix: An invalid reference from the previous analysis could be displayed when opening a rfb file. This was not used actually but introduced confusion.

    version 2.30 12/04/2013
    Introduction of support for the binary rfb-format. An overview of all scan in such a file is dumpe in the messages tab.
  • Bugfix OmniPro7 format: The modality was not detected for electrons.
  • Bugfix: With the introduction of multiscan references the storage logics of references went wrong for multiscan references.

    version 2.25 28/03/2013
  • Bugfix: The SDD to SSD ratio was set to 1 when the depth of the first profile point did not equal exactly the depth of the last point. Therefore could be concluded that a diagonal scan was made. Now a small difference up to 1 mm is allowed. This effect is rare.

    version 2.24 22/03/2013
    Fix for OmniPro-v7 files: field size is actually reported as AB x GT. Assumption on this, based on history, proved to be wrong.

    version 2.23 28/02/2013
  • The range for background subtraction is set to -2000 .. 2000. Note that background subtration must be activated in the measurement menu and on the settings tab for the appropriate data type. Note that for data denoted as 'film', the generic settings are used.
  • For SpecialMode2 the file name is added in the report file.
    Minor bugfix: the measurement modification date field was not filled on reading OmniPro-v7 files. In wtx export this resulted in meaningless date information.
    Validation of watertank PTW data is still need badly. See data validation.

    version 2.22 16/02/2013
    The recently introduced axis swapping with both axis inversion in the graph area and swapping of direction indicators did not work as expected. In a readme file on the installation of OmniPro 7.4 some background information can be found. Version 7.4 complies with IEC1217 conventions while OmniPro v6 was based on IEC601. The main difference is the inline direction, which is from T to G in v7 and from G to T in v6. For now Bistromath uses from G to T direction to set up inline data. To get consistent analysis results not only the graphical representation but also the underlying data should be inverted. How this is handled in Bistromath is described in Axis swapping.
    Validation of watertank PTW data is still need badly. See data validation.

    version 2.21 11/02/2013
  • Using symmetry correction for the measured curve obviously leads to better symmetry and therefore also lower flatness. These manipulated values should however not be interpreted as standard analysis results and are presented in blue now. See also the results panel information.
  • PTW data have now been validated for MultiCheck 3.04.4 with the Starcheck Maxi.
  • Now for the Starcheck Maxi a original measurement file can be stored as reference. See Device specific Reference.
  • Support for diagonals in the undocumented OmnipPro-v7 format.
  • The inline direction in the undocumented OmnipPro-v7 format actually represents data from T to G and not G to T as assumed. This is mentioned in a readme file on the installation disk and is related to IEC1217. This was tested with a wedge field. The data can be rewritten to the OmniPro_v6 format with correct axis direction representation. Also a measurement time with one digit for the hours did not pass the filter. The workaround was: do not measure before 10 o'clock...
  • Bugfix: due to some code reorganisation reference data were stored into the working directory and not in the reference directory where they should be.

    version 2.20 08/01/2013
    The PTW data format can now be written also with the limitation that only single profile files are produced. Writing into a multi data file will only be developed when there is a broadly expressed need for this feature.
    Comparing different file types and/or different tank setups might lead to a mixup of directions and would lead to significant larger complexity of the code. Therefore the data point reading code for all file types was reviewed and partly rewritten in such a way that the data are stored internally always as G»T / A»B / U»D / L»R. As the interpretation of the data itself is not changed, this review should have no effect for any previously generated data files. However newly written data files represent the internal storage conventions as decribed above.
    This reduced complexity comes at a small cost. As data are not always presented anymore in the direction as measured, this might lead to an inverted bottom axis when compared side-by-side with the measuring system, which can be corrected with the newly introduced Axis swapping.
  • The addition of date and time to the file name has been made optional. This is also reflected in the SpecialModes 2 and 3.
  • In the file conversion tab both the PTW and RFA300 were added to the supported list of file types.
  • The interpretatation of G and T side is flipped for XiO files. For AB-profiles the direction is unclear but not critical because they are symmetric. In the physics module the wedge profile is always calculated on the GT-direction, ignoring the (UMC Utrecht) setup configuration which should lead to a wedged AB-profile.
  • Bugfix: the normalisation on the average In-Field area, introduced in version 2.14, resulted in an illegal value for depth dose curves. Both data and logic are corrected.
  • Bugfix: SpecialMode2 caused an endless waiting loop due to safety measures taken in version 2.11. Also, the wedge detection result was not used but merely the wedge angle, for deciding on the correct output string. 
  • Minor bug fix: Depth dose curves without buildup part (i.e. kV depth dose curves) caused a calculation error which is now handled properly.
  • For very small wedged fields, especially on larger depths, wedge detection might fail. In SpecialMode2 this is checked with the SpecialMode[2]Float[2] parameter. SelfTest04_xio.txt can be used to test this.
  • Improved information on the file name and parameter check of the reference data.
  • Some words on the update policy.
  • The detector type, when known, is written into the wtx/wda format as comments.
    Validation for PTW is still an open issue.

    version 2.16 08/11/2012
  • For non-square fields both GT- and AB-filedsize are represented in the file name.
  • Minor bug: decision on which special mode(s) to use went wrong.
  • For -SpecialMode3 now the preselected output format is used in stead of the predefined wtx format. Also all relevant options set for the measurement are done before writing.
  • This help file was reviewed and extended.
    Validation for PTW is still an open issue.

    version 2.15 02/11/2012
  • On export any calculated shift is now represented in the positions.
  • RFA300 files, exported from BistroMath to OmniPro 6, did not pass the scrutiny test as re-imported OmniPro v6 format due to missing values on non-critical parameters such as normalisation levels of the electrometer. Faillure on these field has been made acceptable.
    Validation for PTW is still an open issue.

    version 2.14 30/10/2012
  • For comparison across different linacs there might be more pronounced differences. Also the exchange of a gun filament may introduce unexpected differences. In the classical approach all differences are shown in relation to the central normalisation point. Now the average over the In-Field area can be chosen as normalisation for either measurement, reference or both. As alternative an arbitrary value can be set for the measurement. See normalisation of profiles for an overview.
  • After symmetry correction of the reference no rematching is done, which reduces calculation time significantly.
    Validation for PTW is still an open issue.

    version 2.13 22/10/2012
  • The average step size is no longer used to calculate a dose within the range of defined calculation width. Instead the true number of points in the calculation area is taken.
  • In automatically generated file names, as used to store reference files, the field size is left-padded with a "0" to get at least two characters. Also, when applicable, the scan angle is now correctly represented in the filename.
    Validation for PTW is still an open issue.

    version 2.12 10/10/2012
  • The interpretation of Freescans is refined. When intended as profile it is handled as a generic horizontal profile, otherwise a Fanline is detected.
  • The Measurement menu option "Generic to PDD" applies now also to fanline measurements.
  • HDF files do not contain film data anymore as default.
  • When film data are found explicitly or assumed implicitly, the file format "generic profile" is assumed for any OD to dose conversion and/or background correction.
  • For film data the edge detection based field limits are used as alternative for 50% values. Edge Detection fallback needs to be activated for this behavior.
    Validation for PTW is still an open issue.

    version 2.11 02/10/2012
  • Bugfix: before calculating a division of Measurement and Reference both curves are filtered. Unintentionally the unfiltered curves were used for this calculation. This increased the noise on the "division" curve. Therefore also the relative flatness was overestimated due to noise.
  • Where possible and meaningful, multithreading is applied. Because a lot of calculations are dependent, the gain in speed is limited.
  • Matching may be chosen as preferred method for aligning measurement and reference.
    Validation for PTW is still an open issue.

    version 2.10 26/09/2012
  • Yet another variant of the OmniPro-Accept ascii format was found: the v7.4 differs slightly from previous versions.
  • The normalisation dose and distance in the Gamma analysis are allowed to be zero. A zero setting will ignore that dimension.
  • Support for fanline scans is improved. A correct pathlength is calculated from the position data.
  • The interpretation of the Measurement menu option "Generic to PDD" is extended to Freescan/Point-To-Point profiles.
  • The OmniPro format RFA300 can now be written. These files can be imported into OmniPro.
  • The usage of the alias list is slightly changed for the linac name. It is no longer aplied on the linac name itself but only on the filename of the reference file. This preserves the name of the linac in both the measurement and the reference in the screen representation.
    Validation for PTW is still an open issue.

    version 2.09 08/08/2012
    This version has been published with a lot of subversions (in the build number range 231 - 253) over several months and is still in beta stage for mcc-data, Sun Nuclear data, improved filtering, median filtering and gamma analysis.
  • When the scaling of data of the Calculated or Buffer plot differs significantly, the right axis will be used for those curves.
  • When the buffer curve is activated and there are no data available, the derivative is presented.
  • Context-sensitive help is now given with F1, this was general help.
  • A warnings mechanism has been added to inform on non-fatal problems.
  • The introduction of Gamma analysis offers a new measure of field consistency for non-flat flields like the Flattening Filter Free beams. The dose difference can be relative to the global normalisation dose value or the local dose.
  • The new median filter is used on the results of a division or  gamma analysis . The quadratic filter is extended with a fallback strategy. The number of used points for filtering is not based on the average step size anymore. Instead only points within the range defined by the filtering width are taken. 
  • The PTW CC-Export V1.9 text format (.mcc) and Sun Nuclear text format (.snctxt) can be read. The mmc-format was also tested as clipboard data in a pre-market release of the PTW 2012 software. Validation of these formats under different circumstances is still needed at this moment. Therefore these imports are [beta-status]. Support for a new subversion of the format can be handled now too.
  • Related to the PTW data range, typically with a maximum in the order of 1, this lead to a limited data resolution when exporting to the wms format. This is solved now.
  • The diagonal detection is refined.
  • The normalisation of depth dose curves is explained extensively in this help file.
  • A private patch of Sun Nuclear also delivers a clipboard format, which might or might not be published in coming versions of that software.
  • The handling of generic profiles is refined. In default mode they are handled as profiles. Through a menu item this can be forced to a PDD type.
  • Minor bug: a non-existent references path stored in the ini file did create unexpected errors. Both the references path and the source of the unexpected errors are now checked.
  • Futile bug: the absolute flatness value is rounded to integer value when larger then 10% and a relative flatness is presented to fit within a limited character space.
  • Klemhöfer was renamed to BistroMath to acknowledge the wide range of supported data formats and the new ways of looking at numbers from profile analysis.
  • The RFA300-format is supported.
  • The list of offered file types in the Open... dialog is revised and extended.
  • Bug: incomplete lines in the alias list editor fixed.
  • Updates of this help file.

    version 2.08 08/03/2012
    Introduction of Mirror profile and Mirror to Buffer.
