  • Bug repair: With the setting "Assign origin to all 2D array lines" (currently only implemented for the StarcheckMaxi) switched on, the origin value was not preserved for the reference only when the already available reference data were reused. Instead a zero value was inserted, leading to a sharp edge in the middle and effectively two halved profiles. This is typically the case when the next profile from a multi-profile set is viewed. Now this origin value is both preserved and only used when larger than zero.
  • Minor bug repair: A change in the Extendend Symmetry submenu was not reflected in the Results panel (if Extended Symmetry was defined as panel rule) until this change was stored in a configuration and the program was restarted. Now this is reflected immediately for the next data input.
  • Some possibly non-printable characters are now avoided on the screen.
  • More checks on invalid clipboard data.
  • Improvement: Now BistroMath checks whether the decimal separator on the Windows system is the point symbol ("."). If not, the program will immediately exit after a message is shown.
  • Improvement: The triggering of the "user's dose level" annotation is now triggered by both the explicit menu choice and the application of the evaluation type "u".
  • Improvement: A call to a ClearScreen procedure is guaranteed on reading data through any route, to avoid the impression of a success while the analysis actually failed.
  • Speed improvement: to check file types now only once per file the file is opened. Early checks on small clipboard texts which cannot represent any data.

    See also:
     Configuration
     History v1.00 - v1.99
     History v2.00 - v2.69
     History v2.70 - v2.98
     History v3.00 - v3.25


    History v4.00 - 4.23
    history

    version 4.23
    build 765, 13/09/2021
  • Minor bugfix: Reference file names could still have a "d" for diagonal included for non-standard profiles. Three underlying issues were found and corrected. Diagonal detection was always done but reset in the final analysis. Then the refererence was already loaded. Also, after final diagonal check, still the file type was allowed to change to FFF. Now the load reference code forces full analysis.
  • Minor bugfix: Symmetry correction failed for all file types except the Standard file type because only for that file type the slope data were calculated. Now this is enabled for all but the Small file types. For small fields this is not allowed in both the code and the user interface.
  • Minor bugfix: Without symmetry correction of the reference, the division of the measurment with itself as reference will be exactly 1 in all points. This was seen as invalid result during analysis.


    version 4.22.1
    build 763, 01/08/2021
  • Minor bugfix: On some displays the lines in the Results panel where overlapping due to a wrongly calculated line spacing, based on deviations from design time circumstances. Now a suitable font size is calculated and all positioning parameters are derived from this value only.
  • Stability improvement: Pressing <PageUp> or <PageDown> repeatedly very fast might hang the application. An extra check for has been inserted before accepting the keystrokes.


    version 4.21
    build 761, 16/07/2021
  • Minor bugfix: When Multiple-Scan Indexing (intended for unstructured files) was checked, Bistromath could fail to accept a reference for structured multiple scan files after paging to the next scan. After more investigations it was found that writing text data to a non-zero stream (i.e. the second time) would fail.


    version 4.20
    build 759, 16/06/2021
  • Major bugfix for version 4.19. Some data were accessed after destruction of its owner. This would occur when a temporary reference was set and then the program was closed.
  • Minor bugfix for version 4.14 - 4.19: looping of multiscan files using <PageUp> / <PageDown> failed.


    version 4.19.1
    build 757, 11/06/2021
    For verification and testing purposes, reporting is improved and extended in log level 3:
     ->FindLevelPos[Measured] at normalised level 0.50: -19.932 (-20.10|-19.80|-19.80) cm / 19.969 (19.80|20.10|20.10) cm
    In this example, for the procedure and curve, the left and right border positions ((leftmost data point for the analysis range, nearest point, rightmost analysis point) are given.


    version 4.19
    build 756, 07/06/2021
  • Minor bugfix: When the history list size is reduced the primary engine must be preserved because it contains the shared data of the Configuration tab.
  • New version of config file repair/udate list: BM753_renamed_elements.ini.


    version 4.18
    build 754, 04/06/2021
  • Minor bugfix: BistroMath tracks which method is used for borders, CoF and normalisation point. Since FFF detection only can be done after analysis of the borders, these are based on the Standard Field Type settings. However, after detecttion the borders were still presented with these Standard settings. The border analysis must be repeated with the settings for the new found FFF Field Type.


    version 4.17
    build 753, 01/06/2021
  • New: for FFF detection now a minimal field size can be set explicitely in the Field Types tab.
  • New: in the General detection strategy sub menu now a positions in mm interpretetation can be set for generic data.


    version 4.16
    build 752, 18/05/2021
  • Bug fix: the Top Model always used the maximum as central position. This is incorrect for wFF beams. Now the center position is used for wFF beams and either the center of maximum for FFF beams.
  • The evaluation types 't' and 'K' were added.
  • In the view menu a switch for the Top Model is added.
  • The Swap axis indicators are moved from the view menu to the Advanced Settings tab because these should not be used routinely.
  • The Linac symmetry error settings are moved from the Settings tab to the Advanced Settings tab.
  • The PDD fit setings are moved from the Advanced Settings tab to the Settings tab.


    version 4.15
    build 750, 04/05/2021
  • Minor improvement/bug in GUI: Changes in the alias list needed a explicite reload on each file (or completely new data) in the history to become effective. Now BistroMath processes the complete history list in such cases.
  • Information added in this help file on the Area Ratio and the field size.
  • Support for multiple single file scans gathered in one single file is now also provided in manual (non-automated) mode. See keyboard functions.


    version 4.14
    build 749, 30/04/2021
  • Minor improvement/bug in GUI: The File menu is now immediately updated after a change of SpecialModes in the Processing menu.
  • Bugfix for IBA multiple single scans in one file on clipboard. This concept worked fine when the data were first saved in a file and then dropped on BistroMath. However, the direct copy onto the clipboard left BistroMath in a hung state for the second scan in the data.


    version 4.13
    build 748, 20/04/2021
  • New: added 'Near Origin' option as Center of Field definition. This enables a stable outcome for the field center when it is 'almost zero'.


    version 4.12
    build 746, 02/04/2021
  • Introduction to Profile Evaluation Points in this help file.
  • New: added 'Z' / 'z' to the Results Panel rules for a rescaled positon to the nominal SSD as implementation for Profile Evaluation Points expressed as position in cm.
  • New: added annotation 'X', which will show the actually used X value for a Results Panel rule.


    version 4.11
    build 743, 17/03/2021
  • When a file is reloaded from the raw data, a manually applied shift is preserved. For a multiscan file this reload might actually read another scan. In that case the shift should not be preserved.
    build 745, 30/03/2021
  • Code reviews, no functional changes.


    version 4.10
    build 742, 16/03/2021
  • This version is made in Lazarus IDE v.2.0.12 with FreePascal compiler v3.2.0.
  • With the introduction of the MRlinac Field Type in version 4.08 the detection of FFF features would fail for the MRlinac type as by design Field Types are mutually exclusive. But FFF features are a shared property of both the MRlinac and the FFF Field Type. Therefore now the FFF feature detection is available for profiles already designated as MRlinac and undesignated Standard profiles. When FFF features are detected this is now stored in a (reintroduced) "FFF detected" flag for that profile. A Standard profile will be set as FFF Field Type in this case. A more detailed explanation can be found in the Field Types topic. This has also repercussions for the Results Panel rules: a new cond: "f" is introduced. The visibility of related graphical elements depend now on FFF features.
  • The default SSD is now linked to the Field Type.
  • The In-Field area can also be derived from the nominal field size as set in the data header. The concept is clarified here.
  • Minor bugfix: Due to a recent code regrouping pull down lists were not read anymore from the configuration file. The default at startup was presented instead.
  • Minor bugfix: SpecialMode3 now sets the configured file type correctly.
  • The diagonal detection depends now on the Field Type.
  • New: the slope of the sigmoid in the inflection point is added to the Results panel options.
  • Now also the installation program checks regional settings of Windows for the correct decimal separator. BistroMath already did this, but the message has been clarified.




    version 4.09
    build 733, 21/02/2021
  • Bugfix: For low-resolution profiles like the StarCheck sometimes the 80% or 20% position were not calculated correctly because of selecting the wrong range in the data, leading to a clearly wrong penumbra value. This (rather old) part of the code is completely reviewed and improved. Even on extreme sparse data it will function as expected now.
  • Minor bug: When switching to the next item in the history list, the reference was lost when there was not set a temporary reference. A reload was the work-around. This is fixed now.
  • Code review: the multi-threaded Nelder-Mead code was redesigned as singular engine with shared data such that multiple independent engines can run in their own thread. Progress reporting is now sent asynchronously by the main thread, thus avoiding many multi-threading complications. Procedure calls were optimised for maximum efficiency.
  • Code review: some memory leaks due to not freed structures before closing the program were resolved.
  • Reducing the size of the history list will also unset the temporary reference if it is no longer available.
  • Potential log(0) situation for right axis scaling avoided. Was never triggered in my tests.
  • Potential zero division on pdd-fit normalisation avoided which was already handled by a try..except statement anyway.
  • Code is now also compilable with the upcoming Lazarus v.2.0.12.


    version 4.08
    build 731, 12/02/2021
  • Minor bugfix: Log levels higher than 2 produce a lot of input, making the contents of the messages tab very large. Cleaning was only done at the end of the analysis cycle, making the application unresponsive and terribly slow. Now this is done immedeately when neccessary.
  • Efficiency improvement: when paging through the history unfrozen data were completely processed twice.
  • Minor visual improvement: Smart formatting for left axis labels to show extra decimals when needed.
  • Minor visual improvement: Analysis now always sets the Field Type as priority message (see below).
  • New: Support for Electron and MRlinac Field Type in cond: statement of Results Panel Rules. The  cond: value for a valid reference is "r" and not "v" as published before in this manual. 


    version 4.07
    build 729, 14/01/2021
  • New: Ìn the analysis engine a priority message can be generated. This wil be shown as last message on the statusbar.


    version 4.06.3
    build 728, 15/12/2020
  • Minor bugfix: structured multiscan files (2D arrays) could only be used as temporary reference for all scan lines with activation Index multi reference in the reference menu. The design goal was that the latter setting was only needed for unstructured data sets, i.e. a bunch of scans.

    version 4.06.2
    build 727, 08/12/2020
  • New: Issues were reported on the Fedora platfom only with unresponsiveness for the key combination <Ctrl>+<Alt>+<R> to unlock Save as Reference and other critical menu items. This could not be reproduced. See the Advanced Settings tab on how to make the Unlock item visible permanently.

    version 4.06.1
    build 726, 27/11/2020
  • New: Support for automated processing of multiple single file scans gathered in one single file.
  • Minor bugfix: due to the efficiency improvement in version 4.05, multi-scan files in the w2CAD format failed to read. The underlying data check procedure now works as specified.
  • Bugfix: the Files tab would not find all registered files due to a missing "." for each extension in the list of registered file extensions .


    version 4.05.7
    build 724, 12/11/2020
  • Small code improvement: The evaluation type "u" which calls for the border postiton at users value, in the SpecialMode2-configuration can now be extended with any numeric value like "unn" where nn will be replaced with the used dose level.
  • Efficiency improvement: All raw data are first checked as potentially binary file type and, when not found to be of a known binary type, opened again in text mode. As remnant from the Delphi era both data streams were kept in memory. Now the binary data stream is copied in memory as raw bytes to a text stream. Then the binary stream is emptied, thus also avoiding to open the file twice.
  • Performance/bug repair: When in the Measurement menu User Dose Level was selected as border evaluation level (and a reference was loaded and alignemnet of the reference was chosen), this was not calculated in due time, which sent BistroMath executing an extremely time consuming profile matching procedure, which might also give a subtle different shift result. Alse the field width at user's level failed to present although both borders were available. Now the shortcut of not calculating this value as default during profile analysis is removed. If not used, the user might configure the User Dose Level to 50%, which is also the default. Then the code will take this already obtained result for maximum efficiency.
  • A minor inconsistency was found: The Linac Error calculation still used a fixed d50 border instead of the border definition of the actual Field Type.
  • Some options, like Detect diagonals and Ignore zero steps were not passed timely to the actually used analysis object (also with no history list), failing some profiles to open.
  • For OmniPro v8 files the by OmniPro added text " Accelerator" was not chopped off, failing to identify a reference.
  • In an attempt to move to standard FreePascal the axis sign correction data were accidently initialised to 0 and not to 1. This might nullify positions also and therefore failing to read the data. At a second attempt this would be repaired.
  • A recently introduced feature to chop off zero data points at the end of files (for Varian Eclipse data points outside the body contour) is now limited to depth doses. This intoduced a failure in the selftest.
  • Files of the w2CAD type failed to read (also found in the selftest).
  • The selftest also failed unexpectedly on the edge detection of wedge profiles. This was tracked down to the derivative function where a valid result was set to invalid. This error was introduced between 2016 and 2018 and also found in the last Delphi releases.
  • For a window larger then the minimum required height BistroMath would decrease the height due to a complete rebuild of the results panel every time another tab was selected. Now this instruction, introduced for good measure, is removed again from the tab switching code.
  • When application of a reference fails, more details will be given if the loglevel is increased (v.4.05.2).
  • Insertion of the TG line origin in other scan lines for the StarCheckMaxi will be allowed only in DOSE mode (v.4.05.3).
  • Severe bug fit: A local fitting procedure called another procedure for deciding which data points to use without complete initialisation. In almost all circumstances this was corrected, but recently the filtered version of one measurement hit the sweet spot for this local fit to go significantly outside the range set by the data. This error can be traced back to early 2016 but never revealed iself (v.4.05.4).
  • Severe bug fit: The previous patch (v.4.05.4) reduced the number of used points for position calculations for low resolution data like 2D-data arrays to just one where at least two was intended. As a result the calculated posittion would be the nearest data point (v.4.05.5).
  • Minor bug repair: For measured data values in the range of multiple thousands, the penumbra sigmoid fit could fail. Now the fit is done on normalised data; when applied the figmoid scaling factor is applied again to represent the data as measured (v4.05.6). Also the calculated errors have to be downscaled as they are the square of the differences (v.4.05.7).


    version 4.04
    build 714, 16/10/2020
  • Bugfix for StarCheck files: Although not complety diagnosed, the combination of using the history list and opening a PTW StarCheck file might not present the inline profile initially and therefore not refresh the stored value for the central detector. When instead the crossline was shown first and the setting Assign origin to both 2D array lines was checked, a wrong value for the central detector was applied. Now it is forced that always the first profile of a multi scan file is presented.
  • New: A Field Type Electrons is introduced.
  • New: Legacy support for oddly formatted numbers.
  • Small code improvement: When not frozen, for data sets a complete reprocess is forced upon cycling through the history list.
  • Field type name in axis title is not converted to lowercase and brackets are removed.
  • Corrected alignment of some text elements in Advanced Settings tab.
  • Edge fallback strategy still compared d50 and derivative instead primary and fallback method. Forcing makes no sense anymore. Just change the primary method.


    version 4.03
    build 710, 12/10/2020
  • New: file input-only support for the Varian Eclipse TPS output format.
  • New: BistroMath uses now the SoundEx function to find month text values for multiple languages. For example 'may', 'mai' and 'mei' all give the same soundex function result. Therefore, when text is used for the month, the order 'MDY' and 'DMY' are now working irrespective the real order for day and month.
  • Small code improvement: a temporary reference with lacking information parameters could not be passed through the history list as valid reference, even with Check Temporary Scan type switched off.
  • Small code improvement: Eclipse files with multiple zero-value data points ate the end were found. This might give a large overshoot of the used quadratic filter at the very end of a pdd. This had only effects on the maxium of the graph but annoying anyway. Now those points are chopped off in an early stage.


    version 4.02
    build 707, 03/10/2020
  • Important bugfix: Due to a code revision error for the history list, version 4.01 accesses undefined memory locations for SpecialMode2 handling only. This is repaired.
  • Code improvement: the history feature did not combine very well the temporary reference feature. Now the the latest temporary reference is transferred to the next data set (when not frozen). See details. A complete review of the reference loading process was done. It is higly complicated by the multiple types of possible data types in both text and binary format and whether or not a data set is frozen upon cycling through the history list.
  • New: When a temporary reference is set, this will now be applied immediately on the current data set.
  • New: When a temporary reference is taken
  • New: When a large data set is defined as temporary reference, this may take a while. Progress messages will show on the statusbar.
  • New: The sigmoid penumbra model can be plotted over the measurement or reference (if selected). This feature can be actived in the View menu. This and many other grapical elements can be selected.
  • The Indicators item in the View menu is renamed to In-Field Area indicators.
  • When paging through the history list, the last analysis message stays visible although this might disagree with the newly displayed data set. Therefore now a message on the set Field Type is shown.


    version 4.01
    build 704, 19/09/2020
  • In any saved configuration file (not presets) information on SpecialMode items will be inserted.
  • SpecialMode[2]Float[2] (wedge detection) is not used anymore; standard analysis will do this with the given settings on the Field Types tab.
  • The text format of the left axis markers is optimised for both Zoomed and Unzoomed mode.
  • New: A history list is introduced.
  • New: Multiple files can be dropped or opened, limited by the size of the history list.
  • Added some condional compiler statements for the Fedora platform. By definition no effect for the here published Windows platform release.


    version 4.00
    build 699, 14/08/2020
  • All changes, most of them initiated in the porting process, as published in v3.30 and subversions are ported to version 4.00. This is a long list as the last 3.30 subversion was published in july 2020.
  • Due to the deprecated support of the x87 math processor in Windows10/64bits exact reproduction with previous versions before 3.30.18 is not possible.
  • New: The sigmoid model may be used as alternative to calculate 50% border positions. Also the inflection point is more precise calculated as the derivative function which amplifies the noise by its nature.
  • New: The profile value at a position as percentage of the border to center of field is introduced (Profile Evaluation Point) as evaluation type "r" / "R" for the results panel and specialmode2.
  • New: The first page of this helpfile contains a clickable image for fast navigation.
  • New: In the viewing menu an Auto Unzoom item is added for FFF profiles.
  • New: All menu shortcuts can be changed through the configuration file.
  • New: The right axis can be linked to the grid.
  • New: A pdf print of the current window.
  • New: In the Result Panel rules two new conditions (N=Standard field type, S=Small field type, see below) and field size limits are introduced.
  • Changes in configuration file: a lot of elements were renamed. Backward compatibility is guaranteed with on-the-fly conversion. See configuration issues.
  • Minor design change: The statusbar is now split in two parts. At the right side the confirmed scan number in a multi scan file is shown; for a single data set the number of measurement points.
  • Minor design change: The right axis labels are now aligned with the left axis grid at the minor costs of less nice numbers.
  • Minor design change: The SelfTest is removed from standard release builds although the code is maintained and used during development. Therefore SpecialMode4 is also removed.
  • Minor design change: Graph panel, graph grid and general panels (as a group) have configurable colors.
  • Minor design change: When switching between tabs the shift of a curve is preserved; using Load current data in the File menu does not.
  • Design change: Edge annotations which reflect the primary edge definition can be suppressed.
  • Design change: A new information type is introduced: the Field type. This replaces the (unnamed) default, Wedge and FFF charcteristic with the new Field types Standard, FFF, Small and Wedge.
  • Design change: The annotation for edge values based on the sigmoid inflection point is changed from s to inn, where nn is the actual dose level. A new 50%-level based on sigmoid analysis with annotation s is introduced. The evaluation types for these choices are 'i' and 'I' respectively. The sigmoid may also be used to find the position at user's level (evalution type 'U').
  • Minor bug fix: For generic files the measurement option Generic to PDD failed.
  • Minor bug fix: The generic data reading object was too picky on empty lines and non-printable characters.
  • Minor bug fix: On changeover from a single scan to a array scan data set that started with the same scan type, SSD, field size and depth the single scan reference was maintained as "valid". Only when changing to the next scan in the data set the correct reference arrray scan was taken.
  • Small improvements for the histogram presentation to get a better normalisation.
  • A lot of visual elements have been renamed or replaced with other structures completely.

    build 700, 07/09/2020
  • The Settings tab and Advanced Setting tab are slightly reorganised.
  • Bug fix: A reporting message for the second or next reference of a multireference caused an unhandled error.
  • Bug fix: Added aliases were never used.
  • Bug fix: always the FFF radius was used for the Top model.
  • New:The Field Type MRlinac is added.
  • New: The application of the Top model is widened to all Field types.
  • New: Added 'C' als Evaluation Type. to show the curvature of the Top model.
     
  • New: Actually applied aliases for the current measurment are marked in the Aliases tab.
  • New: The inflection point based penumbra width is now supported according to NCS-33. Therefore the functionality of the Results Panel rule 'p' is also changed.

    build 701, 08/09/2020
  • Minor design change: Now autolooping (<Ctrll>+<PgDown>) ends effectively with the last valid scan in a multiscan file.
  • New: Autocentering of a profile is now optional in SpecialMode3.

    build 702, 09/09/2020
  • Minor bug: In the file Conversion tab the field to change the name template did not become visible.
  • New: The .rfb file type is now also supported in the Conversion tab.
  • For multi scan files there will be displayed one line per scan during conversion.

    Recent history
    history

    These releases are published as independent developer to keep BistroMath alive as open-source software for the radiotherapy community. Feedback is appreciated.

    version 4.25
    build 772, 15/04/2022
  • Minor bug fix: the zoom function did not work as expected in gamma analysis mode.
  • Minor bug fix: For OmniPro v7 / v8 ascii indentification line there might be multiple spaces instead of a single <tab>. The identification rules were too strict for this situation.
  • New: Implementation of Gamma Pass rate. The standard Panel Rules have been extended to accommodate this feature. Also, a "0" can be added to take the user interface default for In-Field area or complete field..
  • New: Explicit FFF assignments can be read and written in OmniPro v6/7/8, IBA RFA300 .asc, PTW and Sun Nuclear .snctxt and clipboard file formats. 
  • New: For the gamma calculation now also the curve is limited to the Infield Area if chosen.
  • New: Allowance of multiple depth dose normalisation definitions for the same modality. They may or may not depend on the Field type and/or linac name. This feature is fully backwards compatible with current configuration files. Howver the format of new or updated configuration files is slightly adjusted. See the Configuration files page on details and interpretation.


    version 4.24
    build 767, 18/02/2022
  • Support for files on other drives in SpecialMode1.
  • For Depth dose curves a open water surface was assumed, leading to a hard coded condition for the normalisation position to be larger than zero. This might not be the case for gantry angles 90 or 270. Therefore this condition is removed.
    build 766, 31/01/2022
  • Code change with no functional effects to avoid compiler platform dependencies.
  • Tested with Lazarus version 2.2.0. In debug compilation mode some changes in compiler switches were needed.

     Known limitations



    Calculation methods

    general information 

    General remarks
    The Omnipro software allows measuring points at irregular positions. Moreover, the measuring speed an therefore the measurement point density may be changed during a scan. This implicates that nowhere a regular interval may be expected which complicates all calculations severely.

    Extracting data from profile
    Values like the maximum value or a position at a given level do generally not coincide with one single point in the curve data. Therefore some way of interpolation is needed. A further complication is the noise in the measurements giving need to include more points in the surroundings.
    Two different methods are used in Bistromath.

    Linear interpolation
    This is done on base of two points: the nearest point and the second nearest point. The interpolation between those two points is straightforward. This method is used for matching two curves and merging two curves. In those case the goal is to stay as closely to the raw data as possible.

    Quadratic fit
    When final analysis results need to be calculated, a best estimate is wanted for a noisy dataset. Therefore a number of points is taken in the neighbourhood of the nearest point. The number of points is derived from the (average) step size and user defined range called the Calculation width.   This closely resembles the quadratic filter, which uses its own calculation range.

    BistroMath now is open source. Maintenance efforts outweigh the benefits of keeping code explanation pages up to date.

    See also:
     Settings,
     Advanced Settings,
     Edge detection.




    On 80 bits and 64 bits floating points

    general information 

    Introduction
    Mirosoft has annouced not to support the x87 coprocessor on the Windows 10/64 bits platform. Its use is deprecated and can be stopped in the future. This can be relevant with context changes (i.e. the processor is going to do something else) and not all registers are preserved. However there are still a large number of 32 bits applications that need to be supported. The 80 bits extended floating point is dependent on the registers in the x87 coprocessor.
    A text value like '9.1' will be converted to exactly 9.1 on the Delphi 32 bits platform using the Extended 80 bits type.

    Freepascal uses 64 bits
    Freepascal (FPC) follows the formal statements and silently changes the still existing Extended to the Double type, a 64 bits floating point type.
    Now the FPC StrToFloat function will produce 9.09999999999996 for the string '9.1'. For other string values the actual numerical value migth be just over the intended value.

    So what?
    BistroMath uses the distance between points to decide whether they are used to contribute to the local filtered value:
          while Abs(twPosCm[P1]-twPosCm[Pc])>cm2 do
    When points have a perfect regular spacing, in the distance between two positions there still is introduced a randomness by the 64 bits truncations which might make the difference a little bit smaller or larger. To avoid incomparable results a new discrete comparison is introduced in Delphi version 3.30.17 which can also be used in FPC:
          while Round(twcDefDiscretisationMult*Abs(twPosCm[P1]-twPosCm[Pc]))>kcm2 do
    This enables to show that both versions really perform identical.


    Responsibility and legal issues
    general information 


    This software comes with no warranties whatsoever. The author is retired and not associated anymore with any radiotherapy institute. He can not be held responsible for consequences of using this software.

    The user and only the user is responsible for his or hers decisions concerning the proper functioning of radiation therapy equipment. This software is merely a tool to support these decisions. With using BistoMath you agree with these conditions.

    Software as medical device: risk analysis
    general information 

    The text below is copied from a provisional functional specifications document as input for the local (software) Quality Management System. 

    BistroMath is not a stand-alone package.  It is a workflow optimisation for comparison with a reference.


    In the screendump above one of the "selftest" files is shown. The original raw data were shifted 20 mm. 
  • The shift is reflected in the Center value.
  • A reference is presented; its date and time can be verified.
  • The reference is shifted correctly towards the measurement. The required shift is reported.
  • The reference "looks" more or less "horizontal".
  • The In-Field area indicators show, with some estimation from the graphical presentation, a width of 0.8*40*1.05=33.6 cm.
  • The differences with the measurement can readily be evaluated from the graph as it is zoomed to a nice window. Despite the noise the it can be seen that the difference wihin the In-Field area is everywhere less then 1%, the maximum is somewhat more than 0.5%.
  • The total height range within the In-Field area of the measurement can be estimated as the calculated Absolute flatness as closely to 2%.
  • The total height range over the In-Field area of the calculated ratio is closely represented by the minimum value as about 0.7%, which is also the Relative flatness.
  • The symmetry is much harder to estimate from the graph in most cases. In this case it can be concluded that it should be in the same range as the flatness.

    All the analysis results can be replicated in the source applications for these data. Due to noise levels, choices in normalisation point and filtering small differences will be found. Although the blue ratio curve is not available in the source applications, the same code is used to derive is value for the flatness. They just reflect what the user assesses as being acceptable in the graph. Some limits are given on the parameters as being acceptable but this is equivalent to obvious deviations from the reference graph.

    For field borders and field width a comparison with a reference is not meaningful. It could be calculated with a gamma analysis, but still would suffer with interpretation issues. The beam limiting devices are constraint to narrow performance limits, little more then the technical achievable deviations. All adjustments are made with built-in software on the linac, the Elekta workflows. Some user influence is possible with the table height for the calibration tool, a machined plate called the pixeltool. There are discussions whether the resultant field borders at 50% should represent the result as the Elekta workflow optimises dose contiguity.
    The 50% field borders do reproduce with high accuracy wit all known applications on the department, typically with 0.1 mm or less. The only difference is IBA Omnipro for small FFF fields. Thisis analysed and highly unstable in the Omnipro software. This was reported to IBA and they confirmed that the analysis method in Omnipro was not suitable for small fields. This was already a design choice in BistroMath: small fields from a FFF beam should be considered as wFF beam. By zooming in on the graph this can be readily confirmed.
    The first derivative in combination with statistical technicques is capable of identifying the penumbras of any field, including wedged beams. This was developed because the wedge information has been missing from the clipboard data generated by Omnipro. As such, the peak in the derivative does represent the steepest part of the penumbra, but this is not necessarily equivalent to the 50% level. More and more it has become clear that they are generally not the same. A well-designed first derivative has to deal with amplified noise and challenges of low data density. Additonal shaping of the peak is needed to overcome both challenges. A second order polynomal function can be modeled as forward calculation without further optimisation. 
    Concluding: the position of the derivative peak is dependent on the shape of the profile and generally around the 53% level. From independent research it was already concluded that the optimal level to define Elekta Agility treatment head jaw positions is 53%. As such this is now defined in our workflows.
    During still ongoing discussions on a missing protocol for FFF beams, in the Dutch NCS-33 subcomittee has been proposed to abandon the 50% level completely and use the inflection point of a sigmoid function. The sigmoid function is a simple four-parameter model which can be initialised with high accuracy from the first derivative position and some data from the penumbra area. To bring these thoughts forward this model is incorporated in BistroMath. Based on a challenge set out by PTW the results of BistroMath could be exactly replicated by completely independent software at the AVL. Again, the position of the inflection point is variable because the beam shapes vary, and can be found at a level of 53%-56%. The advantage of the sigmoid model is, that it takes data of the complete penumbra, which also makes it less susceptible to noise and lack of data points. By definition the sigmoid model describes a larger portion of the penumbra. As long as a bit of the shoulders is incorporated in the data for the model the inflection point is highly stable and very tolerant for any specific data range.
    Inflection point and first derivative peak should match with tight tolerances and in practice do so. Subtle differences can be understood and explained from their methods.
    Field borders from any software source are only used to adjust the BLD's at minute levels (less than 0.5 mm) or used as trigger for the Elekta workflow.



    A depth dose curve (PDD) can be readily viewed in any water phantom software package. Both photon results PDDx and electron results Dnn can be derived from these packages. There are some limitations however: as the UMCU applies fixed normalisation depths, the results generally will not be identical in the standard workflow. They can be made the same at any moment by changing the normalisation strategy. Filtering, which should be applied, may reveal small differences, but are insignificant for these calculations.
    As explained before, the visual presentation is configured to show differences relative to the absolute normalisation point. For photons this is at 10 cm depth. By their nature PDD's represent a wide range values, all being more or less equally important. Both measurement and some manually loaded reference can be normalised to 10 cm in any package also. But due to the wide dynamic range only the ratio of both curves will reveal the differences as an (ideally) flat line on a separate scale.
    When photon PDDx values fail to meet the requirements completely always profile differences have to be considered in choices when at what to adjust, mostly not made by one single individual. Adjustments should also be understood by reviewing underlying linac parameters.

    Summarising, any point a comparison with any other software platform can be done. Some results, such as inflection point calculation are not available however, or highly complicated when comparison of two profiles is involved.

    For beam shape both fast check 2D-arrays and a vast history are available. For beam energy assesment completely independent dosimetry based methods are available and mandatory after beam adjustment.

    A wide range of "selftest" data has been gathered over the years to check all main features and a wide range of the infrequently used capabilities. 

    BistroMath nor its results are never used in a stand-alone context but in a well-developed system of peer review, double checks and supporting independent information sources. It may be concluded that the QMS does not apply to this software application.
